headline: Saving Money, Poisoning Workers
keywords: ['n-Propyl Bromide (nPB)', 'Editorials', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: There is plenty of blame to go around for the neurological damage caused by toxic fumes at Royale Comfort Seating.
lead_paragraph: The workers at Royale Comfort Seating in Taylorsville, N.C., had a simple but grueling job. For 10 hours at a stretch they spray-glued pieces of polyurethane foam into shapes that became the spongy filling of cushions sold to many top furniture brands. Unfortunately, the glue contained a dangerous chemical known as n-propyl bromide, or nPB, and the spray guns left a yellowish fog in the air that coated everything in sight. Exposure to the toxic fumes left some workers so dizzy at the end of the day that they walked as if drunk.

headline: Jury Selection Continues in Trial on Jackson’s Death
abstract: The family of Michael Jackson is suing Anschutz Entertainment Group for wrongful death, claiming it hired the doctor who administered the drugs that led to his death.
lead_paragraph: A global corporation accused of pushing a beloved entertainer to his death. A family whose internal squabbles have been tabloid catnip for decades. A courtroom crowded with lawyers, but off limits to television cameras.

headline: India’s Novartis Decision
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Editorials']
abstract: India’s Supreme Court ruling should help protect the availability of cheap generic drugs for poor patients.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court in India ruled on Monday that Novartis, the pharmaceutical company, should not be given a patent for a cancer drug because it was too similar to Novartis’s earlier version. The decision, which is the culmination of a high-profile, seven-year legal battle, should help protect the availability of cheap generic drugs for poor patients.

headline: Another Jaded Generation of Bright Young Things
abstract: Alexandra McGuinness’s “Lotus Eaters” are pretty, rich and aimless, but they sure have nice digs.
lead_paragraph: Pity the young, affluent and tragically beautiful, if we are to believe  “Lotus Eaters.” The film, from Alexandra McGuinness, throws you into a hazy nonstop Saturnalia in elegant British surroundings as decadent 20-somethings drink, smoke, copulate, dress up, take drugs and flail with their aspirations and arbitrary passions. Its heroine, Alice (Antonia Campbell-Hughes), wants to leave modeling to be an actress; her ex-boyfriend, Charlie (Johnny Flynn), is giving rehab another shot; Marlon (Alex Wyndham) chases Alice; Suzie (Amber Anderson) frets that she is losing Felix (Benn Northover) to Alice; the somewhat older Orna (a good Cynthia Fortune Ryan) pursues Felix while manipulating Alice; and the hapless Benedict (Liam Browne) is just trying to bed whomever he can.

headline: Berlin Exhibition on Judaism Hits a Nerve
abstract: “The Whole Truth,” a show at the Jewish Museum in Berlin, includes a Jewish person sitting in a glass box for two hours every day except Saturday.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Bill Glucroft is not an expert on the Torah, Israeli politics or the Holocaust. But on Thursday afternoon he fielded questions on each of those subjects from visitors to the Jewish Museum here in the German capital as part of a new exhibition.

headline: Two Lonely Souls in Temporary Shelter
abstract: In “Stranger Things,” a young woman arrives in an English seaside village to clear out her dead mother’s house, and finds an unexpected resident.
lead_paragraph: Something unexpectedly profound emerges from the flimsiest of stories in “Stranger Things,” a drama so modest and trusting of its two leads that any directing flourishes might have shattered its spell.

headline: Path to Citizenship Divides Congress and, Polls Show, Confuses Country
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: While lawmakers wrangle about how quickly immigrants should move on the path to citizenship, some Americans are questioning what such a path would mean in practice.
lead_paragraph: A path to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants living in the country illegally has become central to the debate on overhauling the immigration system, but recent polls have indicated that many Americans are still making up their minds on the issue, with doubts persisting about what such a path would mean in practice.

headline: Nationwide Insurance Teams With ‘Mad Men’
abstract: The insurance company made a deal with AMC to sponsor the entire sixth season of the series.
lead_paragraph: A TELEVISION series about advertising will again feature advertising about advertising.

headline: Calls for Reform in New York
abstract: As New York State politics suffer yet another corruption scandal, the arrests have energized those calling for reform in Albany.
lead_paragraph: As New York State politics suffer yet another corruption scandal, the arrests have energized those calling for reform in Albany.

headline: Daniel Hoffman, Poet Laureate Versatile in Many Forms, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Hoffman was the nation’s poet laureate from 1973 to 1974, and his books include a collection of sonnets and an epic poem about the founding of Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Hoffman, a scholar and critic who was the nation’s poet laureate from 1973 to 1974 and whose books include a collection of sonnets, an epic poem about the founding of Pennsylvania and analytical works about Paul Bunyan and Edgar Allan Poe, died Saturday in Haverford, Pa. He was 89.

headline: Corrections: April 5, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 5, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Captive of Human Nature
abstract: Kathryn Hunter plays an ape who plays a man in “Kafka’s Monkey,” a solo show at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Movie stars like Meryl Streep and Robert De Niro are celebrated for their ability to transform into the characters they play on screen, so that their very voices seem to take on new sounds, and their bodies new shapes. But, to my knowledge, they have not ever attempted adding several inches to their arms to embody a character.

headline: High Spirits, Higher Heels
abstract: A factory owner and a drag performer combine efforts in “Kinky Boots,” the new Broadway musical from Harvey Fierstein and Cyndi Lauper.
lead_paragraph: Cyndi Lauper knows how to work a crowd. Making her Broadway debut as a composer with “Kinky Boots,” the new musical that opened on Thursday night at the Al Hirschfeld Theater, this storied singer has created a love- and heat-seeking score that performs like a pop star on Ecstasy. Try to resist if you must. But for at least the first act of this tale of lost souls in the shoe business, you might as well just give it up to the audience-hugging charisma of her songs.

headline: Jordanians and Turks Are Focus of Syria’s Ire
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad’s government accused Jordan and Turkey of “playing with fire” by aiding Syrian rebels.
lead_paragraph: Syria lashed out at Turkey and Jordan on Thursday for what it called their duplicitous work in fomenting the Syrian rebellion, accusing the Turkish prime minister of chronic lies and telling the Jordanians they were “playing with fire” in letting insurgents arm and train on their soil — a possible hint of retaliation.

headline: Last Song Heard
abstract: Peter Wentz ends this week’s weekday solve.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial “Win Valuable Prizes” Alert! The wonderful Marbles brain stores are having their fifth annual cross-country crossword tournament the weekend of April 20-21. If you live in or near any of the five cities in which the tournaments take place, I highly suggest them; they’re fun, and if you’ve never been inside a Marbles store, you’re in for a treat. Click here to register and for more information. Proceeds go to the Brain Research Foundation.

headline: U.S. Agrees to New Rules for Immigration Raids
abstract: The agreement was part of a settlement of a lawsuit accusing the authorities of unlawfully forcing their way into the homes of Latino families on Long Island and in Westchester County.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have agreed to establish new policies governing the conduct of immigration officers during raids, including restrictions on how and when agents can enter private homes, the source of widespread ire and anxiety among immigrants.

headline: Beware of the Man on the Couch
abstract: In “6 Souls,” a psychiatrist tries to figure out what’s going on with a patient who has an unusual contingent of multiple personalities.
lead_paragraph: Originally titled “Shelter,” this supernatural, multiple-personality thriller from Swedish directors Mans Marlind and Bjorn Stein has its own identity crisis. Beginning as a psychiatric freak show, “6 Souls” eventually trades serial-killer intimations for backwoods bad mojo before becoming just another dimly lighted pop-up-stalker flick.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
lead_paragraph: April 4, 2013

headline: 500 Days in a Cave, the Safest Refuge
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Movies']
abstract: “No Place on Earth,” a documentary by Janet Tobias, recounts the experiences of Ukrainian Jews who literally went underground to escape the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: For the Ukrainian Jews in Janet Tobias’s “No Place on Earth,” going underground was both a brute necessity and a literal reality. After the Nazi invasion their families sought improbable refuge in caves outside their village. There they stayed and lived — without sunlight — for more than 500 days. Some emerged at night to forage; at one point hostile villagers sealed an entrance with dirt.

headline: C.D.C. Begins Work on Vaccine for China Flu
abstract: As China announced a sixth death Friday from the mysterious new H7N9 flu, health officials said they were formulating a seed vaccine.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials have begun to make a seed vaccine against the mysterious new H7N9 flu circulating in China, they said Thursday.

headline: Michigan Coach’s Winding Path Leads to Final Four
abstract: After coaching for some 35 years at eight programs at all levels, Michigan Coach John Beilein has reached the college game’s showcase weekend.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The usual collection of college basketball coaches arrived this week for the Final Four. They came from the smallest universities and the major programs; they came to network, to trade inbounds plays and to debate the finer points of the 1-3-1 press.

headline: A Visitor Disrupts a Beach Town Full of Secrets
abstract: Harold Guskin’s “Down the Shore” centers on an amusement park worker, the woman he loves, and the man who married her.
lead_paragraph: “Down the Shore,” a delicate drama set on the New Jersey coast, would be rewarding just for the fine performances from a cast led by James Gandolfini and Famke Janssen. But recent history has given it an extra layer of poignancy that the filmmakers never intended.

headline: Mexico: Plot to Kill Lawmakers Is Halted, Officials Say
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The attorney general’s office said Thursday that the authorities had captured several people who were planning to kill two well-known Mexican legislators.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general’s office said Thursday that the authorities had captured several people who were planning to kill two well-known Mexican legislators. The lawmakers, Ricardo Monreal Ávila, a former Zacatecas State governor and a current member of the lower house of Congress, and his brother, David Monreal Ávila, a senator, are both affiliated with leftist political parties. The armed gang was captured in a Mexico City hotel after an investigation by an intelligence agency, the Center for Research and National Security. Officials also seized weapons and a van that they said the suspects planned to use to carry out the attack. The authorities are questioning the suspects in an effort to determine their motive for the attack.

headline: Destroying a City With Hate
abstract: Maria Iliou’s documentary “Smyrna: The Destruction of a Cosmopolitan City” recounts the burning of a religiously diverse Ottoman port by the Turks.
lead_paragraph: “Smyrna: The Destruction of a Cosmopolitan City (1900-1922)” might have been a stronger documentary had it been made a few decades ago, when more people were alive who had experienced the events of 1922 as adults. But it is still a sobering study in how individual human beings can become afterthoughts in the face of broad movements like nationalism, a phenomenon that is still much in evidence almost a century later.

headline: A Radical Beatified
abstract: “Free Angela and All Political Prisoners” is Shola Lynch’s documentary about the scholar and activist Angela Davis and her 1972 murder trial.
lead_paragraph: Shola Lynch’s documentary about Angela Davis, the activist and beacon of counterculture radicalism, is a snappily edited, archivally wallpapered recollection of fearless behavior in the face of an antsy establishment. But it’s equally significant as a pointed act of retelling.

headline: Look, a Hummingbird!
abstract: “Wings of Life,” narrated by Meryl Streep, has arresting images of flowers as well as birds, bees and bats.
lead_paragraph: “Wings of Life” slows down a brilliantly colored hummingbird so viewers can observe just what an athletic, agile creature it is.

headline: A Photographer Is Uneasy in Front of the Camera
abstract: “Bert Stern: Original Mad Man” is Shannah Laumeister’s profile of the photographer she met at 13 and whose muse she would eventually become.
lead_paragraph: “I used to have a secret relationship with you,” the photographer Bert Stern, 83, says to the filmmaker Shannah Laumeister, 40 years his junior. “Now it’s public.” That relationship is both a blessing and a curse for “Bert Stern: Original Mad Man,” Ms. Laumeister’s adoring profile of the man she met at 13 and whose muse she would eventually become.

headline: Just Like Old Times, It’s Pettitte, Rivera, Victory
abstract: The Yankees’ Andy Pettitte went eight strong innings, scattering eight hits while allowing one run, and Mariano Rivera, in his first appearance of the year, got the save.
lead_paragraph: Joe Girardi is not the type of manager who goes around giving fire-and-brimstone speeches to his players, or to members of the news media. The Girardi way is to be steady to the point of being dispassionate, never too high and never too low. In the Yankees’ black-and-white pinstripe world, Girardi is a muted shade of gray.

headline: Young Man’s Wobbly Steps to Independence
abstract: In “The Story of Luke” a high-functioning autistic man faces enormous changes to his sheltered life.
lead_paragraph: Movies about autism have come a long way since Dustin Hoffman created a sensation in “Rain Man,” playing a savant whose astounding mathematical skills made him a threat to Las Vegas casinos. Whatever its other merits, “The Story of Luke,” a slice-of-life tale of a high-functioning autistic man-child faced with enormous changes to his sheltered existence, explains early on that, no, Luke (Lou Taylor Pucci) does not have any special powers. He’s just like any 20-something trying to find his footing, only more so. (He can, however, make pancakes and 23 other meals he’s learned by watching his favorite cooking show.)

headline: Washed-Up Artist Meets His Dark Muse
abstract: “Eddie: The Sleepwalking Carnival,” a horror comedy from Boris Rodriguez, centers on a once-famous artist whose creative fires are stoked by his houseguest’s very strange habits.
lead_paragraph: The slaughter begins with a dead deer, but by the time “Eddie: The Sleepwalking Cannibal” skids to a close the body count will have crossed the species line several times over.

headline: Obama’s Remarks About California’s Attorney General Raise Eyebrows
abstract: President Obama, on a Democratic fund-raising trip to California, left behind a debate about whether he tripped over the line of political correctness by calling Kamala Harris “the best-looking attorney general in the country.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama headed out to California with a simple goal: to collect a few million dollars for Democrats. By the time Air Force One departed the state, however, he left behind a debate about whether he tripped over the line of political correctness.

headline: A Jilted Lover Unleashed in Paris
abstract: “Simon Killer” is Antonio Campos’s tale of a recently dumped American looking for distraction in Paris.
lead_paragraph: “Simon Killer,” like its sidling antihero, isn’t an easy film to like. Or sometimes to watch. Shot in a style that resembles a nostalgic Instagram filter labeled “seedy-noir,” the film’s darkly saturated images unsettle more than inform.

headline: Newcomers Offer Rangers Fresh Beginning
abstract: The addition of three players has added a spark at a critical time for the Rangers, who have a dozen games left and still sit precariously on the playoff line.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Hockey is supposed to be fun, but this season has not been too enjoyable for the Rangers.

headline: Be Careful What You Wish For
abstract: An ancient kettle with magical powers tests a broke couple’s bond in Ramaa Mosley’s modern fable about money.
lead_paragraph: A comic fable that squanders its twisted-fairy-tale concept, “The Brass Teapot” observes the insidious effects of greed on a young, broke couple. When Alice (Juno Temple) and John (Michael Angarano) acquire a teapot that spits out cash every time they hurt themselves, they leap into the good life through self-inflicted hard knocks but learn a valuable lesson when other people want their stuff.

headline: Inquiry Is Sought Into Death of Castro Critic
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The daughter of Oswaldo Payá, a critic of the Castro government, is calling for an independent investigation into the car wreck that killed him in July.

headline: Psychiatrist Reported Suspect in Theater Shooting as Threat
abstract: A month before a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater last summer, his psychiatrist reported that the man now charged had been having homicidal thoughts.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A month before James E. Holmes was accused of carrying out a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater, his university psychiatrist reported that Mr. Holmes had been having homicidal thoughts and was harassing her in e-mails and text messages, according to documents released Thursday.

headline: Back in Brooklyn, Nets Falter Again in Third Quarter
abstract: Carlos Boozer had 29 points and 18 rebounds to lead the Bulls to victory, spoiling big scoring efforts from Brook Lopez and Deron Williams, who combined for 58 points.
lead_paragraph: The lights went out. Players bounced together in unison on the herringbone floor for the first time in 18 days. Fireworks shot into the air. The Nets were back in Brooklyn, and a sellout crowd at Barclays Center was treated to a close game and a frenetic finish.

headline: Whom Do You Trust on Climate Change?
abstract: A British survey finds that scientists are most believable when it comes to climate change, followed by environmental groups, who come out ahead of the BBC.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — As the debate on global warming steadily drifts away from whether it is real toward how it will affect our future, a new British study looks at the sources people trust to stay informed on the issue.

headline: Obama Budget to Include Cuts to Programs in Hopes of Deal
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicare', 'Social Security (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama will take the political risk next week of presenting a budget plan that proposes cuts to Social Security and Medicare, in an effort to compromise with Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama next week will take the political risk of formally proposing cuts to Social Security and Medicare in his annual budget in an effort to demonstrate his willingness to compromise with Republicans and revive prospects for a long-term deficit-reduction deal, administration officials say.

headline: Skiing Gulmarg Means Thrills Beyond the Powder
keywords: ['ALPINE SKIING', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Skiing', 'Snowboarding', 'Terrorism', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Dodging soldiers on the mountain and ramming through road barricades part of the fun, foreign skiers say.
lead_paragraph: In early March, a white sport utility vehicle, crammed with a group of tourists from Germany, Austria, Switzerland and the United States, left the famous Kashmiri ski resort of Gulmarg well after dark. As the vehicle sped toward Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, the driver, Bashir, gripped the steering wheel and nervously scanned the road ahead.

headline: In Uncertain Season, Old Combination Works Fine
abstract: Mariano Rivera, 43, is the oldest player in baseball, and Andy Pettitte, who turns 41 in June, is close behind. Yet both still perform close to the way they did at their peak.
lead_paragraph: There were echoes Thursday of the greatest moment this young stadium has ever hosted, back in 2009, when the Yankees won the World Series. Andy Pettitte started that night and Mariano Rivera finished. The Yankees took their place on baseball’s mountaintop, where they believe they always belong. King of the hill, top of the heap.

headline: Boise for Davis Cup? The City Has Advantages
abstract: The United States will play its Davis Cup quarterfinal against Serbia this weekend in Boise, Idaho, a city with one of the highest participation rates per capita for U.S.T.A. leagues and tournaments.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — Novak Djokovic is the top-ranked men’s tennis player in the world. He is so intelligent, so engaging, so interested in current affairs that speculation about his post-playing days often touches on the possibility of a political career back home in Serbia.

headline: Brandon Cronenberg on ‘Antiviral’
abstract: The writer and director discusses his film about a clinic that sells the diseases of celebrities to its clients.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director discusses his film about a clinic that sells the diseases of celebrities to its clients.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 A.M. (13) SESAME STREET In three new “People in Your Neighborhood” segments Murray Monster visits Lincoln Center, where he interviews performers about their careers. In this first installment he and the Spanish-speaking lamb Ovejita join the New York City Ballet dancers Kristen Segin, Alina Dronova, Callie Bachman and Sara Adams (above, with Murray) in the studio, where the women illustrate terms like barre and plié and demonstrate how they use their bodies to tell stories. Then Murray and Ovejita put on tutus and join the ballerinas in an excerpt from Peter Martins’s staging of “Swan Lake.”

headline: Backing Into His Father’s Footsteps
abstract: Brandon Cronenberg, 33, son of David Cronenberg, explains how he never intended to make films like his father’s.
lead_paragraph: Body horror and biological obsessions have often been present in the gooey, sometimes shocking films of the Canadian director David Cronenberg. So it may not be surprising that the debut feature from Brandon Cronenberg, the son of the man once called the baron of blood, has similar themes. But what is surprising is how small a role his father’s films may have played in the making of his own.

headline: Buddhist-Muslim Tensions Spread as 8 Detainees Die in Indonesia
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A brawl broke out at an immigration center in Indonesia between Muslim and Buddhist detainees, leaving eight dead and 15 wounded, officials said.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Simmering religious and ethnic violence in Myanmar spread beyond its borders on Friday when a brawl broke out at an immigration center in Indonesia between Muslim and Buddhist detainees, leaving 8 dead and 15 wounded, officials said.

headline: Building Collapse Near Mumbai Kills at Least 72
abstract: The building collapse highlights the problem of unsafe and illegal constructions tacked onto structures in the Mumbai area, where demand for housing is intense and standards are lax or not enforced.
lead_paragraph: 1:47 a.m. | Updated NEW DELHI — The death toll from the collapse of a building near Mumbai rose to at least 72 people on Saturday, two days after the disaster that underscored the prevalence of illegal and shoddy construction ending in disaster.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 5
abstract: Ethnic strife in Myanmar; ice in the Peruvian Andes is melting fast; a controversial play in Hungary; and changes for the Tour of the Basque Country.
lead_paragraph: NEWS A visit to the Kachin region of Myanmar is a sobering reminder of how much hatred and mistrust exist between the majority Burman and the ethnic minorities who live in the country’s highlands. Thomas Fuller reports from Myitkyina, Myanmar.

headline: Schools Adopt Restorative Justice as Alternative to ‘Zero-Tolerance’ Policies
abstract: How would you feel about your school adopting a restorative justice program?
lead_paragraph: In “Opening Up, Students Transform a Vicious Circle,” Patricia Leigh Brown writes about a new approach to student discipline issues that is taking root in some schools.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, April 5, 2013
abstract: What piece of punctuation is missing from the two sentences from this story about the art of naming a dog?
lead_paragraph: This question was written by Katherine Schulten from a Style section article, “You Named Me Brutus? Really?”

headline: Norway’s New Photographic Landscape
abstract: The Norwegian Journal of Photography hopes to encourage new and established photographers as they pursue projects that cross the lines between documentary and art.
lead_paragraph: Helge Skodvin was not on a typical road trip — he was about halfway between mainland Norway and the North Pole. Mr. Skodvin, a photographer from the west coast of Norway, was driving around the Svalbard archipelago searching for cars.

headline: How Would You Feel About a Computer Grading Your Essays?
abstract: Do you think a computer would grade you fairly? Would you be more or less likely to trust a computer’s grade than one from a teacher?
lead_paragraph: Technology is becoming more and more important in schools and education, but is there a limit to what computers should do in the classroom?

headline: Are Ads Moving Past the ‘Standard Indian Housewife’?
abstract: A trickle of new ads feature working women spending their own money. One even shows a man washing his own shirt.
lead_paragraph: If I won a rupee every time an Indian commercial stereotyped women, I could have bought a Ford Figo to use as storage space.

headline: North Korea Events Complicate Nuclear Talks With Iran
abstract: Pyongyang’s nuclear-arms bombast and the cautious foreign response are hanging over resumed negotiations between Iran and the six big powers in unsettling ways.
lead_paragraph: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — North Korea is more than 2,500 miles from the resumed nuclear negotiations that got under way here Friday between Iran and the six big powers, but North Korea’s nuclear-arms bombast and the cautious foreign response are hanging over the negotiations in unsettling ways.

headline: Tensions With North Korea Unsettle South’s Economy
abstract: The Seoul stock market fell Friday, and General Motors said it was making contingency plans for its workers amid a torrent of threats from North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea’s torrent of threats — and the matching show of military power and political resolve from the United States and South Korea — began showing signs of unsettling foreign investors’ confidence Friday.

headline: Bangkok SkyTrain Fund Raises $2.1 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The offering, by an infrastructure fund controlled by the rail operator BTS Group, priced at the top of its marketed range, and ranks as the biggest ever new listing by a Thai company.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A fund controlled by the operator of Bangkok’s sprawling SkyTrain urban rail system raised a record 62.53 billion baht, or $2.13 billion, on Friday in the largest initial public offering anywhere by a Thai company.

headline: Big Detroit Iron Meets Cosmic-Themed Dinosaur Art
abstract: Known for his colorful disco-pop art, Kenny Scharf has also made a name for himself customizing cars.
lead_paragraph: Kenny Scharf sees a world colored by ravenous dinosaur toys, rocket ships and outrageous Cadillac fins. As an artist, Mr. Scharf is known for his Day-Glo disco installations and swirling candy-color cartoon murals, but he has also emerged as an avid car customizer over the last 30 years, transforming classic cars into moving, fantastical pop sculptures.

headline: South Koreans at North’s Edge Cope With Threat of War
abstract: Some residents of Munsan, South Korea, which sits on the edge of the tense border with the North, have learned to accept the dangers, and try to focus on enjoying their daily lives.
lead_paragraph: MUNSAN, South Korea — As Lee Jae-eun retrieved her squirming twins from day care and loaded them into a two-seat stroller, she barely glanced up at the olive green Blackhawk helicopter that swept overhead, just above the high-rise apartment buildings.

abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:

headline: Remembering Jack Pardee, One of the ‘Junction Boys’
abstract: After a 15-year playing career, Pardee was a head coach in college and in four pro leagues. He was one of the favorite sons of Texas football.
lead_paragraph: Jack Pardee had a 40-year football career, as a player and coach, including 15 seasons as one of the N.F.L.’s solid and steady outside linebackers of the 1960s and early ’70s. Pardee died on Monday of gallbladder cancer. He was 76. A few thoughts:

headline: Leaving South Africa for the Gothic Wonderland
abstract: Ms. Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy, in Johannesburg, is one of eight high school seniors who are blogging about their college searches for The Choice.
lead_paragraph: I know where I am going to university this fall! Here is a look at the diary I’ve kept:

headline: HMV Stores to Be Sold to Private Equity Firm
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The private equity firm Hilco Consumer Capital agreed on Friday to buy more than 140 stores of the British music retailer HMV as part of a rescue deal after the company went into bankruptcy earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The private equity firm Hilco Consumer Capital agreed on Friday to buy more than 140 stores of the British music retailer HMV as part of a rescue deal after the company went into bankruptcy earlier this year.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 2
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: Baseball trivia games are a dime a dozen, and the answers are usually just a Google search away. Baseball — from scouting to fantasy games to a catcher calling for a pitch — is all about what is going to happen next. So the Bats Blog team thought it would test our readers’ predictive skills throughout the season with three questions about each upcoming week. Feel free to lean on research, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: B&B Owner Responds to Web Site Review
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Bed-and-Breakfast Lodgings', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Small Business']
abstract: Should the Wedgwood Manor country inn include people in its promotional photographs or not?
lead_paragraph: Criticism can be hard to take, especially when your business is your home. Last week, however, Nancy Galloway and Andre Laporte welcomed our comments and suggestions as to how to improve their inn’s Web site. “It is like having a great editor,” Ms. Galloway said. “You need someone who is looking at your work with a fresh perspective. I am too close to our site and the comments were quite helpful and we are taking many to heart.”

headline: Daily Report: Breathing Room for Whitman at H.P.
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']

headline: Rat Chase Backfires at Reactor in Japan
keywords: ['Rodents', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: Workers at the power plant who were installing wire nets to keep rats away from a cooling system instead tripped that system, causing it to fail for the second time in weeks.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Workers at the stricken Fukushima nuclear power plant who were installing wire nets Friday to keep rats away from a vital cooling system instead tripped that system, causing it to fail for the second time in weeks.

headline: For Cyprus, Gaslight at the End of Tunnel?
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Energy and Power', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: A potentially lucrative deepwater natural gas field could turn the debt-strapped island country into an energy exporter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If there are any bright spots in the gloom surrounding the economy of Cyprus, one place to look would be about 170 kilometers south of the coastal city of Limassol. There, about 1,700 meters below the surface of the Mediterranean Sea, is a potentially lucrative natural gas field called Aphrodite.

headline: At H.P., Activist Steps Up
abstract: The board of Hewlett-Packard, under criticism for overseeing a disastrous acquisition, is being shaken up. | Jon S. Corzine is avoiding, for now, a lawsuit from an MF Global bankruptcy trustee. | Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief of Enron, may leave prison early under a possible agreement with the government. | British and American authorities don’t see eye to eye in the search for a replacement for Libor.
lead_paragraph: AT H.P., ACTIVIST STEPS UP  |  The board of Hewlett-Packard, under criticism for overseeing the disastrous acquisition of the British software maker Autonomy, is being shaken up. The chairman, Raymond J. Lane, gave up that post on Thursday and was succeeded on an interim basis by Ralph V. Whitworth, the activist hedge fund manager who joined the board in 2011. Two other directors left the board altogether.

headline: From the Negative 71st Parallel, (Near) End Transmission
abstract: “Antarctic time” can stretch out like taffy when you are stuck in a storm that hits right as you try to leave. But even when the hours pass their slowest, one can’t help but think how they will miss the place and its pace.
lead_paragraph: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee in Antarctica.

headline: Homegrown Efforts to Recruit Women in Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Venture Capital', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Andreessen Horowitz, the venture capital firm, is drawing on software and a diversity partner to help recruit women. It is one of many efforts among tech companies to make Silicon Valley more diverse.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is not exactly known for its diversity. So when Andreessen Horowitz, the venture capital firm, wanted to make sure its job postings were reaching the most diverse audience possible, its partners did what most people in Silicon Valley do when they spot a problem. They turned to software.

abstract: Will they ever learn?
lead_paragraph: Sigh. So Obama is going with the “chained CPI” thing in his latest proposal — changing the price index used for Social Security cost adjustments. This is, purely and simply, a benefit cut.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Age Limits on Morning-After Pill
abstract: An acidly worded decision raised a broader question about whether a cabinet secretary can decide on a drug’s availability for reasons other than its safety and effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ordered that the most common morning-after pill be made available over the counter for all ages, instead of requiring a prescription for girls 16 and younger. But his acidly worded decision raises a broader question about whether a cabinet secretary can decide on a drug’s availability for reasons other than its safety and effectiveness.

abstract: Employers added only 88,000 jobs in March, a pace of growth too sluggish to make a big dent in the backlog of idle workers. The jobless rate dipped to 7.6 percent from 7.7 percent.
lead_paragraph: It looks as if the spring swoon is back.

headline: Cover Story? FX Apologizes for Error That Cut Off ‘The Americans’
abstract: When the latest episode of your beloved Cold War-era spy drama is cut off before its conclusion by your overeager DVR, who do you blame? The C.I.A.? The K.G.B.? Interpol?
lead_paragraph: In this brave new world of serialized television dramas every minute counts. Miss the closing moments of your favorite show and you could lose out on crucial plot details that send its story spinning off in new and unexpected directions. But when your beloved FX cold war-era spy drama is cut off before its conclusion by your overeager DVR, whom do you blame? The C.I.A.? The K.G.B.? HBO?

headline: Knowosphere at Work: Farmer-to-Farmer Video Advice Boosting Yields
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Earthquakes', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'INDIA', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: In India, Digital Green extends the impact of agricultural extension services using YouTube.
lead_paragraph: David Bornstein, the author of “How to Change the World” and contributor to the Fixes blog here at The Times, has written a spectacular post — “Where YouTube Meets the Farm” — describing Digital Green, a successful effort to extend the reach of social workers and agricultural extension services in India through community-shot videos that explain innovative steps taken by farmers to boost yields or income.

headline: Common Core Practice | Narrative, Argumentative and Informative Writing About Baseball
abstract: The baseball season has begun, and our New Jersey classroom collaborators — many of them passionate Yankees or Mets fans — explored America’s pastime for this week’s writing prompts.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 major league baseball season began this week, and Sarah Gross, Jonathan Olsen and their New Jersey students— many among them passionate Yankees or Mets fans — couldn’t pass up the opportunity to explore America’s pastime for this week’s writing prompts.

abstract: If Gmail keeps suggesting outdated addresses when you address a new message, it may be time to clean up your Gmail contacts list.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: U.N. Agency Suspends Food Aid in Gaza After Protesters Break Into Its Compound
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Food', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency in the Gaza Strip stopped food distribution and other services for refugees indefinitely, an official said Friday.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The United Nations Relief and Works Agency has indefinitely suspended food distribution in the Gaza Strip after protesters angry over the cancellation of a cash assistance program for the poor stormed the agency’s main compound in Gaza City on Thursday, an official said Friday.

headline: UBS Aided Purchase of Stake in Chinese Insurer
abstract: A Swiss banking company’s $5.5 billion loan resolves a mystery over how the Charoen Pokphand Group bought the stake without financing from the state-run China Development Bank.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The Swiss banking giant UBS made a $5.5 billion loan early this year to help a Thai company acquire a 15.6 percent stake in China’s Ping An Insurance Group, according to people briefed on the deal.

headline: When in Rome, Eat Like an Expat
abstract: A new web site aims to demystify the decisions around eating and drinking in the city.
lead_paragraph: Rome is one of the world’s best food cities, but it can be pretty darn hard to find a good meal in this town, and pretty easy to find a bad one, too. That’s where The Rome Digest comes in. A joint venture by five of the city’s leading Anglophone food-and-wine experts, this new site aims to demystify and declutter the decisions around eating and drinking in the city, distilling its offerings down to 100 carefully curated, vigorously vetted need-to-know locations.

headline: Reclaiming a Knicks Title
abstract: MSG Network had two videotapes that contain Game 5 of the 1973 N.B.A. finals restored and will televise the game as part of its commemoration of the Knicks’ last title.
lead_paragraph: The two videotapes that contain Game 5 of the 1973 N.B.A. finals had broken down chemically, turning them soft and sticky. They would not budge in a tape deck.

abstract: More on the term “illegal immigrant,” and a preview of the public editor’s column in Sunday’s newspaper.
lead_paragraph: I’ll be out of the office and off the grid for a few days, but before I go, a couple of thoughts:

headline: Gang Rape Defendant Hopes to Join Indian Air Force
abstract: Air force rules disqualify anyone with criminal records from taking their selection test, but Vinay Sharma had applied before he was charged with participating in the gang rape of a 23-year-old woman.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI —Vinay Sharma, one of the six defendants in the Delhi gang rape case, has asked the court to let him take a written selection exam for the Indian Air Force on Sunday, as he still hopes to join the military branch’s clerical department.

headline: Beneath the Kilt, a Modern Scotland
abstract: Ken Loach’s new film, “The Angels’ Share,” is about four unemployed Scottish scofflaws who cook up a scheme to steal a valuable cask of whisky.
lead_paragraph: In the new comedy “The Angels’ Share” four young unemployed Glaswegians dressed in kilts set out on a journey into the Scottish Highlands. The soundtrack even features the infectious anthem “I’m Gonna Be (500 Miles)” by their countrymen the Proclaimers. But these miscreants could not belong less to the mountains and glens north of the Highland line.

headline: Depression, Not Ended
abstract: Austerity USA.
lead_paragraph: Lousy jobs report. OK, you don’t want to put too much stress on one month’s numbers, yada yada, but it doesn’t look at all good.

headline: Sequestration and the Jobs Report
abstract: The mandatory federal budget cuts don’t seem to account for sluggishness in the labor market — at least, not yet.
lead_paragraph: The March jobs report came in much weaker than expected, with employers adding just 88,000 workers over the course of the month. Did sequestration – the $85 billion in mandatory budget cuts that Congress never managed to unwind, despite promises to the contrary – take a bite?

headline: The Superhero Who Leapt Color Lines
abstract: The new Jackie Robinson biopic, “42,” emphasizes the legendary side of a complicated man.
lead_paragraph: Watching the movie “42” brings to mind the ending to John Ford’s fine 1962 western, “The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance.” A newspaperman (and the viewer) has learned from James Stewart the truth about who really gunned down the evil Valance years before. But rather than run with the story, the newsman rips it up and flings it into the stove. His reason? “When the legend becomes fact,” he says, “print the legend.”

headline: The Curse of Ataturk
abstract: It’s a major problem for Turkey’s Kurds that the notion of “Turkishness” is both ill-defined and staunchly defended.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — “How happy is the one who says ‘I am a Turk,’” said Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, speaking in an emotional finale of a speech in 1933 — a time when Turkey was still trying to forge a national identity out of the ruins of the Ottoman Empire. The notion seemed simple enough: If you think you’re Turkish, then you are.

headline: Louis C. K. and the Ballad of Jack Dall
abstract: Louis C. K. explains, in enthusiastic detail, how he recruited David Lynch to play a memorable character on his FX series, “Louie.”
lead_paragraph: When Louis C. K. gets excited about something, he really gets excited. Case in point: in a recent interview with the Arts & Leisure section of The Times, he expounded on many subjects, including his coming HBO special, “Oh My God,” his work with Woody Allen on “Blue Jasmine” and the number of years he believes he has left in his career. But when the topic of conversation turned to David Lynch, the “Blue Velvet” and “Mulholland Dr.” filmmaker, a certain gleam appeared in his eye. Over the next several minutes, Louis C. K. enthusiastically recounted the story of how he cast Mr. Lynch on “Louie” in the role of Jack Dall, an inscrutable entertainment-industry veteran who trains the Louie character for a fateful audition to replace David Letterman on “Late Show.”

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Sun-Times: Roger Ebert on not being able to eat: “From that time I began to replace what I had lost with what I remembered.” — Melissa Clark

headline: Parsing Racial Politics in the ’50s
abstract: Samuel Fuller’s “China Gate” depicts French incursions in Indochina; “The Sun Shines Bright,” from John Ford, examines racism.
lead_paragraph: China Gate

headline: Punk’d
abstract: “The Best of Punk Magazine” is the missing link in the flurry of books published over the past few years chronicling punk music and art.
lead_paragraph: In 1972 I designed Hilly’s Gazette for Hilly Kristal’s eponymous bar before he opened the famed CBGB. I missed the punk scene by about two years because I was a hippie. Punks hated hippies. At least that’s what John Holmstrom told me years after hippiedom and punkdom had run their respective courses. Holmstrom was a co-founder — along with Ged Dunn Jr. and Eddie “Legs” McNeil — as well as an editor, designer, illustrator and letterer of Punk, the magazine that helped put the music on the map. When I was art director of The New York Times Op-Ed page, he showed me his illustration portfolio. The stiff linear crosshatch style was not the right tone for The Times, and I was not impressed by his comics-style hand-lettered magazine. I now realize what a cultural and historical bellwether it was.

headline: Prize-Writing
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The money is nice, but literary awards often come with ideological baggage and emotional strings attached.
lead_paragraph: In January, the 133-year-old Library Journal announced the creation of a new annual prize: the Amanda Foreman Award for best acknowledgments. Laugh all you like; it was one of the proudest moments of my life. I knew how much effort had been expended in making those acknowledgments as comprehensive and accurate as possible; but I never thought anyone else would notice.

headline: La Famiglia
abstract: In this novel, Italian-Americans balance their aspirations for the future and their nostalgia for Italy.
lead_paragraph: Early in Christopher Castellani’s new novel, “All This Talk of Love,” Frankie Grasso wonders whether he and his family are “at the end of something.” Frankie is a 30-ish graduate student in English literature, still a long way from the end of (for one thing) his dissertation. An answer begins to take shape when his sister, an affluent stay-at-home mom who has never strayed far from their childhood home in Delaware, organizes a family trip to Santa Cecilia, the village in Italy where their parents grew up. For all of the Grassos, the very idea of the trip stirs up thoughts of old losses, ghosts that shadow the present, prompted by the dissonant fact that like many if not most Italian-Americans, Antonio and Mad­dalena Grasso enshrined in their children a glowing image of things Italian yet never took them to Italy or even taught them the language. Feeling oneself “at the end of something,” this slyly ambitious novel suggests, may well be the existential condition of being Italian-American.

headline: The President Proposes . . .
keywords: ['Books and Literature', "New Deal (1930's)", 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ira Katznelson examines how Franklin D. Roosevelt won approval for the New Deal, and at what cost.
lead_paragraph: Ira Katznelson heard his first political argument around the family table a few weeks before the presidential election of 1952. His grandmother started it, as only a grandmother can, by announcing that she wasn’t going to vote. Katz­nelson’s parents, who adored Adlai Stevenson, were suitably shocked. But Bubbeh Frima held her ground. “Since Roosevelt,” she insisted, “they are all pygmies.”

headline: Life Stages
abstract: Owen King’s hero grapples with his first film and his complicated relationship with his father, a B-movie Lothario.
lead_paragraph: “Double Feature” is a lame title for a novel that is epic, ambitious and dedicated to the uncontainable. Nor is the jacket of service; it shows a couple of old movie tickets when it needs a scrum of characters, not getting anywhere but being their talkative and irrepressible selves. I’d guess that this novel — Owen King’s first, after an esteemed story collection — was compiled over a period of years, possibly as a series of short stories about a group of characters. The novel is maybe a third too long, chiefly because as he wanders around King can hardly see a place, a face or a chair without embarking on a wordy, if not literary, description of it. This might have been cut by someone (why not King?) who can see that brevity is his best quality. But he may be a tricky man to edit or organize. He should persevere, for when he is good — and that is often enough to make a page turner of this book — he has a captivating energy, a precision and a fondness for people that are rare and that make the reader doubly impatient for him to do what he does best.

headline: Book of Ruth
abstract: An abandoned daughter searches for her mother in Nancy Richler’s novel set in postwar Montreal.
lead_paragraph: A family story: My mother’s friend Frika, a Viennese Jew, managed to leave Austria for America after the Anschluss. She knew if she were caught smuggling out the means of subsistence, she would be arrested. So she wore her money on her hat, in the form of a diamond brooch, which — thus flaunted — passed for fake. When the Nazis at the border asked what she was taking with her, she replied, “Only what you see!” And they let her through.

headline: Leading Off: College Sports’ Really Bad Day
abstract: A crisis at Rutgers, trouble at Auburn, problems with the Pac-12 —and then there was N.C.A.A. President Mark Emmert’s news conference.
lead_paragraph: If you are among those who love college sports in all their flawed glory, don’t want the system changed no matter how rotten it has become, Thursday was not a good day for you. In fact, one spin through the news cycle might have sent you crawling under the couch cushions. Of course, you probably found some college sports administrators hiding there, so it could get crowded pretty quickly.

headline: . . . Congress Disposes
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: To fight World War II, Roosevelt needed support from legislators who wanted to keep out Europe’s Jews.
lead_paragraph: Franklin Roosevelt enjoyed the overwhelming support of American Jews during his presidency, and the reasons are clear. In his three-plus terms from 1933 to 1945, he led the war against Hitler, supported a Jewish homeland in Palestine, appointed a Jew to the Supreme Court, chose another to be his secretary of the Treasury and surrounded himself with Jewish advisers who helped shape the laws that revolutionized the role of government in American life — what some critics sneeringly called the “Jew Deal.” Then, of course, there was Eleanor Roosevelt, whose concern for minorities fused the bond even tighter. When Roose­velt died in 1945, the Rabbinical Assembly of America described him, almost supernaturally, as an “immortal leader of humanity and a peerless servant of God.”

headline: Up Front
abstract: Part of what made the discovery of gorillas so sensational in the Victorian era was that they were “too similar to humans for comfort.”
lead_paragraph: In his review of Monte Reel’s “Between Man and Beast” this week, David Quammen notes that part of what made the discovery of gorillas so sensational in the Victorian era was that they were “too similar to humans for comfort.” As for whether attitudes have changed much, Quammen — the author of a biography of Charles Darwin, among other books — isn’t so sure; in an e-mail, he cited a recent Gallup poll that found 46 percent of Americans “decline to accept the reality that humans have evolved from ancestral primates.” His most recent book, “Spillover,” is about human diseases that come to us from animals, and he arrives at the terrifying conclusion that such outbreaks are likely to become more frequent and more worrisome. “The next big one might well prove devastating,” he said. Still, if there is one salubrious thing “about these insalubrious afflictions, such as Ebola and West Nile and AIDS and the influenzas,” it’s that “they remind us, by spilling over from nonhuman animals to humans, that we humans are just another animal.”

headline: Death of a Strongman
abstract: A new biography of Hugo Chávez can serve as a political obituary.
lead_paragraph: On March 5, Hugo Chávez’s extraordinary good luck ran out at last. After decades of evading an endless string of opponents — from personal poverty to the United States government — Venezuela’s democratically elected strongman finally succumbed to the one enemy he couldn’t defeat. Even his ending was vintage Chávez. The perpetual showman spent the last months of his life ruling Venezuela Oz-like, by remote control from his sickbed (he even missed his own inauguration on Jan. 10). All of which makes this the perfect time for the release of Rory Carroll’s “Comandante: Hugo Chávez’s Venezuela,” a sort of political obituary for the self-declared savior of Venezuela — a charismatic champion of the poor who, during his 14 years in office, ground one of Latin America’s richest states into the dust.

headline: Founding Father
abstract: Marie Arana’s biography assesses the man who led Latin America’s independence movement against Spanish rule.
lead_paragraph: Simón Bolívar, the Liberator, was the George Washington of South America, or so he was regarded by sundry eminences in the United States during a large part of his extraordinary career. Grandeur was his nature. He aroused adulation. He dealt a few preliminary military defeats to the Spanish imperial army, and in 1813, he entered victoriously, for the moment, into Caracas on a chariot drawn by white-gowned daughters of the leading families, as if he were a god or a Caesar. And he assumed the magnificent title of “Liberator and Dictator.” The chariot and the daughters deviated, it is true, from the austere Washington style, and the dictatorial honorific has hovered a little ominously over his reputation ever since, as you can see by reading Marie Arana’s admiring and rueful biography, “Bolívar.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLE C,  by William H. Gass. (Knopf, $28.95.) From its opening notes, this unquiet bildungsroman about a family of Austrian emigrants — fakes and fraudsters who have cast themselves as Jews — is designed to detonate its middling title.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE IDEA FACTORY: Bell Labs and the Great Age of American Innovation,  by Jon Gertner. (Penguin, $17.) Bell Labs, the onetime research and development wing of AT&T, was behind many of the technological transformations that define modern life, including the transistor, lasers and cellular telephony. Gertner’s incisive history is filled with inspiring lessons and asks a critical question: What causes innovation?

headline: App Smart Extra: More Point-and-Click Adventure Games to Try
abstract: Point-and-click adventure games for mobile devices range from the simple and light-hearted to surreal and complex.
lead_paragraph: My App Smart column this week was about point-and-click adventure games. These apps build on a long tradition of computer-based adventures. Great graphics and touch screens on today’s tablets and smartphones make these games much more fun to play than before. The idea is that you interact with items in the game’s various scenes by tapping on the graphics, solving puzzles as the game’s story progresses.

headline: The Shrinking Ranks of the Working
abstract: The March numbers fuel the narrative that the unemployment rate is coming down not because the economy is getting better, but because people are giving up looking for jobs.
lead_paragraph: Just when you thought it might be safe for the Fed to begin to think about taking its foot off the accelerator, along comes a jobs report that makes the employment picture look much less rosy than we had thought.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: In “The Girls of Atomic City” — at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list — Denise Kiernan explains the prominent role young women played in the Manhattan Project.
lead_paragraph: NUCLEAR FAMILY: The town of Oak Ridge, Tenn., didn’t exist before World War II, but by mid-1945 it had 75,000 residents and used more electricity than New York City. Why? Because, as Denise Kiernan explains in “The Girls of Atomic City” — new at No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list — that’s where the government set up the Manhattan Project’s top secret uranium enriching facilities, staffed almost entirely by young women who didn’t learn what they were working on until the first bomb fell on Hiroshima.

headline: Ghosts of Budapest
abstract: Tamas Dobozy’s stories unfold between war-torn Hungary and the émigré circles of present-day North America.
lead_paragraph: Are you experiencing any of the following: (1) A thirst for ­palinka? (2) A yearning for Budapest, though the closest you’ve ever come is the Hungarian Pastry Shop in Manhattan? (3) An urge to deploy diacritical marks over every other vowel? If so, you may be suffering from Hungarophilia. My own case dates to my mid-20s, when I discovered Peter Nadas’s novel “A Book of Memories.” Its high-Modernist aspirations were just one of the ways this contemporary masterpiece seemed to issue from a more distinguished past. Fascinated, I began reading every living Hungarian novelist I could find in English: Imre Kertesz, Laszlo Krasznahorkai. . . . By the time I got to Peter Esterhazy’s “Celestial Harmonies,” I, too, was dreaming of “palaces with swirling towers and flapping banners gazing at their reflections in the mirror of the lake.”

headline: The Messenger and the Message
abstract: This book presents the life of Muhammad for Western readers.
lead_paragraph: In today’s febrile cultural and religious climate, what project could be more fraught than writing a biography of Muhammad? The worldwide protests at “The Innocence of Muslims,” 14 minutes of trashy provocation posted on YouTube, are a terrible reminder to the would-be biographer that the life story of the prophet of Islam is not material about which one is free to have a “take.” Lesley Hazleton’s “First Muslim” is a book written by a white woman of dual American and British citizenship, published in America more than a decade after the 9/11 attacks. For many believers it is already — even before it is read, if it is read at all — an object of suspicion, something to be defended against, in case it should turn out to be yet another insult, another cruel parody of a story such an author has no business telling.

headline: Roger and Me
abstract: Mike Piazza recalls his career: his achievements, his feuds.
lead_paragraph: As a lifelong Mets fan (you can tell by a photo of me at age 10 dressed as Keith Hernandez for Halloween, and my current aura of despair), I’d hoped Mike Piazza — one of few genuine heroes on the team post-’80s — would be voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame earlier this year, his first time on the ballot. Alas, he fell 98 votes short of the 75 percent required for induction, most likely passed over because of a suspicion that he, like some other power hitters of his generation, took steroids — a rumor addressed at length in his strategically timed memoir, “Long Shot.”

headline: A Death in Venice
abstract: In “The Golden Egg,” Donna Leon’s latest Venetian mystery, Commissario Guido Brunetti looks into the suspicious death of the deaf and mentally disabled man who worked for his neighborhood dry cleaner.
lead_paragraph: There’s an autumnal tone to Donna Leon’s latest Venetian mystery, THE GOLDEN EGG (Atlantic Monthly, $26), that suits the melancholy mood of Commissario Guido Brunetti when he looks into the suspicious death of Davide Cavanella, the deaf and mentally disabled man who worked for his neighborhood dry cleaner. It strikes Brunetti as sad, as well as sinister, that he’s unable to find any public record of Davide, that his mother can’t produce her son’s birth or baptismal certificates, school documents or any other verification of his life. In the eyes of the state, Davide never existed. “It daunted Brunetti, the pathos of it.”

headline: Movies That Spill Beyond the Screen
abstract: Cinema, constantly lamented as a dying art, is going live.
lead_paragraph: For almost its entire life, cinema has been proclaimed a dying medium, under threat from talkies, television, home video and now digital technology. One increasingly popular response to this eternal lament is to think of cinema as a live art.

headline: Mark Knopfler Cancels Shows in Russia
abstract: The former Dire Straits frontman canceled two performances scheduled for June because of what he sees as the government’s harassment of human rights groups.
lead_paragraph: Mark Knopfler canceled two concerts in Russia on Thursday to protest what he sees as the government’s harassment of human rights groups there, the BBC reported.

headline: Gang Rape Defendants at Risk in Tihar Jail, Lawyers and Family Say
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sex Crimes', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: The family of Ram and Mukesh Singh and lawyers for the accused push to get case moved from Delhi.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Ram Singh, one of the men accused in the Delhi gang rape, was cremated in his family village in Rajasthan two days after he was found hanging in his jail cell on March 11. The body his family received was in horrific condition, family members said in interviews last weekend, making them believe more strongly than ever that he did not commit suicide.

headline: Kim Jong-un’s Spanish Mouthpiece
abstract: North Korea’s leader looks increasingly isolated in his war of words with the outside world. But Pyongyang’s European spokesman says Kim Jong-un can still rely on a dedicated band of devotees abroad.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kim Jong-un may lead the world’s most isolated state, but the North Korean leader is not entirely without foreign allies as tensions rise on the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Rutgers Tries to Calm Furor as More Officials Quit
abstract: The circle of those who saw video of a coach’s abusive acts as soon as December was wider than had been understood.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — As Rutgers officials tried Friday to calm the public furor over their handling of abusive behavior by the Scarlet Knights’ men’s basketball coach, the university president and athletic director presented conflicting depictions of who was responsible for the decision to keep the coach on staff after administrators first learned of his behavior.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | March 2013
abstract: Thirty-two pieces about young people published in the last month in the Sports, Arts, World, U.S., Health, Education, Technology and Style sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Each month we round up all the latest articles and multimedia published on NYTimes.com about young people, so that teachers and students can find this rich collection of nonfiction writing all in one place.

headline: Talking Things Out Until the Duck Quacks
abstract: For JoAnneh and Michael Nagler, who have been married since 2009, the second time  to each other, Friday evenings  are special.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: You’ve Been Doing a Fantastic Job. Just One Thing ...
abstract: People often hide constructive criticism inside a compliment, and those on the receiving end never hear it. Is there a better way to provide feedback?
lead_paragraph: MOST of us think we know how to give feedback. Positive comments are better — and more useful — than negative ones. And if you do have to point out something wrong, start with a compliment, move on to the problem, then end on a high note.

headline: Baldness as a Signal of Heart Disease Risk
abstract: Male pattern baldness, the kind that starts at the top or back of the head, may indicate an increased risk for coronary heart disease, according to a new analysis.
lead_paragraph: Baldness may indicate an increased risk for coronary heart disease.

headline: Overseas Finances Can Trip Up Americans Abroad
abstract: Average Americans who live and work in another country can run afoul of tax rules intended for the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: LIVING and working abroad may sound romantic. But having a financial life in more than one country — if one of those countries is the United States — is becoming increasingly complicated.

headline: China Escalates Its Response to Outbreak of Avian Flu
abstract: The government warned people to avoid live poultry and slaughtered more than 20,000 birds at a wholesale market in Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With confirmation that a sixth person has died from a mysterious avian-borne virus, Chinese officials escalated their response on Friday, advising people to avoid live poultry, sending virologists to chicken farms across the country and slaughtering more than 20,000 birds at a wholesale market in Shanghai where the virus, known as H7N9, was detected in a pigeon.

headline: Clinton Continues Her Advocacy for Women’s Rights as Private Citizen
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a glimpse on Friday of how she will fill her at least temporary role as a private advocate for women and girls in a speech at the Women in the World Conference.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a glimpse on Friday of how she will fill her at least temporary role as a private advocate for women and girls, walking arm in arm with Tina Brown at the Women in the World Conference, an annual women’s rights event sponsored by Newsweek and The Daily Beast, which Ms. Brown oversees.

headline: Renovations and Hope on a Block Once Marked by Blight
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Landlords', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Side Street: The transformation of five buildings on Kelly Street in the South Bronx is almost impossible to believe.
lead_paragraph: You do not want to mess with Arnaldo Rivera on Kelly Street. He had heard plenty about this crescent-shaped block off Intervale Avenue in the South Bronx. Drug dealers and addicts had holed up in filthy, crumbling apartments scattered among five buildings that were among the city’s worst.  He was ready.  He had a gun.

headline: Little Accountability for Directors, Despite Poor Performance
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Boards of Directors', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Aficionados of good corporate governance shouldn’t get too excited about the fact that two Hewlett-Packard directors are leaving the board and a third, Raymond J. Lane, is stepping down as chairman.

headline: Marriage Equality Tipping Point
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Bill Nelson of Florida is the 51st senator to come out in support of same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Florida Senator Bill Nelson, who said last week that “marriage is between a man and a woman,” said yesterday that he supports marriage equality. “If we are endowed by our creator with rights, then why shouldn’t those be attainable by gays and lesbians?” he wrote in a statement to The Tampa Bay Times. “Simply put, if the Lord made homosexuals as well as heterosexuals, why should I discriminate against their civil marriage? I shouldn’t, and I won’t. So I will add my name to the petition of senators asking the Supreme Court to declare the law that prohibits gay marriage unconstitutional.”

headline: A Bankruptcy, and Now a Pension Test
abstract: The question is whether the bondholders can get the bankruptcy court to force Stockton out of Calpers, perhaps as the price for continuing its Chapter 9 case.
lead_paragraph: Stockton, Calif.,  has been allowed into Chapter 9 bankruptcy.

headline: Closets, Please, and the Bigger the Better
abstract: Closets are increasingly being recognized as a factor in the sale — or lack thereof — of a New York City apartment.
lead_paragraph: When Apartment J in a Prospect Heights co-op went on the market last summer, 120 people streamed through to see it. At packed open houses, potential buyers marveled at the beautifully renovated kitchen, the privacy-friendly split bedroom layout, and the proximity to Prospect Park.

headline: Salazar Looks Back on a ‘Joyful Run’ as Interior Secretary
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Ken Salazar took over an agency that had been the scene of financial scandal and political malpractice in the Bush administration and succeeded in restoring a measure of ethics and morale.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ken Salazar, a man of unnaturally sunny disposition in an often gloomy town, may be the happiest person in the Obama administration these days. He is going home to Colorado next week, provided his successor as interior secretary is confirmed as expected.

headline: The Gun Report: April 5, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: As regular readers know, the Gun Report has become somewhat obsessed with the many cases of — let’s not mince words here — reckless endangerment, where a parent or guardian leaves a loaded gun around the house, which is found by a small child, who then accidentally discharges it, killing or maiming either herself or someone else. We understand how heart-wrenching this must be for the parents, who will have to face their grief and guilt for the rest of their lives. Having said that, however, we also think that if prosecutors took these parents to court on a consistent basis, these incidents would dramatically decrease. The prospect of going to jail would convince people to lock up their guns.

headline: Why Did Franny’s Cross the Road? To Grow
abstract: The Brooklyn pizza restaurant opens Monday in a new, bigger place with a bigger menu.
lead_paragraph: Imagine moving from a studio apartment to a classic six. That seemed to be the theme as Francine Stephens showed off the new Franny’s, opening Monday in Park Slope, Brooklyn, across Flatbush Avenue from the original. “We’re kind of growing in every way: the space, the kitchen, the menu,” she said.

headline: A Basketball Blowout and Its Celebration Raise Theological Questions
abstract: A Grinnell College player scored a record 138 points in a rout over Faith Baptist Bible, and with his accomplishment came thoughts on ethical behavior in such games.
lead_paragraph: During the next several days, the men’s college basketball season will culminate with the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Something like 15 million viewers will take in the telecasts, and they will reasonably assume they are watching the most important games of the year.

headline: Over the Rainbow
abstract: The former director of Design Miami has created a web site devoted to the work of artisans around the world.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years ago, Ambra Medda, the wunderkind co-founder and director of Design Miami (and Design Miami/Basel), announced that she was resigning from the high-profile fairs that she helped start in 2005, leaving the design world to wonder what her next move would be. Well, she’s made it, and, perhaps not surprisingly, it’s a Web site. L’ArcoBaleno (Italian for “The Rainbow”), which will go live in late May, bills itself as “a content and marketplace site devoted to collectible design.”

headline: Crops and Music, Each in Its Season
abstract: John Eliot Gardiner, a founder of the period-instrument movement who turns 70 this month, has a soft spot for Bach — as evidenced by his nine-hour marathon last week.
lead_paragraph: As a child John Eliot Gardiner saw Johann Sebastian Bach every day. He would pass him on his way to the dining room, where he sang Bach motets with his parents and siblings after meals. He would glance up at Bach, returning from accompanying his mother in an aria from a cantata, in which he played the obbligato violin part. The portrait of the ruddy-faced and bewigged Bach painted in 1748 by Elias Gottlob Haussmann hung above the staircase of the family home in Dorset, England, on loan from its owner, a German musician who had befriended Mr. Gardiner’s father in the interwar years then settled in a nearby village.

headline: The She and He Who Create as We
abstract: Sol León and Paul Lightfoot are the Lennon-McCartney of Nederlands Dans Theater choreographers: two company members who create as a duo. Their troupe performs in New York this week.
lead_paragraph: Tights and point shoes, bunions and tape, a prince and his princess: in dance, certain things always go together. But another kind of pairing, the choreographic duo, hasn’t always been so successful. Sol León and Paul Lightfoot of Nederlands Dans Theater are an exception.

headline: Two More Democrats Switch on Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: Senators Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota and Joe Donnelly of Indiana announced their support Friday.
lead_paragraph: Two more senators announced their support for same-sex marriage Friday, becoming the latest in a flood of lawmakers switching their positions on the issue.

headline: Who Made That Ferris Wheel?
abstract: The vertical merry-go-round that baffled engineers.
lead_paragraph: “I leave it to you, ladies and gentlemen, to say if the wheel is still in my head,” George Ferris called out to a crowd at the Chicago World’s Fair in 1893. Skeptics had joked that the young engineer would never build the giant whirligig that spun in his imagination. That day, his steel behemoth towered over the fairgrounds, its spokes gleaming in the sunlight; it could accommodate more than 2,000 riders at once.

headline: Raiders of the Lost Privy
abstract: If your boyfriend’s mom wants to do an archaeological dig in your backyard, consider saying no.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny afternoon in March 2005, Diana diZerega Wall, a professor of anthropology at City College, stood in my West Village garden, pointing to a low wall that ran along the back perimeter. Part of it would need to be removed, she said. “You understand,” she added, “that we are not bricklayers. We cannot put the wall back.” I smiled, appreciatively. No one was confusing her with a bricklayer, I assured her.

headline: Making the Impossible Veggie Burger
abstract: The process behind our cover for the Food & Drink issue.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover article by Mark Bittman is about a new crop of restaurant chains selling healthful, vegan or vegetarian versions of traditional fast-food items like burgers and buffalo wings. To convey the idea that these vegetable-based products may be the future of fast food, we decided to make an over-the-top vegan “burger” by squeezing different vegetables inside a multigrain bun.
