headline: Court Rules for Women in Western Wall Dispute
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A magistrates’ court in Jerusalem ruled that five women who had been detained for wearing prayer shawls and singing aloud were not disturbing public order.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the latest twist in the struggle for the character of the Western Wall, a magistrates’ court here ruled on Thursday that five women who had been detained at the Jewish holy site that morning for wearing prayer shawls and singing aloud were not disturbing public order, as the police had asserted.

headline: Celebrating for Longer Than 15 Minutes
abstract: About 800 guests stormed the New York Academy of Art’s five floors for its annual Tribeca Ball.
lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol said that an artist is somebody who produces things that people don’t need to have. He also said that good business is the best art. Both ideas were in play Monday night at the New York Academy of Art, the graduate school he helped found in 1982. For its annual Tribeca Ball, about 800 guests stormed the school’s five floors, throwing down Champagne and opinions about the work of 110 students on display.

headline: Labor Board Complaining Over Cablevision’s Tactics
abstract: Cablevision and its Brooklyn cable installers have not settled on a contract since the workers voted 15 months ago to unionize.
lead_paragraph: The battle between Cablevision and organized labor has dragged on for months, punctuated by protests and lawsuits, in a feud that has been particularly nasty even by most labor-management standards. Now the National Labor Relations Board has accused the company of acting illegally to avoid reaching an agreement with several hundred unionized cable installers in Brooklyn.

headline: Julia Sweeney Sees the Absurd in Motherhood (and Shares)
abstract: Only Julia Sweeney would find herself adopting a baby named Mulan — “like the movie.” And she knows it.
lead_paragraph: Within pages of opening “If It’s Not One Thing, It’s Your Mother” by Julia Sweeney (familiar to me, and many, as a former star of “Saturday Night Live” and the creator of the one-woman show and memoir “God Said Ha!”), I felt like I’d made a new friend — a funny, wry, so-cool-she-doesn’t-care-about-being-cool fellow parent with a voice I loved. I asked Julia for permission to share some of the book (it’s below) and I also asked her (among other things) what it’s like to see the world through her eyes.

headline: Scheduled to Play the Twins, the Mets Face Snow Instead
abstract: The Minnesota Twins’ team president said a decision on whether to play Friday’s game against the Mets would be made on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Don’t get the Minnesota Twins’ president, Dave St. Peter, started on the decision to build an open-air stadium in a city known for its brutal winters and fickle springs. The Twins benefited from favorable April weather in their first three seasons at Target Field, but St. Peter figured they were due for a problem.

headline: Russia Skips Hybrids in Push for Cars Using Natural Gas
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Natural Gas', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Russia, the world’s second-largest producer of natural gas, is making a bet that methane-powered cars are an alluring market for future growth.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Igor A. Samarsky of the southern Russian city of Krasnodar gets fuel economy on his 1998 Lada sedan that would make a Prius owner green with environmental envy.

headline: New Yorkers Brace for Cuts in Unemployment Benefits
abstract: Automatic federal budget cuts are playing havoc with emergency unemployment benefits.
lead_paragraph: Federal benefits for New Yorkers who have been unemployed for more than six months have been gradually disappearing. Now, the ones that remain are shrinking.

headline: Handling Nerves, Lynn Enjoys Strong First Round
abstract: David Lynn, a 39-year-old from England, said his runner-up finish at last year’s P.G.A. Championship helped him avoid any nervousness in his first Masters on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Minutes after his four-under par 68 made him the clubhouse leader, David Lynn said his runner-up finish at last year’s P.G.A. Championship helped him avoid any nervousness in his first Masters on Thursday.

headline: Lincoln Scribbled Here: Strokes That Fascinate
abstract: The Professional Autograph Dealers Association’s annual show at the Lotos Club includes treasures like an ink portrait of Lincoln in his coffin and a check he wrote to his carpenter for work on an outhouse.
lead_paragraph: NOT everybody gets it. For some people old documents, however historical, are little more than humdrum records, created to be filed for reference and cited when necessary, the documentary backdrop of grander happenings, with signatures that do no more than guarantee their authenticity. And for those with that point of view, autographed items other than formal documents — say, the back of an envelope — are merely fetishistic totems, and perhaps a little silly.

headline: Getting Personal: Writing College Essays for the Common Application
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore the open-ended prompts for the 2013-14 Common Application essays through writing and discussion. Then, they will identify and examine Times pieces that might serve as “mentor texts” for their own application essays. Finally, they craft essays.

headline: Environmental Readings at Poets House
abstract: Free weekend activities in New York City will include readings at Poets House and the Park Slope Food Co-op and bike lessons at Bldg 92.
lead_paragraph: The Miser has never known quite what to make of W. H. Auden’s assertion in his poem “In Memory of W. B. Yeats” that “poetry makes nothing happen.” Did he really hold so radically modest a view of art’s potential? Or was he being slyly ironic, daring us to doubt such seemingly hopeless pronouncements?

headline: Officially, There’s Now No Chance of Hurricane Sandy Returning
abstract: The World Meteorological Organization’s hurricane committee announced that it had retired Sandy from the list it uses to assign storm names.
lead_paragraph: There will never again be a Hurricane Sandy.

headline: When Independence Means You’re on Your Own
abstract: What sort of help should you expect if you suffer a medical problem at an independent living facility? Even legal experts aren’t sure.
lead_paragraph: In late February, Lorraine Bayless, 87, died at a California independent living facility after an employee declined to provide CPR — for more than seven minutes, even as a 911 dispatcher pleaded with her to intervene. The incident was the subject of enormous public outcry and generated widespread criticism of the facility. But it also raises important legal questions relevant to older adults and families living in similar settings.

headline: Alcohol and Breast Cancer Survival
abstract: A new study suggests that moderate drinking has little effect on survival after diagnosis, and may reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease.
lead_paragraph: Alcohol consumption is known to increase the risk for breast cancer. But a new study suggests that moderate drinking has little effect on survival after diagnosis, and may reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease.

headline: Director Named for New Dance School at University of Southern California
abstract: Jodie Gates is a dancer, choreographer and educator and former principal dancer with the Joffrey Ballet.
lead_paragraph: Jodie Gates, a dancer, choreographer and educator who is a former principal dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, has been named vice dean and director of the new Glorya Kaufman School of Dance at the University of Southern California. Ms. Gates is currently a professor of dance at the University of California, Irvine,  and is the founder and artistic director of the Laguna Dance Festival in Laguna Beach, Calif. In addition to the Joffrey, she has been a principal ballerina with the Frankfurt Ballet, the Pennsylvania Ballet and other major companies. Ms. Gates will begin her position in August at the school of dance. The school was established in November 2012 by a gift from Glorya Kaufman, a philanthropist and dance patron.

headline: Clip: ‘Kon-Tiki’ (Norwegian Language)
abstract: A scene from the Norwegian language version of “Kon-Tiki,” with English subtitles.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the Norwegian language version of “Kon-Tiki,” with English subtitles.

headline: Knicks to Waive Injured Thomas
abstract: The Knicks intend to waive the injured forward Kurt Thomas and sign James Singleton, 31, a 6-foot-8 forward who has been in and out of the N.B.A. since 2005.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The history of the Knicks’ transformative winning streak cannot be written without Kurt Thomas, although the conclusion to this breakthrough season most certainly will be.

headline: New Concerns From Germany Over European Banking Supervisor
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: German diplomats made clear that they had reservations about giving the central bank such powers because it might alter monetary policy to make supervision easier.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Germany has raised new concerns about a proposal to create a single banking supervisor for the European Union that could delay plans to help troubled lenders that finance ministers were to discuss here on Friday.

headline: Never Mind Facebook; Winklevoss Twins Rule in Digital Money
abstract: Silicon Valley and Wall Street are taking note of bitcoin, which has drawn prominent investors like the Winklevoss twins.
lead_paragraph: The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler — Olympic rowers, nemeses of Mark Zuckerberg — are laying claim to a new title: bitcoin moguls.

headline: Wine’s Leading Man Sets Down His Glass
abstract: In his 42 years as technical director of Louis Jadot, Jacques Lardière solidified his status as one of the most unforgettable characters in wine.
lead_paragraph: To watch Jacques Lardière scoot about the cellar at the headquarters of Louis Jadot in Beaune, France, the crossroads of Burgundy, is to see a man in his element. With white hair cascading from his head like a puffy cumulus cloud, red pants the likes of which only a Frenchman could even think of carrying off, twinkling eyes magnified by spectacles and an ever-present smile, Mr. Lardière is a cross between a wizard and an elf, climbing over barrels and digging deeper into Jadot’s rich Burgundian holdings in a determined effort to explain the wondrous mysteries that keep Burgundy lovers so everlastingly entranced.

headline: How to Write a College Application Essay
abstract: The lesson plan on writing college essays couldn’t be more timely for juniors, who are often encouraged to start thinking about their essays before senior year begins.
lead_paragraph: Our friends at The Learning Network blog have just published a lesson plan devoted to helping students prepare their essays for the Common Application, which recently released new essay prompts for the 2013-14 admission season.

headline: Canadian Teenager’s Suicide Ignites Calls for Review of Rape Case
abstract: The recent suicide of a Canadian teenager has revived outrage that the authorities did not do enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011 and bullied after photographs of the assault were shared and posted online.
lead_paragraph: The recent suicide of a Canadian teenager has revived outrage that the authorities did not do enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011 and bullied after photographs of the assault were shared and posted online.

headline: Having Mom Do Your Laundry, to Save Money
abstract: A calculator helps estimate what you can save if you live at home after college.
lead_paragraph: When I was in high school, I visited France on an exchange program and stayed with a well-to-do family. When I returned home, I marveled that the household employed a maid who washed my clothes. My mother rolled her eyes. “You have a maid here who does your laundry,” she said. “Me!”

headline: Hong Kong Operator Makes Bid for Telecom Italia
abstract: Franco Bernabe, the Telecom Italia chairman, said its board of directors had received an offer from Hutchison Whampoa, and that a committee of its biggest shareholders would review it.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Telecom Italia on Thursday said it would formally consider an offer to merge with a smaller rival in a deal that would make the Hong Kong industrial group Hutchison Whampoa its largest shareholder.

headline: Clip: 'Kon Tiki' (English Language)
abstract: A scene from the English language version of "Kon-Tiki."
lead_paragraph: A scene from the English language version of "Kon-Tiki."

headline: Here’s Hoping Understudies Aren’t Needed
abstract: The magician Rob Drummond catches a bullet in his mouth in his show at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: Bang! Bang! The sound of artificial gunfire is not unheard-of at the theater. But the shots fired in “Bullet Catch,” a magic show written, directed and performed by Rob Drummond, are more unsettling than most. They come from what is presented as a real handgun, and while one shot is fired at a porcelain plate, the second is aimed straight at Mr. Drummond’s head, as a volunteer from the audience, wearing ear protectors and goggles, faces him from several feet away — as if participating in a one-sided duel.

headline: Keeping Score: Changing Coaches Changed Nets Late in Games
abstract: Avery Johnson was 3-4 in games decided by 5 or fewer points this season, but in P.J. Carlesimo’s first 28 games the Nets were 9-0 in such games, a significant swing.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 26 the Brooklyn Nets lost to the Milwaukee Bucks, their 10th loss in 13 games after a franchise-best 11-4 start.

headline: Cracking the Mystery of Here to There
abstract: “Time and Navigation,” a new permanent exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum, charts the history of navigation — by land, sea, air and outer space — through the centuries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If you successfully navigate to the coordinates posted at the entrance — 38 degrees 53 minutes 18 seconds north latitude and 77 degrees 1 minute 8 seconds west longitude — you will find yourself at the new permanent exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum, “Time and Navigation: The Untold Story of Getting From Here to There.” And if you then make your way through the 5,000 square feet devoted to this show, most of which is superbly executed, you will realize just how astounding that initial feat was: to journey to a particular spot on the globe, consulting, perhaps, no more than a pocket-size smartphone, without risk of loss of life.

headline: New York’s Longest-Serving Pastor Dies at 93
abstract: Msgr. Gerald Ryan was a joyful though sometimes stern fixture on 138th Street in the Bronx, where he led St. Luke’s parish from 1966 until his death.
lead_paragraph: Msgr. Gerald Ryan, who began working as a priest in the Bronx in 1945 and went on to become the longest-serving pastor in New York and probably the country, died on Thursday at Our Lady of Consolation, a residence for ill priests, in Riverdale. He was 93.

headline: ‘Tuck Everlasting’ Can’t Find a Parking Spot on Broadway
abstract: The musical’s run in Boston has been postponed because, press representatives said, no theater is available for a transfer to New York.
lead_paragraph: With luck, audiences won’t have to live forever to see a musical adaptation of “Tuck Everlasting” hit Broadway, but they are going to have to wait a little longer for it. The producers of a new musical based on that Natalie Babbitt children’s novel, about a girl who meets a boy from a family of immortals, said that its planned world premiere in Boston would be delayed because there were no theaters in New York where the musical could transfer.

headline: Paris Judge to Rule Friday on Hopi Artifact Sale
abstract: A Paris judge said Thursday that she will decide Friday whether an auction that day of Hopi Indian artifacts can proceed despite complaints from the tribe.
lead_paragraph: A French civil court judge heard arguments for two hours Thursday and said she will rule Friday on whether a major auction of sacred Hopi Indian artifacts can go forward in Paris despite claims by the tribe that they were stolen and that selling them is sacrilegious.

headline: Citigroup’s Washington Push
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Citigroup’s chief executive attended the ribbon-cutting at a new branch in the nation’s capital, on K Street, home to the city’s legions of lobbyists. The potential symbolism is hard to avoid.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup‘s chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, understands Washington’s importance.

headline: The Price of Gold (and Ron Paul)
abstract: As the value of gold declines, a look back at the libertarian’s views on fiat currency.
lead_paragraph: The price of gold, The New York Times reported today, has fallen 17 percent since late 2011. Just on Wednesday, the price of bullion dropped $28, to $1,558 an ounce. Gold-focused mutual funds, which reached a peak value of $26.3 billion in April of 2011, have lost half of their value since then.

headline: Joshua Marsh ‘As If’
abstract: Joshua Marsh’s sumptuous paintings of ordinary objects are on view at Jeff Bailey, and a darkly comical video by Johannes DeYoung is being screened in the gallery’s project room.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bailey Gallery

headline: Mary Lucier: ‘New Installation Works’
abstract: A 26-minute video meditation on vision — and on video itself as a mirror of perception — is the centerpiece of Mary Lucier’s show at Lennon, Weinberg.
lead_paragraph: Lennon, Weinberg

headline: Senate Republicans Describe Cordial, if Not Convincing, Dinner With Obama
abstract: Senate Republicans described the dinner Wednesday with President Obama as casual, but most said they came away unmoved by his arguments.
lead_paragraph: President Obama threw his second dinner party of the year for Republican senators Wednesday night, but if the first such venture in March yielded a few rounds of “Kumbaya,” the second was apparently more “Hit the Road Jack.”

headline: ‘Faith Ringgold’s America: Early Works and Story Quilts’
abstract: Nearly a dozen of Faith Ringgold’s better-known story quilts are on view at ACA Galleries, along with some of her paintings from the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: ACA Galleries

headline: Agus Suwage: ‘Cycle No. 2’
abstract: Self-portraiture is the common thread of Agus Suwage’s show at Tyler Rollins Fine Art.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Rollins Fine Art

headline: Jon Kessler: ‘The Web’
abstract: Jon Kessler explores society’s — and the art world’s — obsession with Apple and with digital technology in “The Web,” a kinetic installation at the Swiss Institute.
lead_paragraph: Swiss Institute

headline: Khalil Rabah: ‘Pages, 7, 8, 9’
abstract: Supposed excerpts from a wryly conceptual “newsletter” on Khalil Rabah’s fictional Palestinian Museum of Natural History and Humankind are on view at e-flux.
lead_paragraph: e-flux

headline: The Roger Vivier Legacy
abstract: The release of a coffee table book on the history of Roger Vivier, inspired conversation at the Museum at F.I.T. on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Last night Dr. Valerie Steele, the director of the Museum at F.I.T., moderated a discussion with the Roger Vivier creative director Bruno Frisoni and the Vivier brand ambassador Inès de la Fressange to talk about the release of a vibrant new coffee table book on the history of the storied French shoe label. Images from the new tome informed the talk, which took place in the Katie Murphy Amphitheatre.

headline: Google Introduces a Tool for Planning for Your Digital Afterlife
abstract: As Web companies and legislators grapple with who controls your digital life after you die, Google introduces a tool for designating what you want to happen to your data.
lead_paragraph: One of the most haunting questions facing Web companies and their users is, what happens to the stuff of our digital lives after we die?

headline: Bangladesh Police Arrest Acting Editor of Pro-Opposition Paper
abstract: The editor, Mahmudur Rahman, was charged with sedition at a time when strikes by opposition forces have frozen travel and are crippling the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: CHITTAGONG, Bangladesh — The police in Bangladesh arrested the acting editor of a pro-opposition newspaper on Thursday amid strikes by opposition forces that have frozen travel in much of the country and that are crippling its economy.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Turkey Said to Be Targeted
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Synagogues', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Twelve people were arrested in a plot said to be linked to Al Qaeda to attack the embassy in Ankara and other targets.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkish police said Thursday that they had found evidence of a plot linked to Al Qaeda to bomb the United States Embassy in Ankara, a synagogue in Istanbul and other targets, from a raid on two houses in February, according to news reports.

headline: ‘Murals on the Bowery,’ Organized by Art Production Fund
abstract: The steel shutters on some Lower Manhattan storefronts will provide the canvases for paintings that could truly be considered street art.
lead_paragraph: ROLLDOWN STEEL MURALS

headline: Wheelies: The Top-Selling Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: The number of Toyota Corollas sold last year is disputed, but Toyota maintains its compact outsold the Ford Focus last year.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Republican Effort to Unpack the Court
abstract: Liberals are tearing into a Republican plan to reduce the number of judges on the country’s most important appeals court, calling it a political ploy.
lead_paragraph: Liberals are tearing into a Republican plan to reduce the number of judges on the country’s most important appeals court, calling it a political ploy to keep President Obama from making the court less conservative.

headline: Ex-KPMG Partner Is Charged in Insider Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors revealed a brazen two-year insider trading scheme involving Scott London, a former senior partner at the accounting giant KPMG, and a longtime friend.
lead_paragraph: 11:05 p.m. | Updated

headline: Romney Visits New York to Thank Donors
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mitt Romney hit Manhattan on Thursday for what several people with knowledge of his trip described as a “thank you” tour for donors and fund-raisers from his recent presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Since losing the 2012 presidential election, Mitt Romney has pumped his own gas (with wind-tousled hair), navigated Costco with his wife, Ann (stocking up on everything from bottled water to paper towels) and welcomed grandchildren 19 and 20 (twins, from his youngest son, Craig).

headline: Aiding Sobriety, a Chord at a Time
abstract: Eric Clapton unites grimy Midtown Manhattan and the pristine Caribbean with his guitar festival benefiting a rehab clinic in Antigua.
lead_paragraph: IT’S about 1,700 miles from Madison Square Garden to Willoughby Bay in Antigua, and it is hard to imagine two places more different than the grimy canyons of Midtown Manhattan and the pristine, windswept hills overlooking the Caribbean that are home to the Crossroads Center drug rehabilitation clinic.

headline: To Catch a Killer Nurse
abstract: In “The Good Nurse” by Charles Graeber, a real-life murder investigation takes some odd paths.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, the world discovered what a night nurse named Charles Cullen had been doing during the preceding 16 years. He had killed a judge, a priest and an unknown but large number of other people. He may have been the most prolific serial killer in history.

headline: A President’s Death, Recalled in Artifacts
abstract: Ahead of the 50th anniversary of President Kennedy’s assassination, museums and auctioneers are bringing out some disturbing and tangential items.
lead_paragraph: A PRESIDENT’S DEATH,

headline: What God Wants
abstract: The gay journalist Jeff Chu traveled across the country to meet with preachers, pastors and ministers who fall all over the map when it comes to the issue of homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: “Yeeeah, Sydney!” the songwriter and comedian Tim Minchin shouts into a microphone. “Are you up for a . . . sing?”

headline: Voices Inside Their Heads
abstract: For writers who inhabit many different worlds, there may be no such thing as a definitive “style.”
lead_paragraph: Mohsin Hamid’s latest novel boasts a startlingly distinctive voice, as commanding and unadorned as its title, “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia.” But what may be most exciting about that voice — the whole book is delivered in the terse declarations of a mock self-help manual — is that it’s nothing like the voices we met in his two earlier novels. The first, “Moth Smoke,” was a moody, multipart evocation of party kids and S.U.V.’s in Lahore, poetically given life by Hamid as if to the manner born; his second, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” was a fast-moving monologue from a young Pakistani, educated at Princeton and once well employed in New York (as Hamid was), who’s returned to his homeland post-9/11 and lures a Daniel Pearl-like American into a confrontation.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Dan Savage began writing his syndicated column, “Savage Love,” more than 20 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Dan Savage, who reviews Jeff Chu’s “Does Jesus Really Love Me?” this week, is perhaps best known for his syndicated column, “Savage Love.” The column first appeared in The Stranger, a Seattle weekly newspaper, in 1991, and is now published worldwide — quite an accomplishment for something that began as a joke. “A gay guy giving advice to straight people about straight sex?” as Savage put it in an e-mail. “The plan — the joke — was that I was treating straight relationships and straight sex with the same contempt that straight advice columnists had always treated gay sex and gay relationships. I thought I could stretch the joke out for six months at most. But the column took off. It turned out that straight people really enjoyed being treated with contempt — it was a new experience for them. Twenty-plus years later, I’m still writing the column.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: AEROGRAMMES: And Other Stories,  by Tania James. (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) James’s 2009 debut novel, “Atlas of Unknowns,” followed the divergent lives of two motherless sisters from Kerala, India. Her first story collection displays a similar warmhearted lyricism, as eclectic characters — a chimpanzee, a ghost, two Indian wrestlers in Edwardian London — are entangled in sticky human relationships.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BETWEEN MAN AND BEAST: An Unlikely Explorer, the Evolution Debates, and the African Adventure That Took the Victorian World by Storm,  by Monte Reel. (Doubleday, $26.95.) In the age of ­Darwin, the discovery of gorillas caused a sensation.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Paulo Coelho assembled his novel “Manuscript Found in Accra,” No. 2 on this week’s hardcover list, after soliciting ideas from his 6.3 million Twitter followers.
lead_paragraph: THE LAST KEY: Paulo Coelho, the elfin guru of a novelist who unleashed “The Alchemist” on the world, is at No. 2 on this week’s hardcover list with a new novel, “Manuscript Found in Accra” — although a more forthright title might be “Manuscript Found on Social Media,” since Coelho assembled the book after soliciting ideas from his 6.3 million Twitter followers. The resulting volume of ponderous clichés will surprise nobody familiar with Coelho, or Twitter.

headline: Hope Springs Eternal
abstract: Journeys of self-discovery await the adventurers of these fantasy tales.
lead_paragraph: When my oldest son was 3 and something didn’t go quite the way he had envisioned, he would lament: “I want to go back! I want to go back!” Surely, one of the hardest jobs of childhood is accepting that life moves forward and when something terrible happens, it cannot be undone with either words or wishes. Two new middle-grade fantasy novels feature children on the verge of adolescence who want very much to change the course of life events, and who learn it’s never as simple as it may seem.

headline: The Bad Guys
abstract: Four picture books showcase villains and tough situations.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who knows children knows they are not timid when it comes to pondering ethical conundrums. Rather, as their routine cry of “No fair!” proves, they live for it.

headline: Her Town
abstract: A teenage girl in rural New Hampshire grapples with death.
lead_paragraph: Grandparents often appear in children’s literature just so they can be taken away. At times, death provides a largely unearned “teachable moment,” while at others it conjures a powerful approximation of grief. Linda Urban’s new novel, “The Center of Everything,” uses the premise of a grandparent’s death in a surprising way, exploring not only grief but also its occasional companions, anxiety and guilt.

headline: Get Back
abstract: This mirror sends people into the past, but can’t retrieve them.
lead_paragraph: All successful novels for young adults must pass what one might call a narcissistic grandiosity test. Adolescents are, of course, at a developmental stage in which a certain level of passionate self-involvement is the norm. This is both natural and necessary. Good young adult novels must therefore reflect and dramatize the reader’s fantasy of being victimized and misunderstood, yet secretly possessed of powers that allow mastery of one’s destiny. Consequently, the characters in Y.A. fiction tend to live in special worlds, somehow set apart from those of other people. Often, they’re either escaping from or saving their parents; if they discover a way to do both simultaneously, even better.

headline: The Back Story
abstract: The final volume of Jane Gardam’s trilogy looks more deeply at the life of its hero’s nemesis.
lead_paragraph: On a list of my top reading interests, the lives of kooky geezers in a fading English village don’t rank high. But all it takes is a page or two of Jane Gardam to force a reconsideration. Her prose is so perceptive and fluid that it feels mentally healthful, exiling the noise and clutter of your mind as efficiently as a Schubert sonata. She could make actuarial tables pleasurable.

headline: The Road to Salvation
abstract: Escapees from a polygamous cult, Peggy Riley’s heroines are unprepared for the world that lies beyond.
lead_paragraph: A car crashes into a chickasaw plum tree in the Oklahoma panhandle, two sisters in the back seat strapped together at the wrist. Four days behind them, in Idaho, lies a remote fundamentalist compound where their father governed 50 wives. Yes, 50. Yes, he bedded them all.

headline: Grave New World
abstract: In Nathaniel Rich’s novel, a mathematician becomes an expert predictor of disaster.
lead_paragraph: Natural calamity has long occupied a central role in our stories; there’s a pretty good one about a guy escaping a flood with some animals on a boat. After this past fall, expect several more, with Nathaniel Rich and his intelligent, exhaustively researched second novel, “Odds Against Tomorrow,” at the vanguard of post-Sandy catastrophe lit.

headline: Bookshelf: For the Birds
abstract: New picture books starring a pair of goslings, animated chickens, lucky ducklings, and a boy and his bluebird.
lead_paragraph: New picture books starring a pair of goslings, animated chickens, lucky ducklings, and a boy and his bluebird.

headline: Heart’s Desire
abstract: Two poetry collections from Britain’s poet laureate, Carol Ann Duffy.
lead_paragraph: Carol Ann Duffy, the British poet laureate, is almost unknown in this country, which makes her no worse off than blood pudding, haggis or Marmite. Britain and America are no longer divided by a common tongue — for 50 years or more, we have been listening to British music, watching British television and welcoming British writers as warmly as we once welcomed Dickens. Still, most poets don’t travel well; apart from an oddity like Seamus Heaney or Derek Walcott, poets are rarely known outside their home countries (worse, they’re rarely known outside their hometowns).

headline: Poetry Chronicle
abstract: New books by Daisy Fried, David Yezzi, A. Van Jordan and Rachel Hadas.
lead_paragraph: WOMEN’S POETRY  Poems and Advice.  By Daisy Fried.  University of Pittsburgh, paper, $15.95.

headline: Unreliable Sources
abstract: A journalist explores his father’s sudden, hazily explained death.
lead_paragraph: Michael Hainey wanted to be like his father. Since his father died when he had just turned 6, he had to base his model less on memory than on myth. His father was a Chicago newspaperman, and so Hainey romanticized the bygone world of Chicago newspapermen. He venerated good reporting. He drank Scotch on the rocks. He sensed secrets in his childhood home. His mother told him his father had died of a heart attack. “I had to pry this out of her,” Hainey writes in “After Visiting Friends.” She was vague about the circumstances. “All my life,” he says, “I’ve felt the story I was told about how my father died did not add up.” An obituary mentioned that his father had been visiting friends: who? It also mentioned a strange address: where had his father gone, and why? So Hainey looked for answers.

headline: A Knowing Eye
abstract: The photographer Dorothea Lange and her most enduring portrait inspired Marisa Silver’s novel.
lead_paragraph: We know the photograph. A seated woman — hand at her jaw, skin etched with worry — looks into the middle distance. Children rest their heads on her shoulders, faces turned away; an infant lies bundled in her lap. By capturing the plight of California’s ­Depression-era migrant workers, Dorothea Lange’s “Migrant Mother” transformed a nation’s attitudes toward the poor from the moment of its publication in 1936. Today, its immediacy dulled by time and fame, it functions mainly as a visual metonym for the Great Depression. We look at it, but we no longer see it, to borrow a distinction made in Marisa Silver’s phenomenal new novel, “Mary Coin.”

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — They called themselves the A.D. Jail Crew and sought to band together “brothers and sisters” in prisons across Germany to “defend loyalty, comradeship and the ‘old’ values.” Their aim, according to an advertisement found by the authorities who broke up the network, was to provide support for neo-Nazis serving time behind bars.

headline: A New Generation Dives In to Learn the Old Language
abstract: The resurrected Dance Theater of Harlem returned to the stage with a bold choice, Balanchine’s “Agon,” and three other works in a mixed program at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Founded in 1969 to dispel the myth that blacks couldn’t dance classical ballet, Dance Theater of Harlem toured internationally for decades as a shining symbol that they could. For decades there were also administrative and financial troubles, and in 2004, mounting debts forced the troupe to go on hiatus. Now it has returned, and on Wednesday at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center the nervousness was palpable. Everyone wants this company to succeed.

lead_paragraph: Herbalife wasn’t knowingly involved the insider trading scheme that revolved around a now-former KPMG partner. But the nutritional supplements company still played a major role all the same.

headline: Freedom From High Society in the Sunny Outdoors
abstract: “John Singer Sargent Watercolors,” a Brooklyn Museum show that also features works from the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, highlights a different side of an artist best known for his flattering oil portraits of the rich.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the turn of the 20th century John Singer Sargent went through a midlife crisis. An American expatriate in London, he was sick of painting flattering portraits of rich people, though he could do it with such seemingly effortless panache that he’d become one of England’s most celebrated artists. He began to retire from that lucrative but repetitious occupation.

headline: Where the Spies Are: A Training Camp for Automotive Paparazzi

lead_paragraph: Brenda Priddy, an auto spy photographer, is starting a camp for people who dream of joining the ranks of car paparazzi. Starting on July 7, Ms. Priddy will lead would-be car spies through the basics of her craft in a four-day camp in the Nevada desert.

lead_paragraph: You still can’t ask Ellen Pao anything. But Reddit announced Thursday that the former venture capitalist will now be working with the social networking site, home of the popular Ask Me Anything chats.

headline: Now That’s What We Call a Softball Jersey
abstract: This year we’ve already scored a victory with our new jerseys, designed by Christoph Niemann.
lead_paragraph: Avid followers of The New York Times Magazine softball team may remember that last year’s season was, by standard measures, not exactly a winning one. (Definitions of “win” have been known to vary.) But this year we have already scored a victory with our new jerseys, designed by Christoph Niemann, possibly while he was was running a marathon. Judging by T-shirt sales alone, it appears that our roster this year has tripled in size — although numbers were slightly skewed by Lauren (The Killer Within) Kern, who purchased two for herself, despite concerns that our outfielders “will blend in with the grass.”

headline: Horror at Every Turn of a Dark Cyberjungle
abstract: “Disconnect,” with Jason Bateman and Hope Davis, offers a montage of overlapping stories about thievery, humiliation and exposed secrets on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: The jittery characters who scuttle through the three stories that make up “Disconnect” are struggling to make their way through today’s treacherous cyberwilderness. Some are predators, others prey. Naïve travelers who venture into territory taken over by upstart tribes of technological outlaws risk being ambushed, fleeced and humiliated. Law enforcement is often helpless to catch up with tricksters adept at staying ahead of the game.

headline: A Detached Look at Pop Art From Post-Fascist Italy
abstract: Giosetta Fioroni’s solo show of films and silvery works at the Drawing Center is a reminder of how little Americans know of Pop Art in Italy.
lead_paragraph: “Giosetta Fioroni: L’Argento” proves that the field of postwar Italian art, though crowded at the moment, is far from exhausted. This show at the Drawing Center complements recent gallery exhibitions of Lucio Fontana, Piero Manzoni, Giorgio Griffa, Gianni Colombo and Luigi Ghirri, not to mention museum surveys of Michelangelo Pistoletto and Alighiero Boetti, introducing us to the only female member of the School of the Piazza del Popolo (named for a popular Roman artists’ hangout).

headline: A Temperament for Trouble and a Nose for Fine Whisky
abstract: In Ken Loach’s “Angels’ Share,” a hot-headed hooligan from Glasgow’s underclass turns out to have an extraordinary talent for identifying different varieties of whisky.
lead_paragraph: “The Angels’ Share,” the twinkly title of Ken Loach’s new comedy, is slang for the roughly 2 percent of malt whisky that evaporates while it ages in a cask.

headline: Bully Wallpaper and a Ceiling Lost in Space

lead_paragraph: The great halls of Grand Central, the American Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art each present different painted faces: Grand Central has a swath of the heavens at nighttime, redone 15 years ago; the natural history museum has murals of the life of Theodore Roosevelt, restored last fall; and the Metropolitan Museum, well ... where are the murals, anyway?

headline: That Rookie at First Is in a New Position
abstract: “42,” Brian Helgeland’s new film about Jackie Robinson, is blunt, simple and sentimental, using time-tested methods to teach a clear and rousing lesson.
lead_paragraph: Biographies of great athletes can be roughly sorted into three categories. There are hero-worshiping fables suitable for fourth-grade classrooms, scandalous feet-of-clay exposés and, rarest of all, narratives that link sports with significant, nonathletic historical events and social issues. In America those events and issues almost always have to do with race, which makes the life of Jackie Robinson especially ripe for sweeping, comprehensive treatment.

lead_paragraph: “Da Vinci’s Demons” proposes a new definition of Renaissance man. Painting, drawing and inventing are no longer sufficient. To be the hero of a 21st-century pay-cable historical drama, Leonardo must also fight like a mixed-martial-arts star, bed the boss’s mistress (the boss being Lorenzo de’ Medici) and solve crimes like a combination of Sherlock Holmes and Gil Grissom from “CSI.”

headline: Take the Long View

lead_paragraph: During a job review, my boss told me I was in line for promotion when my supervisor moved up. Well, my supervisor left. But the boss promoted a woman who joined the company after me rather than giving me the job as promised. He said this woman will make a better manager than I would. (I’m a man.) I think this is reverse-sexism, but I’m not sure what to do about it. Talk to human resources, my boss’s boss or just eat it? J. D.

headline: Deficit Reduction, Minus the Reduction
abstract: The president’s new budget, while admirable in many respects, comes up short in one big way.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s new budget, released on Wednesday, is stuffed with constructive ideas. It bravely outlines concrete steps to begin fixing Social Security. It flouts today’s all-deficit-cutting, all-the-time mentality with important proposals for fresh spending on infrastructure and universal prekindergarten education. It includes detailed plans to close tax loopholes and raise needed revenues from the wealthy.

lead_paragraph: ‘Passages Through the Fire: Jews and the Civil War’ (through Aug. 11) It was not uncommon during the Civil War for family members to take opposing sides. Of the five sons of Abraham Jonas, who served as postmaster general of Quincy, Ill., and his wife, Louisa, four sided with the Confederacy — though one brother later became a Union soldier. The only one supporting the Union from the start was the youngest, Edward Jonas, above right, in an undated image.

abstract: Our relationship was not an obvious one, but neither of us liked the obvious.

headline: Autographs Are Far Less of a Mess
abstract: “Antiviral” is the first feature film directed by Brandon Cronenberg, the son of David Cronenberg.
lead_paragraph: The wormy apple doesn’t fall far from the rotting tree. In saying that, I don’t mean to cast aspersions on the Cronenberg family bloodline but only to point out that in his first feature, “Antiviral,” the 33-year-old Brandon Cronenberg exhibits the same obsession with mutilation and infection as his father, David, did in movies like “Crash” and “The Fly.”

headline: Eyeing That Empty Seat
abstract: In “Arcadia,” a film directed by Olivia Silver that opens on Friday in Brooklyn, three children grow ever more suspicious about their father’s intentions during a family road trip.
lead_paragraph: “Arcadia” opens at dusk with four people slipping out of a house like thieves. As soon as they climb into the car it becomes evident that the man and the three children with him are related. Yet when one of the kids, 12-year-old Greta (Ryan Simpkins), pauses to look at some family photographs, the air stirs. Something has happened here, but it takes time — along with many miles, a few fights, some misunderstandings and a young awakening — to know what.

headline: A Festival Now Comfortable in Its Skin
abstract: In its 12th season the Tribeca Film Festival, which begins Wednesday and includes the premieres of 53 features, has woven itself into the fabric of the New York cultural schedule.
lead_paragraph: In any life there are moments of acute awareness when you suddenly realize the degree to which you’ve grown up. The Tribeca Film Festival, which begins its 12th season on Wednesday, is experiencing such a flash.

headline: Is It Art, or Is It Just Real Estate?

headline: The Apocalypse, for Laughs
abstract: In Todd Berger’s comedy, Julia Stiles and David Cross play one of four Los Angeles couples whose weekly brunch is interrupted by a large-scale catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: It may be the end of the world, but they feel fine, even oblivious. That, at any rate, appears to be the principal, really the only point of the impishly, unfortunately titled “It’s a Disaster,” an underbaked comedy about eight people facing their mortality. Set in the present, it mostly unfolds in a Los Angeles house within gasping distance of a large-scale catastrophe of the kind usually let loose by masters of disaster, like Roland Emmerich. The writer and director, Todd Berger, is working on a far smaller scale than his blockbuster brethren do, and that may explain why he keeps calamitous details fuzzy, using two corpses, a Hazmat suit and a murder of crows to suggest the apocalyptic big picture.

headline: Emirates’ Laws Trap a Doctor Just Passing Through
abstract: A South African doctor on a layover in the United Arab Emirates is trapped there by criminal charges he had not been aware of.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — For Dr. Cyril Karabus, it was a routine job, albeit in an exotic location. For six weeks in 2002, he filled in for another doctor in Abu Dhabi, lured like many other foreign professionals by the big paychecks that doctors, bankers, lawyers and architects can earn in the United Arab Emirates and other Persian Gulf nations.

headline: Settlement to Benefit Borrowers
abstract: A New York State investigation results in a settlement that could rein in the outsize premiums charged for so-called force-placed insurance, for borrowers who let their homeowners’ insurance lapse.
lead_paragraph: Banks and mortgage servicers often impose what is known as force- or lender-placed insurance on borrowers who allow their homeowners’ insurance to lapse. But a state investigation, and a resulting settlement, could rein in the outsize premiums that come with these policies, which are typically 2 to 10 times higher than standard plans, even though their coverage is more limited.

headline: An American’s Long March With Mao
abstract: “The Revolutionary” centers on Sidney Rittenberg, who was sent by the United States Army to China at the end of World War II, but stayed on and joined the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Rittenberg wanted to be a revolutionary. So when the United States Army sent him to China just after World War II, he stayed on and joined the Communist Party, becoming a privileged insider, a rare foreigner among the party elite. He helped promote the Cultural Revolution, speaking at rallies all over China. And he was imprisoned, twice, spending almost 16 years in solitary confinement. (The first time, the authorities offered to release him if he returned to the United States, but he chose to remain in prison to prove his loyalty to the revolution.)

headline: Sequestration of Justice
abstract: Budget cuts for federal public defenders are gutting the constitutional right to counsel.
lead_paragraph: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith is a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden and a former spokesman for Al Qaeda. He is accused of providing material support for terrorism, and, as the federal indictment against him charges, conspiring to “murder United States nationals anywhere in the world.”

headline: Brain Disease and the N.F.L.
abstract: Retired players deserve the chance to prove in court the link between the violent professional game and head trauma and that the league failed to protect them.
lead_paragraph: More than 4,000 retired players are suing the National Football League for failing to protect players from chronic risks of head injuries routinely inflicted in professional football games — and then willfully concealing those risks from players. headline: One on One: Douglas Rushkoff on Everything Happening Now

lead_paragraph: Douglas Rushkoff hurts the way only a onetime true believer can hurt. Before he taught at New York University and the New School, he was an early fan of the Internet. “I was a slacker, and it seemed like a way to slack,” he says. “We’d all work when we felt like it.” Instead of a contemplative paradise, however, the marriage of networked technology and capitalism tortures our consciousness with an incessant, demanding present. “We’ve attached ourselves to it,” he says; “We respond to things when it wants us to, which is all the time.”

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) ADAPTATION (2002) The director Spike Jonze and the writer Charlie Kaufman (along with his imaginary twin, Donald, who is also credited with writing the screenplay) journey into metafiction in this movie about the two Kaufmans (Nicolas Cage, in both roles) and Susan Orlean (Meryl Streep), a writer for The New Yorker whose book “The Orchid Thief” inspired the film. Chris Cooper won an Oscar for best supporting actor for his role as an orchid obsessive; Ms. Streep and Mr. Cage (above) also received Oscar nominations. “ ‘Adaptation’ is, most obviously, a movie about itself, as gleefully self-referential an exercise in auto-deconstruction as you could wish,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But it is also, more deeply, a movie about its own nonexistence — a narrative that confronts both the impossibility and the desperate necessity of storytelling, and that short-circuits our expectations of coherence, plausibility and fidelity to lived reality even as it satisfies them. Common sense suggests that there could never be such a movie, but if there could, it would have to be one of the slipperiest, most fascinating and, by any sane reckoning, best movies of the year.”

headline: Development and Its Discontent
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Street traffic is exploding in Cambodia. And no one can keep up.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH — In 2010, the Cambodian government unveiled with great fanfare the country’s first traffic overpass. The $6 million project — lit with a futuristic blue neon swoosh — was intended to ease congestion where a major boulevard that runs north-south through Phnom Penh intersects with twin bridges that cross the Bassac River, just to the east. Prime Minister Hun Sen called the Sky Bridge Project a “great achievement” and proclaimed that it would end traffic problems in the area.It wasn’t long before commuters discovered a catch: By making it easier for motorists traveling north-south to keep going straight, the new overpass made it impossible for them to turn left onto the intersecting east-west road. The result is a mess. Now, drivers heading south who want to cross the river must first take a right and drive away for several hundred meters and then make a U-turn and head back. And motorists heading north are forced to turn right, which necessarily takes them onto the bridges — meaning that they are forced to cross the river, turn around and cross the river again. Congestion in the area is worse than ever, and the traffic more dangerous.

headline: Day 2: Highlights and Analysis From the Masters
abstract: Highlights and analysis from the second day of the Masters.
lead_paragraph: The Australian Jason Day holds sole possession of the lead after 36 holes at the Masters on Friday, finishing at six under par with four birdies on the back nine. Day, who finished tied for second at the 2011 Masters, had never topped the leader board overnight at a major. Day is one shot ahead of his countryman Marc Leishman and the American veteran Fred Couples, who are tied for second at five under. Angel Cabrera, Jim Furyk, and Brandt Snedeker are tied for fourth at four under.  Tiger Woods, who had his back nine derailed by a severe bounce off the flag pole on No. 15, is part of a seven-way tie for seventh. As the day wrapped up, most eyes were on the middle-to-bottom part of the scoreboard, as the cut line hovered around the name of 14-year-old Guan Tianlang of China, who just barely survived with a score of four over.   Guan would have advanced more comfortably had he not been assessed a rare stroke penalty for slow play on the 17th hole.  Despite the unusual ruling, Guan did not take opportunities offered to him by Tom Rinaldi of ESPN to criticize or bemoan the controversial ruling.  “I respect their decision,” he said.

headline: Who Made That Lipstick?
abstract: Creating a kiss-proof formula.
lead_paragraph: In the 1940s, lipstick tended to fade and smear. Women were constantly checking their teeth for red marks and repainting their mouths. Hazel Bishop — a biochemist with a background in petroleum science — set out to solve this problem. Using the tiny kitchen of her Central Park West apartment as a lab, she cooked potions in a double boiler and compounded dyes on a countertop. Sometimes so much dust escaped from her experiments that the butter in her refrigerator turned red. Lipstick had existed for centuries, of course, but Bishop hoped to create a long-lasting version for the modern woman, one that would stand up to the friction of coffee cups, cigarettes and kisses. She hit on a formula made with lanolin and dyes that penetrated deep into the skin. To demonstrate its sticking power, she persuaded her neighborhood druggist to decorate his hand with streaks of her lipstick. As he rang up purchases, the red stripes stayed bright.

headline: Prairie Jazz Companion
abstract: Maria Schneider blends big-band jazz, poetry and chamber music. It’s not as easy as it sounds.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago the jazz composer Maria Schneider traveled back to her hometown, Windom, Minn. She climbed a ladder with a childhood friend named Tony Thompson and found herself at the top of a silo. She looked out over the fields: acres of Thompson’s bean plants moving over and past one another in the breeze. Windom, population 4,646, is the seat of Cottonwood County, near the state’s southwest corner. The Des Moines River flows leisurely through it. The land is smooth prairie, in all directions. “The mistake people make,” Schneider told me about this flat place she came from, “is thinking that it’s flat.”

headline: Temple Grandin on Autism, Death, Celibacy and Cows
abstract: Why she chose a life without sex and will not pooh-pooh a link between vaccines and autism.
lead_paragraph: In your new book, “The Autistic Brain,” you seriously entertain possible links between vaccines and autism in children, links that scientists have vehemently dismissed.  Well, there’s only one vaccine that could possibly be a problem, and that’s the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine. Now that they’ve changed the vaccine, it has fewer antigens, and that would make it a lot safer. But with the old version of the vaccine, I have not yet come across a study that looked at regressives — when a child had some speech but lost it.

lead_paragraph: Frank Sinatra performed there; so did Rodney Dangerfield and Kermit the Frog.

headline: Chaos Assembled, Beauty Emerges
abstract: Alan Gilbert prepares to conduct the New York Philharmonic in Charles Ives’s Fourth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the second movement of Charles Ives’s Symphony No. 4 a tender melody suddenly erupts into bawdy cacophony, like a marching band lurching through a carnival fun house.

headline: Leading Off: A Baseball Brawl That Hurts
abstract: The Dodgers were fuming and furious after the Padres’ Carlos Quentin charged the mound on Thursday night and broke pitcher Zack Greinke’s collarbone.
lead_paragraph: Zack Greinke, the right-hander who signed a six-year, $147 million deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers in the off-season, broke his left collarbone Thursday night when Carlos Quentin of the San Diego Padres charged the mound after Greinke hit him in the left shoulder with a pitch.

headline: Back Home in Texas, for the First Time
abstract: To prepare for her performance in the Broadway revival of “A Trip to Bountiful,” Cicely Tyson visited Wharton, Tex., and the family home of the playwright Horton Foote.
lead_paragraph: WHARTON, Tex. — This is the kind of town (population 8,832) where line-hung laundry flaps in the breeze, crows caw from 100-year-old oaks, and neighbors have you over for a Sunday supper of fried chicken and collard greens. Everyone knows everyone, so a stranger gets noticed, particularly a famous actress putting her hands in the dirt of a plowed-up cornfield.

headline: The Man Who Took His Life as a Dance
abstract: The Worlds of Oliver Sacks is an interdisciplinary festival at New York Live Arts, led by Bill T. Jones.
lead_paragraph: “Are we still shaking?” the choreographer Bill T. Jones asked, extending a hand to Dr. Oliver Sacks, the writer and neurologist. Then he chuckled and instead went in for a hug, parting ways with him after tea at Dr. Sacks’s Greenwich Village apartment.

headline: New Chamber Music From Lee Hyla
abstract: “My Life on the Plains,” a new album of chamber works by Lee Hyla, features performances by the Firebird Ensemble.
lead_paragraph: Lee Hyla: ‘My Life on the Plains’ (Chamber Works)

headline: Technology’s Impact on the Value of Financial Advice
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Financial Planners', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Financial advisers are putting greater emphasis on technology, but it is unclear whether that is better for their clients.
lead_paragraph: WE use technological shortcuts for things from simple tasks like booking vacations and buying books to more consequential matters like searching for a new home or trying to diagnose our ailments.

headline: Gym, Tan, Laundry, Family, Talk Show
abstract: Vinny Guadagnino of “Jersey Shore” hosts “The Show With Vinny,” on MTV, in which guests hang with him and often his relatives on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: It could have been any house on this suburban stretch of Staten Island, with a well-worn basketball hoop outside and a sign out front warning, “Beware of Dog.” But here one wintry February afternoon Vinny Guadagnino, the former “Jersey Shore” star, was pacing from room to room of the home where he grew up, now the site of his new MTV talk show, as he awaited a visit from the pop star Kesha.

headline: When Shareholder Democracy Is Sham Democracy
abstract: There are 41 publicly traded companies with directors who lost their elections last year. Despite these votes of no confidence, they stayed in their posts.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I argued that it was hard to imagine a more compelling case for ousting directors than the one posed by Hewlett-Packard.

headline: The Gun Report: April 12, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Since Roger Ebert’s passing last week, most obituaries have focused—naturally enough—on his witty, wide-eyed movie criticism. But in his later years he wrote on a number of topics, including gun legislation. After the massacre in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater, he wrote an Op-Ed in this newspaper arguing that there is no “easy link between movies and gun violence. I think the link is between the violence and the publicity.” He continued:

headline: The Coda of Shuggie Otis
abstract: Now 59, the R&B musician Shuggie Otis has had a baffling career, from a teenage blues guitar prodigy to decades of silence and now a new album and a tour.
lead_paragraph: This week the first new music in almost 40 years will arrive from Shuggie Otis, one of the more enigmatic figures in pop music history. The album, “Wings of Love” (Epic/Legacy), with 14 previously unreleased tracks, is being packaged alongside a reissue of his previous and most celebrated recording, “Inspiration Information,” from 1974.

headline: Common Core Practice | Pseudo-Academia, ‘Accidental Racist’ and Broadcasts in Latin
abstract: This week, our collaborators in New Jersey got playful with both their Times choices and the writing activities they suggest for them.
lead_paragraph: This week, our collaborators in New Jersey got playful with both their Times choices and the writing activities they suggest for them.

headline: Popcast: ‘Accidental Racist’ and the Possible Value of a Flawed Song
abstract: The New York Times Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow talks to Ben Ratliff about Brad Paisley’s controversial new song, “Accidental Racist.”
lead_paragraph: This week, the New York Times Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow talks to the host Ben Ratliff about Brad Paisley’s controversial new song, “Accidental Racist,” in which the central character — a white southerner — walks into a Starbucks and experiences a moment of clarity, or something like that, regarding the Confederate flag T-shirt he’s wearing. (LL Cool J plays the barista and de facto spirit guide.)

headline: Wheelies: The Fantasy Electric Truck Edition
abstract: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, is busy wrangling with the Texas Auto Dealers Association, and IndyCar comes back to the Pocono Raceway.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Growing Up on a Musical Diet of Presley and Blondie
abstract: Hayley Williams of the group Paramore says her influences include Debbie Harry of Blondie and Elvis Presley.
lead_paragraph: The Tennessee pop-punk band Paramore, fronted by Hayley Williams, is attempting a reintroduction. It has to. Its self-titled fourth album, just released on Fueled by Ramen, follows two years of turmoil in which the brothers Josh and Zac Farro, the nine-year-old band’s founding guitarist and drummer, quit. On his blog Josh Farro called Paramore “a manufactured product of a major label” and accused Ms. Williams of hogging the spotlight. She stood up for her band and its authenticity on MTV. (Zac Farro later said his brother had regrets about the post.)

headline: America’s Quartermaster
abstract: How Montgomery C. Meigs won the Civil War, one load of supplies at a time.
lead_paragraph: In July 1862, George B. McClellan’s Peninsula Campaign ended and Union forces slowly began their trek back from Virginia’s backwaters, stunned by their losses. But if it was a failure on the battlefield, as a logistical operation, it was a stunning success, one of the great organizational feats of human history, all thanks to one man: Quartermaster General Montgomery C. Meigs.

headline: In the Hytner Era, the National Theater Hit Its Mark
abstract: Starting with “Jerry Springer: The Opera,” Nicholas Hytner has repositioned the three-stage complex as arguably the defining theatrical address in the English-speaking world. And he still has two years to go.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—At last, a date has been named. I’m referring not to the next general election but to a handover to come that may loom larger in the minds of culturally minded Britons. Nicholas Hytner has announced that he will step down at the end of March 2015 as artistic director of the National Theater, a position he has filled with considerable glory since 2003, over time repositioning the primacy of the three-auditorium complex as arguably the defining theatrical address in the English-speaking world.

headline: A Coffee Deal for the Long Haul
abstract: Joh. A Benckiser of Germany is paying a rich price for its latest coffee acquisition, but rivals may be in for a jolt.
lead_paragraph: Bart Becht’s $10 billion coffee run has a dash of Warren E. Buffett about it.

headline: U.S. Penalizes Russians for Human Rights Violations
keywords: ['Jackson-Vanik Amendment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The Obama administration imposed sanctions on about two dozen Russians under a new law that has soured ties with Moscow, but avoided targeting many high-level government figures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States imposed new sanctions Friday on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, and Moscow vowed to retaliate as a fractious dispute between the two countries escalated further into a cold war-style, tit-for-tat clash.

headline: Rare Bay Psalm Book Goes on View at Sotheby’s
abstract: One of eleven surviving copies of the first book printed in what is now the United States is expected to fetch more than $15 million at auction.
lead_paragraph: One of eleven surviving copies of the Bay Psalm Book — the first book printed in what is now the United States, and one of the world’s most valuable books — will be on public view from Friday until Sunday at Sotheby’s in New York, in advance of a November auction where the book is expected to fetch more than $15 million.

headline: Interim M.T.A. Leader Picked to Be Its Chief
abstract: Thomas F. Prendergast is the governor’s nominee to be chairman and chief executive of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, succeeding Joseph J. Lhota, who resigned to run for mayor.
lead_paragraph: More than three months ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority lost its chairman, Joseph J. Lhota, to a mayoral run buoyed by the subway system’s rapid recovery after Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “American Meat,” about the meat production industry, will open Friday at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street in Greenwich Village. There will be a panel discussion after the film. Tickets are $11 per person, and Chipotle Mexican Grill, one of the sponsors of the premiere, will hand out a free gift after the screening and at other showings over the weekend.

headline: As You Watch, Invasion of the Platforms
abstract: Transmedia, a marriage of narrative and new technology, gets its nod in programming like “A Journal of Insomnia” at the Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to “A Journal of Insomnia,” part of the Storyscapes section of the forthcoming Tribeca Film Festival, will set up an appointment and, at the agreed-upon hour, receive a phone call. They will then presumably stumble sleepless to their computers, click on the “Insomnia” Web site and interact with one of four characters featured in the festival’s foray into transmedia: the crazy-quilt crossroads of new technology, uncertain expectations and audience participation.

headline: Food’s Newest, Chicest Magazine: Cherry Bombe
abstract: Inside the biannual publication’s first edition, starring Karlie Kloss on the cover.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Florida; North Adams, Mass.
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Solid Sound Festival, North Adams, Mass. After a one-year hiatus, this music festival, curated by and featuring the band Wilco (above), returns to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (MASS MoCA) from June 21 to 23. Throughout the museum’s 19th-century factory buildings and across its expansive lawns, about two dozen acts, including bands like Yo La Tengo and Neko Case and comedians like Jen Kirkman, will perform. A part of North Adams’s downtown will be open for camping, and $80 round-trip bus transportation is available from New York and Boston.

headline: Full Circle, Almost, for Real Sociedad
abstract: Real Sociedad is on pace to return to the Champions League next year, completing a 10-year circle that saw them relegated from La Liga.
lead_paragraph: Fans at Anoeta saw six goals last Saturday. Two were scored by Malaga, a quarterfinalist in this season’s Champions League, but it was the four that were scored by Real Sociedad that will add to the growing sense of belief that echoes around San Sebastián these days.

headline: Mets Find Out They Won’t Have a Snow Day
abstract: The Twins announced Friday afternoon that their game with the Mets on Friday night would be played despite wintry weather in the area.
lead_paragraph: 3:08 p.m. | Updated A Twins spokesman said Friday night’s game is on. The club is offering free coffee and hot chocolate at the Target Field gates to anyone hardy enough to show up.

headline: Jonathan Winters, Unpredictable Comic and Master of Improvisation, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Winters shone as a guest on TV talk shows and kept audiences in stitches with characters like Maude Frickert, a sweet-seeming grandmother with a barbed tongue.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Winters, the rubber-faced comedian whose unscripted flights of fancy inspired a generation of improvisational comics, and who kept television audiences in stitches with Main Street characters like Maude Frickert, a sweet-seeming grandmother with a barbed tongue and a roving eye, died on Thursday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Guilt by Slippery Slope
abstract: One thing you have to love about the debate over gun control is the lack of inhibition.
lead_paragraph: One thing you have to love about the debate over gun control is the lack of inhibition. The anti-gun-control side seems especially willing to say ridiculous things, but their opponents aren’t shy, either.

headline: A Grand Paean to Royalty
abstract: An eighth-floor apartment opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art is dominated by a Versailles-style grand salon.
lead_paragraph: A fancifully renovated floor-through apartment dominated by a Versailles-style salon with a coffered 18-foot-high ceiling decorated with Fabergé-egg intricacy and a 40-foot-long wall of windows opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art is entering the market for the first time in nearly 40 years. The all-cash asking price for the five-bedroom four-bath co-op, which also has two powder rooms, four marble fireplaces, and a staff suite, is $25 million; the monthly maintenance is $9,750.

headline: Chocolate-Crusted Banana Blondies
abstract: Tired of banana bread and banana muffins? Melissa Clark presents another sweet option for ripe bananas.
lead_paragraph: Tired of banana bread and banana muffins? Melissa Clark presents another sweet option for ripe bananas.

headline: Cracking the Walnut
abstract: I routinely throw them into salads of all kinds, and finely chopped walnuts can go into everything from omelets to pungent Mediterranean nut-based sauces to soups, pasta dishes and of course desserts, writes Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: Nuts can add lots of flavor and crunch to your favorite dishes, and they just happen to be good for you. In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman celebrates the versatility of the walnut. As she writes:

headline: The Week in Food
abstract: From honey laundering to bacon condoms, your week in food news.
lead_paragraph: Lots of meat news: More evidence linking red meat consumption to heart disease: Researchers have found that bacteria in the human gut converts a nutrient common in beef into a compound that might quicken the build up of plaques in the arteries. (Just in time, Bill Gates has a new site promoting plant-based food companies like Hampton Creek Foods and Beyond Meat.)

headline: One Man, Saved From Invisibility
abstract: A lingering visit with a gay black hustler, Shirley Clarke’s nonfiction “Portrait of Jason” (1967), has been reissued.
lead_paragraph: “What do you do for a living, Jason?”

headline: A Muslim College Mixes Subjects to Achieve an American Feel
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'Muslim-Americans']
abstract: At Zaytuna College in California, the Greeks, the scholastics and the whole Western tradition are being taught alongside the Koran.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — I was a bit late for my meeting last week with 19-year-old Mussab Abouabdalla, who I hoped would explain to me why anyone would attend Zaytuna College, an unaccredited three-year-old Muslim institution with about 30 students and not even 10 professors. I found Mr. Abouabdalla at Caffe Strada. He had arranged his books on the table as if to answer my question.

headline: Without the Fudge, Blondies Have More Fun
abstract: Dark rum, ripe banana, butterscotch and a touch of sea salt. Go forth and bake these chocolate banana blondie bars.
lead_paragraph: When I imagined a pan full of chocolate banana blondie bars, I could see exactly what I wanted. A bittersweet bottom crowned with a brown-butter, rum-scented, banana-imbued butterscotch blondie. Two distinct layers and a complex set of flavors harmonizing in every gooey bite.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Thank You, Roger Ebert
abstract: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott reflect on the life of Roger Ebert, the brand he created, and the effect he had on Mr. Scott’s beginnings as a film critic.

lead_paragraph: The world of big law has been buzzing with talk about billing, especially after a client of DLA Piper accused the giant law firm of inflating bills through overstaffing and  performing unnecessary work.

headline: Chávez’s Lasting Impact
abstract: Even in death, the former leader Hugo Chávez plays an omnipresent role in Venezuela’s presidential campaigns as voters prepare to elect their new leader on Sunday.

abstract: Wedding gowns need to be treated like people, with proper cleaning and room to breathe.
lead_paragraph: Basement, attic or back of closet: those three storage options, though commonly chosen, are not the best for brides hoping to save their wedding gown for the next generation.

headline: J.C. Penney Wins Ruling in Dispute With Macy’s
abstract: A judge says the retailer can at least temporarily sell housewares designed by Martha Stewart under the JCP Everyday label.
lead_paragraph: With Ron Johnson out, Martha Stewart is in at J. C. Penney, at least for the moment.

headline: A Dad’s Hidden Truth of Parenting: We’re All Clichés
abstract: I thought being a blogging dad made me a rare man willing to share his frustrations — until I realized they’re frustrations we all share.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, a new wave seems to be washing over the world: a wave of bellyaching fathers complaining about how hard it is to be a parent. There is nothing particularly original about these complaints. In fact, as in most things, women were here first. But when it comes to whining, we men are better at it, or at least much, much louder.

headline: Maria Tallchief, a Dazzling Ballerina and Muse for Balanchine, Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Tallchief achieved renown as an early prima ballerina with the New York City Ballet, dancing for George Balanchine and entertaining audiences with her speed, energy and fire.
lead_paragraph: Maria Tallchief, a daughter of an Oklahoma oil family who grew up on an Indian reservation, found her way to New York and became one of the most brilliant American ballerinas of the 20th century, died on Thursday in Chicago. She was 88.

headline: Fewer Americans Lose Jobs, but Hiring Is Also Down
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Data from the Labor Department may help explain why long-term unemployment persists.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN workers are being fired or laid off less often than at any time in the last decade, the government reported this week. But companies are also less willing to hire than they used to be.

headline: To Celebrate a Landmarks Law, Planting Flags in a Tiny New York
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: As part of a project to highlight the 50th anniversary of a landmarks law, 109 yellow flags will mark the city’s historic districts on the Queens Museum of Art’s Panorama.
lead_paragraph: David Grainger is walking on the water again. One foot is upstream from the Manhattan Bridge and the other foot is downstream from the Williamsburg Bridge, and he is reaching over the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to plant a yellow flag at the intersection of Pierrepont Street and Hicks Street in Brooklyn Heights.

headline: DNA Project Aims to Make Public a Company’s Data on Cancer Genes
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Breast Cancer', 'Inventions and Patents', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: Researchers are asking cancer clinics to hand over Myriad Genetics’ test results so they can more easily interpret the risk posed by mutations of two breast cancer genes.
lead_paragraph: Anyone in the United States who wants to know if she has mutations in two breast cancer genes has little choice of where to be tested. One company alone has patents on the genes, and that company pretty much controls the market.

headline: Looking for Love and Lobster Salad
abstract: A couple meets in the kitchen at a children’s birthday party, 2 states and 178 miles from home.
lead_paragraph: About the last place on earth a single person with no children would expect to meet someone is at a children’s birthday party 2 states and 178 miles from home. Then again, if by chance two single people should be at such an event, they would certainly stand out in the crowd.

headline: Jettisoning a Few Extra Square Feet
abstract: Alyse Booth and Steve Lefkowitz decided to downsize, and while they were at it, move to Manhattan from Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five years ago, Alyse Booth and Steve Lefkowitz bought a second home in the Berkshires, a house near a pond on four wooded acres.

headline: Immigration Compromise Leaves Out Many
abstract: The Times’s Ashley Parker on why a plan that offers a path to citizenship is a win for Senator Marco Rubio but a loss for illegal immigrants who’ve only recently arrived.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Ashley Parker on why a plan that offers a path to citizenship is a win for Senator Marco Rubio but a loss for illegal immigrants who’ve only recently arrived.

headline: Now Listening | Ra Ra Riot, ‘All I Fear’
abstract: An indie rock group with ties to old-fashioned means of music discovery, releases a limited-edition 10-inch vinyl.
lead_paragraph: The indie rock outfit Ra Ra Riot is no stranger to old-fashioned means of music discovery. After all, the group, which first cut its chops playing house parties at Syracuse University, gained notoriety only after putting in stints at CMJ and South by Southwest and garnering positive reviews for its tireless live shows. It’s fitting, then, that the band — made up of Wes Miles on vocals, Rebecca Zeller on violin, Mathieu Santos on bass and Milo Bonacci on guitar — should be fans of Record Store Day.

headline: In France, Where Brunch Is Au Courant
abstract: Everything at Miss Terroir bore a hand-made pride of place, distinct in flavor and redolent of origins. It was as far from clichéd brunch fare as I could imagine.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I darted over to Paris for a long weekend to visit our 21-year-old son, Peter, who is spending the semester studying abroad and absorbing the numerous cultural pleasures that Europe has to offer. Unexpectedly among those pleasures, he said, Parisians are currently obsessed with brunch, a bane of the New York food-obsessed, who writhe in agony over the popular banality of bad eggs Benedict and dreadful Bloody Marys.
