headline: New York City Unveils Parking App Pilot Program
abstract: Parking on New York City streets can be frustrating, but the city Transportation Department will try to alleviate the problem using a smartphone app.
lead_paragraph: New York City passed a major milestone this week, introducing a new app that helps motorists find and pay for parking using a smartphone. The pilot program for the app will be near Fordham University in the Bronx and will include 264 parking spaces along nine blocks.

headline: What Happens if You Don’t Pay Your Taxes
abstract: There are lots of nonmonetary penalties, like being denied a hunting or medical license or having your driver’s license suspended.
lead_paragraph: People who commit tax fraud can face big fines and even imprisonment. Just ask the recently released Wesley Snipes, who had served most of a three-year sentence for not filing his taxes. The timing of his release, just ahead of the tax filing deadline, may not have been an accident; the Internal Revenue Service appears to ramp up publicity of its tax fraud cases right before April 15, a 2010 study found.

headline: Big Ticket | A Reconfigured Aerie, Sold for $16.25 Million

abstract: First, an early-April hot spell, and now, freezing winds and rain. What do you suppose is going on here?
lead_paragraph: What is it with this weather? A warm January, a chilly start to spring, an early-April hot spell complete with brush-fire outbreaks, and now, freezing winds driving the rain into the sockets of your skull.

headline: Are You Ready for Some Futebol?
abstract: Soccer is not just a game in Brazil, it’s a national drama. Here’s a script to help you join the show.
lead_paragraph: The banner-waving, anthem-singing fans of Rio de Janeiro’s Flamengo club formed a billowing mass of ruby-and — black-clad humanity. They moved not only in reaction to the ebbs and flows on the field far below, but also to the samba beat pounded out by musicians in the midst of the grandstand mayhem around me and my friend Doug. The bands had not stopped playing, and fans had not stopped chanting, in the 18 minutes since the game began.

headline: In Mexico, Where the Waves Still Win
abstract: Worried that sleepy Troncones might be shedding some of its authenticity to go chic, the author returns to her favorite beach and faces her fears.
lead_paragraph: Planning a return trip to my favorite beach in the world, I was almost as apprehensive as I was excited. The last time I visited Troncones — a town of some 600 people pushed up against the Sierra Madre del Sur mountains on the Pacific coast of Mexico — was five years earlier. At the time, we’d been living in San Miguel de Allende, and we occasionally drove down with our two sons and two dogs. My husband — an avowed “non-beach guy” — and I had come to love this village of farmers and fishermen for its rawness, its drowsy authenticity.

lead_paragraph: A FEW TIMES A YEAR, Nick Pologeorgis leaves his family’s business on West 29th Street to attend the fur auctions in Toronto, Seattle and St. Petersburg, the home of the Russian sable market. His father, Stanley, started Pologeorgis Furs in 1960; after Nick graduated from Boston University in 1984 with a degree in finance, he joined the firm. His sister, Joan, works on the production side. Lately, if there’s one thing Mr. Pologeorgis has noticed at the auctions, aside from rising prices (they have doubled in the last three years), it’s the number of Chinese bidders. No doubt the two are connected.

At 14, he was playing with the game and the poise of a player twice his age. But on Friday, Guan was punished for dawdling, with a one-stroke penalty for slow play after the 17th hole of his second round at Augusta National Golf Club.

lead_paragraph: When Louis C. K. walks onto a stage in Phoenix at the beginning of “Louis C. K.: Oh My God,” his new HBO stand-up special, and responds to the crowd’s applause with what feels like a practiced bit of false modesty — “I don’t necessarily agree with you but I appreciate it very much” — it’s the only moment that feels inauthentic in the hourlong show. If he didn’t agree with the audience, would he have been doing this for more than a quarter-century?

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers:  Scott Snyder’s  ‘American Vampire’
abstract: This week, Volume 5 of “American Vampire,” about a new breed of bloodsucker, enters the list at No. 2.
lead_paragraph: The writer Scott Snyder seems to be making a home out of our hardcover list. This week, Volume 5 of “American Vampire,” about a new breed of bloodsucker, enters the list at No. 2. (He is also the writer behind the Batman stories at No. 1 and No. 8.) In this latest installment of “American Vampire,” Mr. Snyder has been blessed with two gifted collaborators: Rafael Albuquerque, the original series artist, and Dustin Nguyen, who illustrates a spin-off story included in this collection. Though vampires have seemingly given up their number one status in pop culture to zombies, Mr. Snyder proves there are still plenty of tales to tell about these creatures of the night. Mr. Nguyen lends his wonderfully expressive and moody art to an adventure involving the hunt for the granddaddy of all vampires, Dracula, while Mr. Albuquerque illustrates the exploration of all things related to Skinner Sweet, the first American vampire, who is more vicious and less bothered by sunlight. The only drawback to reading this book in collected form is that the reader does not get to long savor the cliffhangers with which Mr. Snyder ends most issues. (Click here for a profile on Mr. Snyder from Sept. 2011.)

headline: Adam Smith Hates Bitcoin
abstract: Blazing a high-tech path to the 17th century.
lead_paragraph: There have been many good pieces written on the dubious economics of Bitcoin; I especially liked this one by Neil Irwin. One thing I haven’t seen emphasized, however, is the extent to which the whole concept of having to “mine” Bitcoins by expending real resources amounts to a drastic retrogression — a retrogression that Adam Smith would have scorned.

headline: Someone’s Ruffled Her Feathers, and She’s in Perpetual Motion
abstract: The choreographer Milka Djordjevich is performing her solo “Kinetic Makeover” at the Chocolate Factory.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “Kinetic Makeover,” the choreographer Milka Djordjevich stands with her back to the audience. She stands there a long time, in silence, dressed in a pink and blue top and tight sherbet-orange pants (designed by Reid Bartelme). Almost imperceptibly, she begins to sway side to side. Gradually, the swaying swells, her knees bending, her torso pitching, until she has rocked herself onto the floor in a seated position and turned her face front. . Her eyes continue to ticktock, left, right, left.

headline: Two, Three Essays? More Can Mean Less

lead_paragraph: DURING a staff retreat last winter, Boston College’s admissions officers decided something had to change. Between 2004 and 2011, the college’s yield — the proportion of accepted students who enroll — had declined from 32 percent to 23 percent. Some applicants, says John L. Mahoney, director of undergraduate admissions, “probably weren’t very serious about us all along.”

headline: A Savory Taste of the Pampas
abstract: Gaucho Grill, an Argentine steakhouse with Italian flair, is elegant without being trendy or self-conscious.
lead_paragraph: The first empanada I ever had was made by an Argentine friend in college. That country’s version of the small South American meat patty features a substantial beef filling tucked into a flaky shell, and it was love at first bite. I’ve had dozens and dozens of empanadas since, made in almost as many styles, but it was the one from Gaucho Grill, an Argentine restaurant that opened in White Plains last year, that gave me the biggest thrill since my first.

headline: Bonhomie, Even if They Don’t Know Your Name
abstract: Once a scruffy bar, the River Grille, in Chatham, has changed its mood and menu under new owners.
lead_paragraph: When he was a boy, back in the 1970s, Michael Pryer often accompanied his father to a bar called Flynn’s, in Chatham. Over the years, he mused about turning the scruffy bar into a place where customers could order more than just a liverwurst or Taylor ham, egg and cheese sandwich — the only items the kitchen served back then, Mr. Pryer, 47, recalled over the telephone after my visits.

headline: The Taste Divide
abstract: In this issue we feature images that we hope open your eyes to new ideas of taste and beauty as they have ours.
lead_paragraph: How does an actress design her image? In our celebrity-obsessed culture, she usually dresses in the very latest fashion and has her photographs airbrushed into superhuman oblivion. Julianne Moore, while she indeed looks ravishing in films and on the red carpet, and even in her sweatpants at morning drop off (where I see her from time to time as our children attend the same school), is not such an actress. She is someone who rather pushes the boundaries in her acting in order to inhabit the characters she plays. For this issue she collaborated with the photographers Inez and Vinoodh and the makeup wizard Peter Philips, all artists in their own right, who seek to extend our way of seeing. Here they show us a more real, and even exaggerated side of Moore’s natural beauty. Freckled from birth (and not in a cute way, she explains in the piece), Moore’s face was sprinkled by Philips with even more spots. The resulting image, unlike most cover shots, isn’t retouched to perfection. The power comes from Moore’s striking and honest intensity, and from her scarcely made-up face, remarkable and beautiful at age 52.

headline: A Chat With Raj Chetty, Clark Medalist

lead_paragraph: This afternoon, we caught up with Raj Chetty, the 33-year-old Harvard economist who is the latest winner of the John Bates Clark Medal, a prestigious award for economists under the age of 40. Mr. Chetty is a public economist whose work has addressed topics including the returns from education, tax policies and savings behavior, often by parsing huge troves of data. This interview was lightly edited for clarity.

abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry travels through Asia with no sign that he has found a real solution.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry sent several important messages to North Korea after talks on Friday in Seoul with South Korean leaders. Speaking at a news conference, he said that the United States would defend its South Korean and Japanese allies if there was conflict, that the international community would never accept the North as a nuclear weapons state, and that Washington was willing to resume long-stalled negotiations but only if the North Koreans agreed to move seriously on denuclearization.

headline: A Box of Sheep
abstract: With the purchase of the fleece, an old prejudice ebbs.
lead_paragraph: This week, a sheep arrived in a box. Not the whole sheep, which is still, I hope, grazing happily in a pasture somewhere in northeast Washington State. Only its fleece. I’ve raised many animals but never sheep. My dad, who raised them as a farm boy, left me with a vicious prejudice against them, and the only sheep I saw as a boy did nothing to counter it. They stood — a dim, ghostly flock — in a grove they had denuded entirely of grass and undergrowth. It occurs to me now that this was the fault of the farmer, not of the sheep, who have no more interest in eating bare dirt than I do.

headline: The Île à Vache: From Hope to Disaster
abstract: A plan to colonize recently freed slaves on an island near Haiti goes terribly awry.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s massive Fortress Monroe, operating under Union control from the beginning of the war, played witness to an unusual sight on the morning of April 14, 1863. The brig’s main cargo, however, consisted of passengers — specifically 453 recently freed African-Americans — about to set sail for a new life in Haiti.

abstract: A day after a Bronx judge freed David Bryant, who had been convicted in the death of an 8-year-old girl, the girl’s family was just starting to process what had happened.
lead_paragraph: The last time Walter J. Smith saw his little sister Karen alive, on a warm spring day, March 28, 1975, she was on her way to the corner store to buy a 100 Grand candy bar. Hours later, at 1:50 a.m., her body was found in a darkened 16th-floor stairwell of the South Bronx housing project where she lived. headline: Germany: Former President Wulff Charged
abstract: German prosecutors charged former President Christian Wulff with corruption on Friday, more than a year after he quit amid accusations that he had accepted favors from business executives before becoming president.
lead_paragraph: German prosecutors charged former President Christian Wulff with corruption on Friday, more than a year after he quit amid accusations that he had accepted favors from business executives before becoming president. Mr. Wulff, 53, was picked by Chancellor Angela Merkel in 2010 for the largely ceremonial post. He quit 20 months later after the revelations about vacations with rich friends and favors and gifts that he had accepted earlier in his political career. On Friday, prosecutors in Hanover accused Mr. Wulff of allowing a movie producer to pay for a family vacation in 2008, while Mr. Wulff was governor of Lower Saxony. In exchange, prosecutors said, Mr. Wulff lobbied the engineering giant Siemens to help promote one of the producer’s films. Mr. Wulff, who denies the allegations, rejected an offer to settle the case by paying a fine.

lead_paragraph: IF this column were a TV show, what kind of TV show would it be? The Haggler is thinking dark comedy, laugh track optional. But sometimes the material here feels more like the stuff of farce. Laugh till you cry farce. As it does with the continuing Whirlpool ordeal experienced by Shira London, who e-mailed an update last week.

headline: Medical Care, Aided by the Crowd
keywords: ['Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Philanthropy', 'Microfinance', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Watsi, a start-up founded by a former Peace Corps volunteer, is using crowdfunding to provide health care to patients in third-world countries.
lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, Chase Adam, a Peace Corps volunteer in Costa Rica, was riding a bus through a town called Watsi, when a woman got on board asking for money. Her son, she said, needed medical attention and she couldn’t pay for it. As the woman walked through the bus, she showed people a copy of her son’s medical record. Mr. Adam, who is now 26, noticed that nearly everyone donated money.

headline: North Korea Threatens Colorado City, Inaccurately
abstract: A video released on a North Korean government Web site shows the nation targeting nuclear weapons at a Colorado city. But a map shown places the city in the vicinity of Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: North Korea, which seemed to be running out of tubs to thump, found a new target for its ire in a propaganda video released Saturday on Uriminzokkiri, a government Web site.

headline: Conduct at Issue as Military Officers Face a New Review
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)']
abstract: The American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by the people they command on qualities including character.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a series of scandals involving high-ranking officers, the American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by their peers and the people they command on qualities including personal character.

headline: A Viewer’s Guide to the Mayoral Candidates
abstract: Seeking the New York City mayor’s office are seven Democrats, three Republicans and one candidate on the Independence Party’s ballot.
lead_paragraph: Seeking the New York City mayor’s office are seven Democrats, three Republicans and one candidate on the Independence Party’s ballot.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 14
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio will appear on seven shows this Sunday, talking about what’s ahead for the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio visits seven programs this Sunday, talking about immigration as he and the rest of a bipartisan group of eight senators prepare to release a proposal to overhaul the system. The Florida Republican will appear on the five major Sunday shows, as well as the programs on Telemundo and Univision.

headline: Basketball’s Renegade Spirit
abstract: Today’s A.B.A., a basketball league that is not particularly professional, shares little with the original other than the name, the ball and a renegade spirit.
lead_paragraph: Today’s A.B.A., a basketball league that is not particularly professional, shares little with the original other than the name, the ball and a renegade spirit.

headline: DNWR in the EA
abstract: Wages are hard to cut.
lead_paragraph: That’s downward nominal wage rigidity in the euro area (and actually in neighboring countries too). I’ve been talking about DNWR in the US context, but it’s a much bigger issue in Europe, where the whole adjustment strategy relies on “internal devaluation”: countries that experienced large capital inflows during the period 2000-2007 are supposed to regain competitiveness by cutting costs, and that’s really hard if nominal wages have to come down.

headline: ‘My Treat’
abstract: Best. Puzzle. Ever. By Elizabeth C. Gorski, of course.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh my, I loved this puzzle. Your mileage may vary. But as far as I’m concerned, the only thing that would have made this puzzle better is if we had some sort of technology here at The New York Times that would make the puzzle lickable. Maybe scratch ‘n’ sniff, as a second choice. But definitely lickable.

headline: Robert Byrne, Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Byrne analyzed top-flight matches and wrote a chess column for The New York Times from 1972 to 2006.
lead_paragraph: Robert Byrne, an international grandmaster and United States chess champion who, as the chess columnist for The New York Times, analyzed top-flight matches from 1972 through 2006, the eras of Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov, died on Friday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: Coachella: A Few Sparks of Creative Rock
keywords: ['Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Rock Music']
abstract: A suite of young American bands tried to find a path out of the current American rock scene.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — American rock music might get a bad rap, but its cancer begins from within. Major labels have all but tabled creative ambition, meaning that even bona fide indie stars may have to content themselves with being miniscene champions for life. Early on Saturday at Coachella, there was a suite of young American bands trying to find a path out of the darkness.

headline: Obama’s Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Social Security (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicare']
abstract: President Obama’s proposal to trim future Medicare and Social Security benefits as part of a deficit compromise could force Democrats to take an uncomfortable stand on a measure that is unpopular with their base.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whether or not Republicans ever agree to a budget deal with President Obama, one thing seems certain: now that he has officially put Social Security and Medicare benefits on the negotiating table, opponents on his party’s left will make that an issue for Democrats in the midterm elections next year — and perhaps in the 2016 presidential contest.

headline: Shy No More, N.R.A.’s Top Gun Sticks to Cause
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, has honed a no-compromise strategy over the last 35 years that is now facing its most difficult test in decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Victims of the massacre in Newtown, Conn., had just been laid to rest when Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, met with his board of directors in early January. A national tide of grief had prompted new attacks on his group and a White House push for more gun control measures, while Mr. LaPierre — who had called for armed guards in every school — was pilloried as a “gun nut” on the cover of The New York Post.

headline: Mystery Shrouds Rise and Aims of Rebel at Helm of Central African Republic
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Michel Djotodia, a wily opportunist who conducted a coup d’état in the Central African Republic in March, continues to hold the presidency, despite an international outcry.
lead_paragraph: A portly sexagenarian, Michel Djotodia had dressed for his coup d’état, donning desert camouflage, a turban and sandals like those of the rebels in his region of the Central African Republic.

headline: Sierra Leone’s Health Care System Becomes a Cautionary Tale for Donors
abstract: The top leadership of the Health Ministry faces charges of misusing foreign funds, raising alarm in a nation with the region’s worst health statistics.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — The health statistics in this battered land, still scarred from a decade of civil war, are so alarming that for a decade, donors have opened their wallets to help improve some of the world’s worst rates of maternal and infant mortality. This is the third-most dangerous place on earth to have a baby, and one of the most perilous to be a baby.

headline: No Stranger to Scandal, Spitzer Says Weiner ‘Can Come Back’
abstract: As he considers a potential mayoral run in the wake of an online sex scandal, former Congressman Anthony D. Weiner has won a vote of confidence from a politician who can identify with his predicament: Eliot Spitzer.
lead_paragraph: As he considers a potential mayoral run in the wake of an online sex scandal, former Representative Anthony D. Weiner has won a vote of confidence from a politician who can identify with his predicament: Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Brooklyn School Takes Title at the ‘Supernationals’
abstract: Edward R. Murrow High School won its division in the scholastic championships last week, and Webster University of St. Louis was the Final Four of College Chess title winner.
lead_paragraph: Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn won its division at the “Supernationals” scholastic championships in Nashville last weekend.

headline: Morneau’s Homer Ruins No-Hit Bid, but Mets’ Harvey Stays Dominant
abstract: Matt Harvey continued his sensational start to the season, taking a no-hit bid into the seventh inning as the Mets beat the Twins for the second day in a row.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It wasn’t a bad pitch, but it wasn’t the right pitch. Matt Harvey realized that not long after Minnesota’s Justin Morneau swung at an inside slider with two out in the seventh, pulling a home run high off the right-field pole and halting Harvey’s bid for a second Mets no-hitter in two years and his first professional shutout.

headline: Wigan Defeats Millwall in Violence-Marred F.A. Cup Semifinal
abstract: Fighting in the stands at Wembley Stadium in London set back Millwall’s efforts to move away from its reputation for the violent behavior of its supporters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There were two sparkling goals, a typically gray and rainy English day and plenty of pomp, but the lingering image from Saturday’s F.A. Cup semifinal between Millwall and Wigan will be that of a young girl crying.

headline: Early Signs of Parity in A.L. East, Where 90 Wins May Be Enough
abstract: With Toronto and Baltimore stronger this season, the American League East, a division that for the last 12 years has been won by a team with 95 or more victories, could have a champion with only 90 wins.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Orioles unloaded on Phil Hughes on Saturday, hitting him so hard for three innings that Hughes said he could not remember the last time he had pitched so badly. Maybe there were better times to ask Hughes about the strength of the division, times when he could have been more objective. But his perspective seemed to sum up the new reality of the American League East.

headline: On Leader Board Full of Challengers, Top Two Say They Have a Plan
abstract: Brandt Snedeker, a near winner in 2008, and Angel Cabrera, the 2009 Masters champion, shared the lead after the third round at seven under. Tiger Woods was four shots back.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Controversy over Tiger Woods’s two-stroke penalty for hitting from the wrong spot Friday enveloped the Augusta National Golf Club grounds for hours before play began in Saturday’s third round. In the galleries, among the players and in the deliberations of tournament officials, the attention of all conversation was focused on the past, on what Woods did and did not do in the second round.

headline: Hughes Returns to Mound, but Briefly
abstract: The fans booed, early and often, as Yankees pitcher Phil Hughes struggled against the Orioles, who pummeled Hughes for nine hits, including three home runs, and five runs.
lead_paragraph: The grumbling began with a lone fan who had given up on Phil Hughes in the third inning. “Take him out! Take him ouuuuuut!” He was louder with each hard hit. Soon, a few others started to boo. By the fourth, as Hughes walked off the mound with his head bowed after being removed from the game, the crowd was more decided.

headline: Attention, Second-Guessers: Golf Takes Calls (and Texts)
abstract: An illegal ball drop by Tiger Woods was first brought to the attention of Masters officials in a text message, highlighting the unusual relationship between those who enforce the rules and television viewers.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In golf, and almost no other sport, interactive, real-time communication between armchair television viewers and referees supervising the competition routinely changes rulings and alters the outcomes of tournaments. This collaboration of living room second-guessers and rules officials is an almost weekly occurrence. On Saturday, it embroiled the Masters, golf’s biggest event, in a controversy that involved the game’s most celebrated player, Tiger Woods.

headline: China Makes Inroads in Nepal, and Stanches Tibetan Influx
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Buddhism', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Chinese are trying to stem the flow of disaffected Tibetans fleeing to Nepal and to enlist the help of the Nepalese in cracking down on the political activities of those already there.
lead_paragraph: CHOSAR, Nepal — The wind-scoured desert valley here, just south of Tibet, was once a famed transit point for the Tibetan yak caravans laden with salt that lumbered over the icy ramparts of the Himalayas. In the 1960s, it became a base for Tibetan guerrillas trained by the C.I.A. to attack Chinese troops occupying their homeland.

headline: Playoff Race Reanimates Rivalry, and Rangers’ Overtime Goal Electrifies It
abstract: In a game with significant playoff implications for both teams, the Rangers pulled out an overtime victory against the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Nassau Coliseum was rocking the way it used to, decades ago, when J. P. Parise, Denis Potvin and Chico Resch were leading the upstart Islanders against the established Rangers of John Davidson, Phil Esposito and Ron Duguay. Those clashes generally ended with the Islanders on top, but that was not the way Saturday night’s game ended.

lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Three weeks before the Connecticut neighbors Yale and Quinnipiac met on college hockey’s biggest stage, they played on a much smaller one in the ECAC Hockey tournament’s consolation game. Quinnipiac won that day, just as it had in the teams’ two meetings during the regular season.

headline: Judge Rules Against Football Helmet Manufacturer
abstract: Riddell, the country’s largest helmet manufacturer, will pay $3.1 million to a 22-year old man who was injured in 2008 while playing high school football.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Colorado has found that Riddell, the country’s largest helmet manufacturer, was at fault for failure to adequately warn players wearing their football helmets about the dangers of potential concussions.

headline: A ‘Gangnam Style’ Escape From Korean Tensions
abstract: Psy, the Korean pop sensation and creator of “Gangnam Style,” referred to North Korea during his Seoul concert on Saturday, amid some comic comparisons between him and the North Korean leader and some speculation he could be a peacemaker.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — “Psy. I read about this guy named Psy in Korea,” the U.S. secretary of state, John Kerry, said Saturday, addressing Chinese and overseas reporters at a news briefing in Beijing, where he was visiting to discuss the high tensions on the Korean Peninsula, among other things.

headline: Coachella: Rap’s Web-Fueled Misfits
keywords: ['Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: The festival’s lineup of rappers included Action Bronson, Earl Sweatshirt and others who arrived at stardom without the benefit of radio airplay or major-label deals.
lead_paragraph: INDIO, Calif. — At Coachella, everything happens more or less on time, but 2 Chainz was late. His set on Saturday afternoon was meant to start at 4 p.m., but 4:05, 4:10 and 4:15 all passed without sight of him, his band reduced to playing a minute or so of “I’m Different,” which petered out, soon followed by boos.

headline: Wayne LaPierre: Behind the Rhetoric

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jodi Kantor looks at how the National Rifle Association’s Wayne LaPierre has drawn strength from criticism directed at him since the school shooting in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Rebel Flag Flies Over a Province, and Indonesia Wants It Torn Down
abstract: The strife-torn Aceh Province passed a bylaw last month that declared the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the province’s official flag and seal.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian government has given the leaders of strife-torn Aceh Province until Tuesday to annul a bylaw passed last month that declares the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the province’s official flag and seal.

headline: Should You Be Paying Taxes on Your Baby Sitter?
abstract: If you pay a nanny or baby sitter more than $1,800 a year, you are required to be paying employment taxes.
lead_paragraph: If you want to hear a pin drop, ask a room of parents whether they report employment taxes for their baby sitter or nanny. My (admittedly unscientific) conclusion, drawn from four years of Manhattan motherhood, is that many families do not. In a 2011 discussion of nanny compensation on Park Slope Parents, most families reported paying their caregivers completely off the books, while very few said they paid the tax. Susan Fox, founder of Park Slope Parents, suspects the off-the-books number among her readers is well over half.

headline: A Purveyor of Brie, Prosciutto and Anthems
abstract: Patrick Watson, a Brooklyn cheesemonger and trained opera singer, is getting ready to sing the national anthem at the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Thirty minutes before Stinky Bklyn opens for business, its proprietor strolls the floor singing in a powerhouse tenor to Parmigiano-Reggiano and hickory-smoked Benton’s bacon. He is not being a ham. Patrick Watson is getting his pipes in shape to sing the national anthem at the Barclays Center, where he is better known as the supplier of Stinky Brown Butter Rice Krispy Treats and the crumbled blue cheese topping on the Nathan’s Famous hot dogs sold at the concession stand.

headline: Highlights and Analysis From Masters
abstract: Adam Scott of Australia won his first green jacket on the second playoff hole at the 77th Masters. Times reporters provide updates and analysis.
lead_paragraph: Adam Scott, 32, became the first Australian to win the Masters, defeating Angel Cabrera of Argentina in the second hole of the sudden-death playoff Sunday.

headline: Top Brass, Low Key
abstract: The trumpet soloist Alison Balsom, who will perform on Sunday at Town Hall with the Scottish Ensemble, talks about the challenges in a field with limited repertory.
lead_paragraph: She is only 34, but there is already a statue of the glamorous trumpeter Alison Balsom standing in her hometown, Royston, England, where she grew up playing in a brass band.

headline: Rubio Offers Full-Throated Support for Immigration Bill
abstract: Legislation that would overhaul the country’s immigration system received a forceful endorsement from Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who after holding back for weeks appeared on seven talk shows to voice his support.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio offered an extraordinary endorsement of legislation to overhaul the nation’s badly strained immigration system on Sunday when, after holding back for weeks, he appeared on no fewer than seven television talk shows to explain and defend a plan that he said would be “a net positive for the country, now and in the future.”

headline: Jackie Robinson Movie Has Strong Opening
abstract: ’42,’ a baseball biopic, was a strong No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in about $27.3 million over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood was predictably shocked over the weekend to find that a well-reviewed drama succeeded at the box office even though it was aimed at geriatric moviegoers (industry definition: anyone over the age of 25). The Jackie Robinson biopic “42” was a strong No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in about $27.3 million, according to its distributor, Warner Brothers. Legendary Entertainment spent a relatively modest $38 million to make the film, which performed best among older men, the hardest demographic for studios to reach.

headline: Rat Kidneys Made in Lab Point to Aid for Humans
abstract: Researchers said that while creating functional kidneys for people was a long way off, replacement organs made like the rat kidneys would have benefits over other methods.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston have made functioning rat kidneys in the laboratory, a bioengineering achievement that may one day lead to the ability to create replacement organs for people with kidney disease.

headline: For Manchester City, F.A. Cup Final Offers a Consolation Prize
abstract: The victory sent Manchester City into the Cup final against Wigan and perhaps gave some job security to City Manager Roberto Mancini.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Saturday, there was ugliness at Wembley, as the bloodied faces of a group of Millwall fans — who pummeled one another, and the police, in the stands in a grim episode of in-game violence — overshadowed Wigan’s victory in an F.A. Cup semifinal. On Sunday, the lasting image of the second semifinal at England’s national stadium was more idyllic: a sea of light blue Manchester City fans, moving in unison as they danced, cheered and whipped their scarves around in giddy celebration of a thrilling 2-1 win over Chelsea.

headline: Students Face Tougher Tests That Outpace Lesson Plans
abstract: New York City public school students are undergoing rigorous preparation for the redesigned exams, which are likely to cover some material that is not yet in the curriculum.
lead_paragraph: At Public School 10 on the edge of Park Slope, Brooklyn, parents begged the principal to postpone the lower school science fair, insisting it was going to add too much pressure while they were preparing their children for the coming state tests.

headline: Kerry Says North Korea Talks Are Possible, but Hints at Conditions
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said that the United States was prepared to reach out if North Korea made the first move to abandon its nuclear weapons program.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday that the United States was prepared to reach out to Kim Jong-un of North Korea if he made the first move to abandon his nuclear weapons program.

headline: Centerpiece of Gun Bill Remains in Doubt
abstract: The Senate could vote as early as Tuesday on expanded background checks for gun buyers — a centerpiece of broad gun legislation — but leading lawmakers said Sunday that approval of the measure remained uncertain.
lead_paragraph: The Senate could vote as early as Tuesday on expanded background checks for gun buyers — a centerpiece of broad gun legislation — but leading lawmakers said Sunday that approval of the measure remained uncertain.

headline: For One Royal, History Has Added Insult to Injury
abstract: In her new book, “The Creation of Anne Boleyn,” Susan Bordo seeks to dispel the “sedimented mythology” about Boleyn, the ill-fated second wife of Henry VIII.
lead_paragraph: In February, when the British novelist Hilary Mantel delivered a lecture describing the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, as a “plastic” princess “designed by a committee and built by craftsmen,” the response was swift and in some quarters furious. Prime Minister David Cameron dismissed the remarks as “completely misguided and completely wrong.” The Daily Mail denounced them as a “venomous attack.”

lead_paragraph: A scene from Tanya Barfield's play, a co-production between Playwrights Horizons and Primary Stages.

headline: End of Palestinian Power Play Muddles the Peace Process
abstract: The resignation of the Palestinian Authority’s prime minister, Salam Fayyad, adds a layer of confusion to the already contentious Palestinian political scene.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Salam Fayyad, the internationally respected Palestinian politician and economist, is widely credited with ending the chaos in the West Bank and putting things in order in his six years as prime minister. But his resignation over the weekend, the result of internal power struggles, has left the Palestinian Authority suspended in political ambiguity and confusion.

headline: Mets and Twins Postpone Series Finale as Snow and Temperature Fall
abstract: With snow pelting the field by 10:40 a.m. and a temperature of 32, the Twins called off Sunday afternoon’s game with the Mets.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Most of the Mets never made it to Target Field from their hotel on Sunday morning.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum Has More Time
abstract: The Museum of the City of New York has agreed to continue running the museum for another three months.
lead_paragraph: Although the South Street Seaport Museum has yet to recover from Hurricane Sandy, the Museum of the City of New York has agreed to continue running the museum for another three months.

lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Flaws Seen in Protection of Animals on the Set
abstract: Guidelines for animal safety on film sets exist, but after the recent death of a shark on the set of a Kmart commercial, some question the American Humane Association’s financial ties to the industry.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a film set, even the bugs bite by the book.

lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Quirks and All, a Group Welcomes a Playmate
abstract: The jazz trio Bad Plus collaborated with the guitarist Bill Frisell at the Allen Room on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: The Bad Plus is an odd bird. The three members of this trio individually lean on specific languages of jazz improvisation, but collectively the band hesitates to get close to any single tradition. It likes to build a crescendo past the point of comfort, or move extremely slowly, or structure a kind of pop song with irresolutions and gravitational tempo shifts and wild staggers, or pump stiff grandiosity into something simple and scratchy. It plays, a little perversely, with putting on a hard shell. It exaggerates with a straight face and builds self-contained events within themselves rather than partial re-enactments of an open-ended story, which is what most jazz is.

headline: Wallace Appears Close to Returning and Reminding Fans He Still Plays for Knicks
abstract: Once thought to be lost for the season, Rasheed Wallace is ahead of schedule in his recovery from foot surgery.
lead_paragraph: Rasheed Wallace, the Knicks veteran with the scruffy beard, has been on the court before games for the last month practicing his jumper, mostly from behind the 3-point line. He may get the chance to do it in a situation that counts when the Knicks visit the Charlotte Bobcats on Monday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Company Reports']
abstract: Reports include quarterly earnings from Microsoft, PepsiCo and Bank of America, as well as housing starts and leading economic indicators for March.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the Consumer Price Index, housing starts and industrial production for March (Tuesday); the Federal Reserve’s beige book (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims and leading economic indicators for March (Thursday).

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in St. Louis
abstract: A look at the most surprising result during the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams last month.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The most surprising result during the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams here last month was when Sabine Auken; Morten Bilde and Dennis Bilde (Morten’s son) from Denmark; and Roy Welland of New York City defeated Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness). With 16 boards to play, Monaco led by 56 international match points and was fielding two of the world’s top-ranked pairs. With their rankings in parentheses, these were Fantoni (1) and Nunes (2); and Helgemo (9) and Helness (10).

headline: Psy’s New Video Is a Quick Web Hit
abstract: The Korean pop singer known as Psy released a new single over the weekend, and many were quick to notice.
lead_paragraph: The Korean pop singer known as Psy, who gained global notoriety last year when his song “Gangnam Style” became an Internet sensation, released a new single over the weekend, and many were quick to notice. In a little over a day, the video for the song, “Gentleman,” attracted more than 32 million views on YouTube after it had its premiere on Saturday during a concert in Seoul.

headline: In Little Italy, Saving the Past by Rebuilding It
abstract: The board of the Italian American Museum in the Little Italy neighborhood of Manhattan has drawn up plans to sell its building to a developer and relocate inside whatever structure replaces it.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century brick building that houses the Italian American Museum in the Little Italy neighborhood of Manhattan radiates an Old World intimacy, with its tin ceiling and its proximity to shops that still sell slices of pink prosciutto and balls of snow-white mozzarella.

headline: Booksellers Hoping for Pulitzer in Fiction
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The publishing world — stinging after a 2012 in which the Pulitzer Prize board did not bestow a fiction award — hopes for a winner in 2013.
lead_paragraph: At the Community Bookstore in Park Slope in Brooklyn last Wednesday, booksellers were happily engaged in an annual parlor game of the publishing industry: guessing which title might win the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for fiction on Monday.

headline: Flaunting the Spirit of Support for the Arts
abstract: Linz, Austria, is making a stronger bid to put itself on the international cultural map with its handsome new opera house.
lead_paragraph: LINZ, Austria — This industrial city of almost 200,000 midway between Vienna and Salzburg, and the capital of the state of Upper Austria, has long had a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to culture. So it seemed, at least, in a series of slightly defensive speeches by government and arts figures on Thursday evening at the opening of the new Linz Opera House, formally known as the Musiktheater am Volksgarten, referring to the public park it adjoins.

headline: Losing a Step, Nike Seeks to Regain Its Edge
abstract: The company has recently had a hard time standing out amid the clutter, bringing out fewer ads that are widely deemed cool.
lead_paragraph: Lost in the middle of a debate last month over a Nike ad that congratulated Tiger Woods for regaining his ranking as the world’s No. 1 golfer was that people were talking about a Nike ad.

headline: This Caesar Wears an African Cloak
abstract: The blood runs warm in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s vibrant production of “Julius Caesar,” now at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The blood runs warm in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s vibrant production of “Julius Caesar,” now at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Experience has taught the inhabitants of the African country in which this Shakespeare tragedy has ingeniously been reset that life is tenuous and easily taken. Their fears lie close to the surface, quick to tumble into anger, despair and, on occasion, a joy that remains edged in apprehension.

headline: A Child’s Video Tour of Her Family’s Garden
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'iPhone', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A child uses her mom’s iPhone to create a guided tour of a garden in springtime.
lead_paragraph: An enduring question these days is how to engage children with nature given how much time they spend looking at screens of one size or another.  I’ve written off and on about the merits of hybrid experience, …

headline: What Makes a Crowd
abstract: The return of Gayle Dean.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Gayle Dean was a prolific crossword puzzle constructor in the pre-Shortzian era (prior to 1993) and she’s had a few puzzles since then, but we haven’t seen here since 2001. Ms. Dean is back today with a lesson in Yiddish.

headline: Racing Against Time to Save a Young Star
abstract: In “Futurology the Musical,” astronauts from the future travel through time to intervene when an aspiring young actress-singer is on the verge of being corrupted by a showbiz lizard.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you were impressed by a makeover? In the hands of New York’s finest blond-highlighters, blow-dry artists and cheekbone illusionists, almost any woman can dazzle for 24 hours. But Tara Taylor’s transformation in “Futurology the Musical” is something else.

headline: Scenes from Coachella
abstract: More photographs from the music festival in Indio, Calif.
lead_paragraph: More photographs from the music festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: Aliens Invaded, and the Future Looks Like the Old West
abstract: The science-fiction show “Defiance” features a post-invasion earth in which humans struggle to coexist with seven alien races.
lead_paragraph: The new television show “Defiance” has received so much attention for being joined at the hip to a video game that the wrong questions are being asked about it. How the TV series and the online game — which share characters and stories but take place in different parts of a post-alien-invasion earth, circa 2046 — will inform each other is more than a little beside the point, especially since the show’s first season is already shot and won’t be affected by the game.

headline: More Cracks Undermine the Citadel of TV Profits
abstract: Television has thrived on bundling, which offers a way of protecting things but also tends to obscure the weaknesses within. Now those flaws are becoming more apparent.
lead_paragraph: For the longest time in the media business, the concept of the bundle has been foundational. Ads go with editorial content in print, commercials go with programming on television and the channels you desire are paired with ones you did not in your cable package.

headline: Crossroads Guitar Festival
abstract: Scenes from Eric Clapton’s festival at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Eric Clapton’s festival at Madison Square Garden.

headline: The Blues Mix and Mingle With Soul, Country and Rock
abstract: The blues was the center of the universe at Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival this weekend at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The blues was the center of the guitar universe at Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival, two all-star concerts with more than 30 guitarists on Friday and Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Classical and Modern, Partners in the Spirit
abstract: “Gloria,” a New York premiere choreographed by Robert Garland, was the centerpiece of Dance Theater of Harlem’s second program in its comeback run, at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 10 years on hiatus, Dance Theater of Harlem is back. Its return performance on Wednesday at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center, though flawed, gave reasons enough to celebrate. But its second program, on Friday, opened with something more heartening: “Gloria,” a beautiful New York premiere by the company’s resident choreographer, Robert Garland.

headline: Intel Tries to Secure Its Footing Beyond PCs
abstract: The world’s largest semiconductor maker is struggling to adapt as PC sales collapse, users rely more on mobile phones and tablets, and cloud computing expands.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — For the last several months, Andy Bryant, the chairman of Intel, has been trying to put steel in the backs of the company’s employees. At meetings, he tells them that Intel must fundamentally change even though the computer chip maker still has what it takes to succeed in engineering and manufacturing.

headline: Upon a Rotating Set, a Shift of Siegmunds in Wagner Performance
abstract: A shift in Siegmunds makes for a challenging performance of “Die Walküre,” the Robert Lepage production of Wagner’s opera that is returning at the Met.
lead_paragraph: “Die Walküre” returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday, and the machine worked without noticeable hitches. Yes, that machine, the 45-ton set consisting of 24 rotating planks that dominates this production from the director Robert Lepage. These days an element of tension hovers over each performance from Wagner’s epic cycle, back for the first run this season at the Met, because you never know when the machine might malfunction, as happened on April 6 during “Das Rheingold.”

headline: More Snow Could Be in Mets’ Future
abstract: Light early-morning snow showers and an ominous forecast prompted the Twins to postpone Sunday’s game, and this might not be the last postponement for the Mets on this trip, either.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Light early-morning snow showers and an ominous forecast prompted the Minnesota Twins to postpone Sunday’s game with the Mets before some people had their breakfast. The Twins e-mailed the announcement at 8:53 a.m. Central time.

headline: Support Grows for European Effort to Fight Tax Havens
abstract: More European finance ministers agreed over the weekend to push for automatic exchanges of bank records to crack down on tax havens, a plan that already had the support of five countries.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Europe’s effort to crack down on tax havens gained momentum during the weekend as the number of countries agreeing to share more bank information doubled.

headline: Sabathia’s Star Comedic Turn
abstract: The Yankees’ C.C. Sabathia is expanding his horizons as a commercial actor with a new spot for ESPN’s “SportsCenter.”
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ C.C. Sabathia is expanding his horizons as a commercial actor. In a new spot for ESPN’s “SportsCenter” that comes out Monday, Sabathia gives a marvelous deadpan comedic performance along with the ESPN hosts Steve Levy and Scott Van Pelt in an ad that plays off Sabathia’s heft.

headline: BBC Tactics in Covering North Korea Are Faulted

abstract: Reporters who joined students from the London School of Economics on a North Korean trip did not disclose their true purpose and filmed an undercover documentary, the university said.
lead_paragraph: As tensions escalated between North Korea and the world late last month, a small group of students from the prestigious London School of Economics crossed the border into the reclusive country for what was described by organizers as a government-sanctioned “week of sight seeing, meeting with ministers, government officials” and academics.

headline: Knicks Win and Get What They Want: Matchup vs. Celtics
abstract: With a suspense-free victory over the Pacers, the Knicks locked in the second seed in the Eastern Conference and secured a home-court advantage for the first two rounds of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: The scene was set Sunday afternoon at Madison Square Garden — for payback, for message-sending, for a modest celebration and for a timely, well-earned rest. All the Knicks needed on this first day of the final week of the season was a sound victory over the Indiana Pacers. That, and four quarters without anyone being bruised, battered or broken.

headline: NPR Series on Race Aims to Build a Wider Audience
abstract: The race, ethnicity and culture reporting in NPR’s series “Changing Races” is part of the network’s strategy to “do better about mirroring America,” the chief executive says.
lead_paragraph: NPR’s race, ethnicity and culture reporting initiative will make its broadcast debut this week with a four-part series called “Changing Races” for the morning and evening news programs.

headline: A Trudeau Again Leads Canada Party
abstract: Justin Trudeau, 41, the son of Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who was prime minister for 15 years, is faced with reviving a party that is no longer dominant in federal politics.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Justin Trudeau was elected leader of the embattled Liberal Party of Canada on Sunday, 45 years after his charismatic and contentious father, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, assumed the same political position.

headline: Random House Adds a Big Name in Fitness
abstract: David Zinczenko, the former Rodale executive who wrote the “Eat This, Not That” series, will write three books on exercise, diet and nutrition, and form a new imprint, Zinc Ink.
lead_paragraph: David Zinczenko, the former Rodale Inc. executive with a talent for self-promotion and sculpturing physiques, has signed on with Random House to provide some juice to its health and fitness offerings.

headline: German Elites Drawn to Anti-Euro Party, Spelling Trouble for Merkel
abstract: Alternative for Germany, started by a Hamburg economics professor, could play the role of spoiler in the September elections.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With less than six months to go before parliamentary elections in Germany, a new political party that is calling for an end to the European currency union is gaining strength.

headline: U.S. Rethinks How to Respond to Nuclear Disaster
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Radiation', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Dirty Bombs and Radiological Weapons']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to publish a document that would reduce projections for how much radiation exposure is likely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two years after the Fukushima nuclear accident in northern Japan, the United States government is using lessons from that disaster to rewrite its plans for responding to radiation contamination, focusing on long-term cleanup instead of emergency response. But the proposals have set off vehement opposition from critics of nuclear power.

headline: Coordinated Blasts Kill at Least 20 in Somalia’s Capital
abstract: Islamist militants known as the Shabab carried out a suicide attack on the court complex, and a bomb was detonated later on the airport road.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Militants carried out a suicide attack on the court complex here, and a bomb was detonated later on the airport road, in a coordinated wave of violence Sunday in the Somali capital that left at least 20 people dead, officials said.

headline: Once-Maligned Coin Nears Its Big Payday
abstract: Ryan Givens and his family are expected to collect $2 million to $5 million at auction for a rare nickel that was once labeled a fake.
lead_paragraph: On the rainy night of March 9, 1962, a head-on car crash scattered a quarter-million dollars’ worth of coins across a North Carolina highway, and the life story of a solitary collector named George O. Walton came to an end. But another story began — one of expert blunders, abiding family loyalty and long-awaited redemption.

headline: Venezuela Gives Chávez Protégé Narrow Victory
abstract: Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked protégé of Hugo Chávez, won an unexpectedly close race for the presidency. His rival demanded a recount.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In an unexpectedly close race, Venezuelans narrowly voted to continue Hugo Chávez’s revolution, electing his handpicked political heir, Nicolás Maduro, to serve the remainder of his six-year term as president, officials said late Sunday.

headline: A Capricious River, an Indian Island’s Lifeline, Now Eats Away at It
abstract: The Brahmaputra River, a critical laboratory in climate studies, is fast eroding an island in Assam that it has encircled and sustained for ages.
lead_paragraph: MAJULI, India — Not too long ago, Ganesh Hazarika grew rice, vegetables and peas near the edge of the Brahmaputra River on a small plot that provided him a livelihood and a safety net. Then one day the river took it away. Steadily and mercilessly, it had chewed at the banks until his tiny farm fell into the water.

headline: Europeans Reach Deal With Google on Searches
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Search Engines', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators.
lead_paragraph: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators into whether it abuses its dominance of online search.

headline: Afghan Interpreters for the U.S. Are Left Stranded and at Risk
abstract: Afghans who worked for American forces have found themselves without military protection and facing a backlog for visas that could help give them protection.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The first time the Taliban tried to kill him, Sulaiman was driving to his base when his truck was hit by a rocket, knocking him down a cliff.

headline: For Guan, a Week to Savor
abstract: China’s Guan Tianlang got a standing ovation and big cheers from the gallery on the 18th green after finishing for a total of 12-over 300.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At the last hole, Guan Tianlang retrieved his ball from the cup after ending his first Masters with his 48th par. The fans ringing the 18th green gave him a standing ovation. They no doubt were thinking that they had not seen the last of Guan, a 14-year-old from China who finished as the low amateur.

headline: A Top Producer Leaves ‘Katie’ for CNN
abstract: Michael Bass, a longtime deputy of Jeff Zucker’s dating from their days at “Today,” left Katie Couric’s syndicated talk show to be a senior vice president at CNN.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Zucker, who left Katie Couric’s syndicated talk show, “Katie,” at the end of last year to take over CNN Worldwide, is bringing in one of the show’s top producers to join him.

headline: In Testimony, Guatemalans Give Account of Suffering
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Mayans']
abstract: Many spoke of the horrors they endured as children, when the government was pursuing leftist guerrillas and anyone believed to be a sympathizer.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — They were just children when Guatemalan soldiers rampaged through their villages, often killing their parents and siblings. Many fled to mountain forests, where they foraged for food and watched some of their numbers starve to death.  Some were abducted and sent to other families to be raised, in cities and towns far from the life they had known.

headline: A Mill’s Fate Weighs Heavy on a Washington Timber Town
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Paper and Pulp']
abstract: Residents and workers in Hoquiam, Wash., say they are hopeful the town’s largest private employer will reopen, but delays have left uncertainty hanging thick in the air.
lead_paragraph: HOQUIAM, Wash. — On mornings with good weather, Jack Durney has coffee in the backyard of his house overlooking the town where he grew up and now presides over as mayor, and one of the first things he focuses on these days is the boiler stack at Harbor Paper. Is there steam coming from the mill?

headline: Bryant Goes Away, but Not Quietly
abstract: After tearing his left Achilles’ tendon on Friday, Kobe Bryant has taken to social media to share his thoughts and promise a comeback.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant is no stranger to social media. In recent months, he has treated his millions of followers on Twitter and Facebook to pictures of his breakfast. He has espoused the virtues of sleep aids. He has shared inspirational quotations. And, in a nod to the all-consuming commerce of his chosen profession, he has cited his various sponsors, which include watchmakers, apparel companies and an airline based in Turkey.

headline: The Antisocial Network
abstract: The fruitless search for dehumanized money.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin’s wild ride may not have been the biggest business story of the past few weeks, but it was surely the most entertaining. Over the course of less than two weeks the price of the “digital currency” more than tripled. Then it fell more than 50 percent in a few hours. Suddenly, it felt as if we were back in the dot-com era.

headline: If Companies Are People...
abstract: Corporations don’t pay anywhere near their fair share in federal taxes. Fixing that is the first step to both fiscal — and economic — recovery.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S an idea: why not tax corporations as if they were natural persons, in accordance with their newly discovered rights of free speech? That move would solve any impending fiscal crisis.

headline: Branko: Return to Auschwitz
abstract: Branko Lustig, a Holocaust survivor and Oscar-winning producer of “Schindler’s List,” returns to Auschwitz for the bar mitzvah he couldn’t have in his youth.
lead_paragraph: Branko Lustig, a Holocaust survivor and Oscar-winning producer of “Schindler’s List,” returns to Auschwitz for the bar mitzvah he couldn’t have in his youth.

headline: As Wall St. Soars in Tough Era, Company Size Is a Big Factor
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Corporations', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: American giants are benefiting from productivity gains and renewed growth in China and other overseas markets, allowing them to increase profits even if business at home remains lackluster.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough to make sense of the economy these days.

headline: ‘Branko: Return to Auschwitz’
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The filmmaker Topaz Adizes follows Branko Lustig, Holocaust survivor and Oscar-winning producer of “Schindler’s List,” as he returns to Auschwitz.
lead_paragraph: April 15 marks the 68th anniversary of Branko Lustig’s liberation from the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp when he was not quite 13 years old. In this Op-Doc video, we follow Mr. Lustig back to Poland to visit the Auschwitz and Birkenau camps (where he was also interned) and to celebrate the bar mitzvah he could never have as a young man.

headline: Daniel Reich, 39, Resourceful Art Dealer, Dies
abstract: Mr. Reich put on exhibitions of emerging artists in his tiny studio apartment in Chelsea before moving to a commercial space.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Reich, a scrappy and innovative New York art dealer who held exhibitions for two years in his tiny studio apartment and, even after renting a traditional gallery, continued to show art nomadically in places like the Chelsea Hotel and a former delicatessen in Midtown, died on Dec. 25 at his parents’ home in Larchmont, N.Y., his sister confirmed this week. He was 39.

headline: On Guns, a Mixed Report From the States
abstract: Broad federal legislation is needed to close potentially lethal interstate loopholes.
lead_paragraph: The good, the bad and the ugly are emerging from statehouses across the nation as lawmakers address wildly different gun proposals prompted by the Newtown, Conn., massacre in December.

headline: Parties’ Rifts Hinder Background Check Measure in Gun Bill
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Divisions over a measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are undermining support for what was seen as a compromise deal to ease passage of a broader bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Deep divisions within both parties over a bipartisan measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are threatening its chances as the Senate this week begins debating the first broad gun control legislation in nearly 20 years.

headline: Justices Consider Whether Patents on Genes Are Valid
abstract: The Supreme Court is poised to take up the question of whether human genes can be patented. But some say advances in the field may blunt the impact of its ruling.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is poised to take up the highly charged question of whether human genes can be patented. But another question could trump it: Has the field of genetics moved so far so fast that whatever the court decides, it has come too late to the issue?

headline: Past Failures Vanish as Australian Wins Masters
abstract: Adam Scott, beating Ángel Cabrera in a playoff, exorcised the memories of Greg Norman’s collapse at the 1996 Masters and his own collapse at the 2012 British Open.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — With two strokes using his long putter, once considered the dullest tool in his bag, Adam Scott expunged one bitter memory that was 266 days old and another that had lingered in a country’s consciousness for 17 years. Scott became the first Australian to win the Masters when he drained a 12-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole Sunday and defeated Ángel Cabrera of Argentina, whose birdie bid moments earlier had died on the edge of the cup.

headline: Are Human Genes Patentable?
abstract: In an important case about science and law, the Supreme Court should emphatically say no.
lead_paragraph: BRCA1 and BRCA2, abbreviations for breast cancer 1 and 2, are the names of human genes linked to a significant increase in the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for women. In 1997 and 1998, Myriad Genetics, based in Utah, obtained broad patents on the isolated DNA it managed to extract from these genes and on diagnostic tests to find the genes.

headline: Carmen Weinstein, Who Led the Jews of Cairo, Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Weinstein was the driving force behind the restoration of Maimonides’s yeshiva and other monuments of Egyptian Jewish history.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Carmen Weinstein, the leader of Cairo’s small Jewish community and the driving force behind the restoration of Maimonides’s yeshiva and other monuments of Egyptian Jewish history, died on Saturday at her home here on the island of Zamalek. She was 82.

headline: Europe’s Bitter Medicine
abstract: Harsh austerity and reform policies are depressing growth and fostering discontent.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, European leaders have pushed a cocktail of fiscal austerity and structural reforms on troubled countries like Portugal, Spain and Italy, promising that it will be the tonic to cure their economic and financial ailments. All the evidence shows that this bitter medicine is killing the patient.

headline: Cowboys and Eggheads

He is young and fun and personable and as the young female portion of his fan base would say, adorbs! Australians, of course, are over the moon. headline: Defensive Gun Use
abstract: The N.R.A. says guns are used up to 2.5 million times each year in self-defense. That’s not true.
lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association maintains a blog called The Armed Citizen, which highlights defensive gun use. The latest entry, from April 9, describes three incidents: Two from 2013 and one archival example from 1969. It’s not hard to see what the NRA’s getting at, but just in case, a sidebar on the site states: “Studies indicate that firearms are used over 2 million times a year for personal protection, and that the presence of a firearm, without a shot being fired, prevents crime in many instances.” In other words, as Wayne LaPierre put it after Newtown, “the only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun.”

headline: Indonesia: Flag Dispute Put Off
abstract: The Indonesian government has extended the deadline for Aceh Province to annul a bylaw that declared the banner of a former separatist movement to be the province’s official flag,
lead_paragraph: The Indonesian government has extended by 60 days a deadline for the government in Aceh Province to annul a new bylaw that declares the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the province’s official flag and seal, a Ministry of Home Affairs official said Monday. Zaini Abdullah, the governor of Aceh, had faced a Tuesday deadline to strike down the bylaw, which was passed by the provincial legislature last month. The dispute centers on the outlawed flag of the Free Aceh Movement, now defunct, which signed a peace agreement with the Indonesian government in 2005 that ended a 29-year civil war. The national government and armed forces oppose the use of the banner, citing multiple national laws against separatism. Officials in Aceh say the peace agreement and the province’s special autonomy status allow it to have its own flag and seal.

lead_paragraph: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran has started a three-nation Africa trip that includes a visit to Niger, a leading producer of uranium. Mr. Ahmadinejad, left, is also visiting Benin and Ghana. Iran’s state-run media did not specify the purpose of the trip beyond a desire to advance relations with all three countries. But the stop in Niger aroused speculation that Iran, which is under international sanctions over its disputed nuclear program, might be looking for outside sources of uranium, despite its claims of self-sufficiency. Last week Iran said it had opened two new uranium mines, suggesting that its supply is running low. According to the World Nuclear Association, a London-based trade group representing the nuclear profession, Niger is the world’s fourth-biggest uranium producer. Most of it goes by contract to Areva, a mining company based in France, the former colonial power in Niger.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE CENTRAL PARK FIVE (2012) The directors Ken Burns, David McMahon and Sarah Burns revisit the case of the Central Park jogger, a 28-year-old white woman who was found in the park very early on April 20, 1989, bound, gagged, nearly naked and nearly dead, and the five black and Latino teenagers who were arrested (above, Yusef Salaam, one of the accused). They argue that the convictions, and the years the defendants served for the attack, of which they were eventually absolved last year, constituted a second, racially motivated crime. “Equal measures criminal investigation, cultural exhumation and a consideration of race in a presumptively postracial America, it seeks to set the record straight,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Measured in tone and outraged in its argument, it is an emotionally stirring, at times crushingly depressing cinematic call to witness. It’s also frustrating because while it re-examines the assault on the jogger and painstakingly walks you through what happened to the teenagers — from their arrest through their absolution — it fails to add anything substantively new. If you followed the news, the story will be familiar; if you lived in New York in 1989, it may also feel incomplete.”

headline: Why Do I Think My Salary Pays for Child Care?
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Parenting', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Both working parents are equally in need of child care. So why do I suddenly think of my salary as paying that bill?
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I wrote an eBook about how couples manage their money. As part of my research, I read “The Creation of Domestic Currencies” by the Princeton professor Viviana Zelizer, who studies the way economics and emotion intertwine. Dr. Zelizer writes about how in the 1920s and ’30s, when wives earned money — no matter how much money it was or how important it was to the family’s bottom line — it was treated as “pin money” and was earmarked for the more frivolous expenses. Maybe it would be used to buy a special dress for the baby. It probably would not be used to buy a house.

lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported profit of $2.2 billion in the first quarter, driven by strength in investment banking and lending. The earnings of $4.29 a share represented a 9 percent increase from the quarter a year earlier. The results beat analysts’ expectations of $3.89 a share, according to Thomson Reuters. “Our strong client franchise across our businesses drove generally solid results. Still, the potential for macroeconomic instability was felt in the quarter and constrained overall corporate and investor activity,” Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman’s chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. Goldman’s stock rose slightly in premarket trading on Tuesday. headline: Catch of the Day
abstract: T has an envelope-style clutch with a natural edge.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that these soft, buttery clutches were once swimming in Lake Victoria and are now eliciting oohs and aahs on a breakfast table at Balthazar in New York. Passers-by stop to ask how to snare one of them. Nile perch leather clutches in natural beige and smoky blue gray are exquisite and surprisingly sturdy. Susan Easton, a former graphic designer who traverses the globe seeking such treasures, found the leather in Kisumu, Kenya, where she met the wives of fishmongers who skin and prepare the fish for sale. Each piece, hand-sewn by an artisan born to a family of tailors, is made from a single fish hide and is sewn along the bottom of the envelope-style clutch, which leaves a flap with an interesting, natural edge. The metal clasp is made of reclaimed brass, hammered and shaped like a fish scale. Get hooked.

headline: Holy Coding Error, Batman
abstract: How much damage from a calculation mistake?
lead_paragraph: The intellectual edifice of austerity economics rests largely on two academic papers that were seized on by policy makers, without ever having been properly vetted, because they said what the Very Serious People wanted to hear. One was Alesina/Ardagna on the macroeconomic effects of austerity, which immediately became exhibit A for those who wanted to believe in expansionary austerity. Unfortunately, even aside from the paper’s failure to distinguish between episodes in which monetary policy was available and those in which it wasn’t, it turned out that their approach to measuring austerity was all wrong; when the IMF used a measure that tracked actual policy, it turned out that contractionary policy was contractionary.

headline: An Import With a Foot in Spain
abstract: At Manzanilla, which is at its best about half the time, Dani García offers exceptional additions to the growing catalog of great Spanish tastes in New York.
lead_paragraph: Wylie Dufresne was sitting at the end of the bar. In about three weeks he would open another restaurant of his own, but he had given himself a night off to check out somebody else’s, Manzanilla. Its chef and owner is Dani García, a big deal in Andalusia and, as the first guy to bring liquid nitrogen into the kitchen, a member in good standing of the modernist sorcerers’ club. At his flagship restaurant, Calima in Marbella, Mr. García makes trompe l’oeil tomatoes and fashions chocolate butterflies with mango wings. Simply by opening Manzanilla, his first restaurant outside Spain, on East 26th Street, he has drastically increased the number of chefs in town with whom Mr. Dufresne might conceivably swap recipes.

headline: Officials Describe Chaos at Guantánamo in Weeks Before Raid on Prison
abstract: The raid at the naval base in Cuba followed weeks of tensions over a growing hunger strike that detainees’ lawyers say was provoked by a search of Korans in February.

In The New York Times Book Review, Gary Sernovitz writes, “Lytal asks the essential questions: how to be good; how to be an adult; how to live outside one’s head; how to love unselfishly; how to understand if this girl, this town — any of it, anything at all — are indispensable, and if they’re meaningful enough to turn into art.” In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Lytal discussed the elements of autobiography in his book, what he’s learned from being a book critic and more. abstract: Asunción may be a rarely visited city in a rarely visited country, but it’s worth a visit, especially as part of a larger South American trip.
lead_paragraph: Cooking a chipa caburé in a tatakua is surprisingly like roasting a marshmallow in a campfire. After wrapping dough around a stick, you place it just barely inside the edge of the domed brick oven and rotate it slowly. Get too close to the wood fire and the exterior burns; rotate it just enough and it browns beautifully as the inside cooks through, ready to be slid off the stick and eaten hot.
