headline: Sister Act | Chapin Sisters
abstract: On their new album, the Chapin Sisters channel the Everly Brothers to sublime effect.
lead_paragraph: Abigail and Lily Chapin have been singing together their entire lives, and performing as a band, the Chapin Sisters, for almost a decade. For their latest project, the pair decided to compose an album entirely of Everly Brothers songs — not so much as a tribute but, according to Abigail, 33, as “a master class.” Because the folk-pop duo began their career as a trio — their half-sister, Jessica Craven, left the group to start a family in 2009 — they’d been studying the Everlys for clues as to how to move from what Abigail describes as “an almost doo-wop style, in which one of us is singing and the other two were kind of backing her up,” to a sound that features the kind of two-part harmonies that the Brothers are famous for, in which both singers deliver almost every line “as a single storyteller.”

headline: Dr. Leo Galland Is Answering Your Fresh Juice Questions
abstract: Want to know about the benefits of juice cleanses? Can fresh juices make you look Gwyneth Paltrow-radiant?
lead_paragraph: Can 16 ounces of vegetable juice really help “cleanse” your body of toxins? And which toxins are we talking about? What are “live enzymes,” anyway, and should you be ingesting more of them? If you’ve got gobs of fruit (and the sugar that comes from it) squeezed into your cold-pressed juice, is that ultimately a good thing or a bad thing? What’s up with wheatgrass and liquid chlorophyll? Should fresh juice be pasteurized? Can a juice cleanse really make your skin as glowingly radiant as Gwyneth Paltrow’s?

There were no objects in display cases, no signs saying, “Don’t touch.” Every exhibit was handmade on site and was meant to look it.

lead_paragraph: “Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay” is a mouthful of a title, if not nearly as charmingly loquacious as those for some of Mr. Jay’s books, including “Learned Pigs & Fireproof Women: Unique, Eccentric and Amazing Entertainers: Stone Eaters, Mind Readers, Poison Resisters, Daredevils, Singing Mice, etc., etc., etc., etc.” Those four punctuating “etc.’s” — what more could there be? — are an especially nice touch because they suggest that Mr. Jay has so much up his pushed-up sleeves that he couldn’t possibly squeeze everything into a single title.

headline: How We Got More Than Even With New York Magazine
abstract: A re-cap of The Times Magazine’s softball game last night against New York magazine.
lead_paragraph: Duke and Carolina never play each other until the final month of the college basketball season. And the Army-Navy game traditionally is the last contest of the college football regular season. So, yes, it seemed a wee unnatural that The New York Times Magazine and New York magazine would meet in the season opener of their media softball league on Monday night. It was pegged as our big rivalry game of the year for reasons I’m not entirely clear about. I guess some of our people used to work there and vice versa. (Oh, and they also beat us last year.)

headline: Where to Find Fish, Rabbit and Duck Heads in New York
abstract: A listing of restaurants that offer the experience of eating animal heads.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a renewed appreciation of China’s rustic culinary roots, eating animal heads has become fashionable in Beijing, as Craig Smith writes in this week’s Dining section. There are restaurants solely devoted to the preparation of fish, rabbit and duck heads. In New York you may search long and hard without finding such a restaurant. Look carefully, though — not only in the warrens of a mall in Flushing, Queens, but also on Restaurant Row in Manhattan — and you may be surprised to see what’s looking back. Though the cooking process may render an entire head a nearly uniform brown, there’s no mistaking a rabbit’s incisors or a duck’s bill.

headline: Bring On the Next Marathon
abstract: We’re just not afraid anymore.
lead_paragraph: Looking at scenes of the Boston sidewalk a few hours after Monday’s bombing — torn clothing, bloodstains, shards of glass — I found my mind going back to a similar sidewalk in Tel Aviv in September 2003. A Hamas suicide bomber had blown himself up at a bus stop outside the Tsrifin army base, and by coincidence I was nearby and got there to witness the immediate aftermath. As I wrote then, parts of the bomber were still on the street, including his hairy leg. His shoe had been blown off, but his brown sock was still daintily on his foot. Israeli rescue workers calmly carried away the dead on stretchers, with an odd mix of horror and routine. But what I remember most was something the police spokesman said to me: “We will have this whole area cleaned up in two hours. By morning, the bus stop will be repaired. You will never know this happened.”

headline: Florida: Teachers Sue Over Evaluation System
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Seven Florida teachers have brought a federal lawsuit to protest job evaluation policies that tether individual performance ratings to the test scores of students who are not even in their classes.
lead_paragraph: Seven Florida teachers have brought a federal lawsuit to protest job evaluation policies that tether individual performance ratings to the test scores of students who are not even in their classes. The suit, which was filed Tuesday in conjunction with three local affiliates of the National Education Association in Federal District Court for the Northern District of Florida in Gainesville, says Florida’s two-year-old evaluation system violates teachers’ rights of due process and equal protection. Under a 2011 law, schools and districts must evaluate teachers in part based on how much their students learn, as measured by standardized tests. But since Florida, like most states, administers only math and reading tests and only in selected grades, many teachers do not teach tested subjects. One of the plaintiffs, a first-grade teacher, was rated on the basis of test scores of students in a different school in her district, and another, who teaches vocational classes to aspiring health care workers, was rated based on test scores of students in grades and subjects she had never taught. “This lawsuit highlights the absurdity of the current evaluation system,” said Andy Ford, president of the Florida Education Association.

headline: Advice From Expert on Male Sexuality, Part 2
abstract: Prof. Ronald F. Levant answers readers’ questions  about re-entering the dating world, impotence and other male sexuality problems.
lead_paragraph: Readers recently submitted questions about male sexuality to Dr. Ronald F. Levant, a professor of psychology and director of the Psychology Department Counseling Clinic at the University of Akron. Part 1 of his answers can be found here. Dr. Levant was president of the American Psychological Association and is an author or editor of 14 books, including “Men and Sex: New Psychological Perspectives.” Dr. Levant asked the counselors whom he supervises in his clinic, all Ph.D. students in psychology who see a broad range of clients, to help him compose answers to these questions. Thanks are given to Mike Aguilar, Brittany Baker, Natalie Grandy, Craig Libman and Arielle Riutort. Because of the large number of submissions, not every question was addressed. In particular, we were not able to answer questions on medical issues, as our expertise is psychological, not medical. This feature is closed to further questions.

headline: The Tax Implications of Starting a Business With Retirement Money
keywords: ['Capital Gains Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Retirement', 'Small Business']
abstract: No matter how you finance your business, it makes sense to think about how you are going to get out before you decide to get in.
lead_paragraph: Last week I wrote about the risks of using retirement money to finance your business. I spent some time looking at a strategy called ROBS — rollover as business start-up — and came to the conclusion that although it is being done by thousands of businesses, it has yet to receive the full blessing of either the Internal Revenue Service or the Department of Labor. As a result, I would advise my clients to stay away from the strategy.

Carefully curated by Clare Borthwick, Christie’s specialist in vintage couture and accessories, the goods include jewelry from Chanel, Kenneth Jay Lane, Miriam Haskell and Yves Saint Laurent; handbags from Hermès in almost every color, including a white Birkin with gold hardware ideal for the summer; and trunks from Louis Vuitton that date back to the first quarter of the 20th century. headline: Afghan Islamic Courts: A Pre-Taliban System With Post-2014 Potential?
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Casey Garret Johnson, who served as a political analyst in Afghanistan from 2008 to 2012, discusses the function of an Islamic court system.
lead_paragraph: The American military has built much of its transition strategy in Afghanistan around establishing local police forces to help keep the peace. In recent months, much has been made about the rise of indigenous anti-insurgent forces, separate from the American-sponsored local police, in the historical Taliban strongholds of Ghazni and Kandahar Provinces. Implicit in the praise for these forces is that indigenous militias of this type represent a vital local vision for the future and a sustainable means of keeping the Taliban at bay after 2014.

headline: Moonless on the Mississippi
abstract: The forgotten story of the Mississippi River Squadron at Vicksburg.
lead_paragraph: For most Americans, their historical memory about the Civil War centers on the battles in the East, from the First Bull Run to Petersburg. But taken at its most fundamental level, the Civil War was actually a war of geographic attrition, beginning in the West. The West constituted the strategic military arena, for there, rivers ran parallel to Union lines of invasion; in the East, they ran perpendicular to them.

headline: Vain Glorious | Aqua Spin Classes
abstract: A fitness fad that’s swept over France, has just landed stateside.
lead_paragraph: Aqua spinning, the fitness fad that’s swept over France, has just landed stateside with the newly opened Aqua Studio in TriBeCa. As the name implies, there are elements taken from traditional spinning — fat-blasting and calorie-burning moves, upbeat soundtracks, and friendly (but firm) instructors — but there are also benefits that only exercising in water can boast. For starters, there’s the draw of a low-impact, high-resistance workout. The water supports your body weight and reduces stress on joints while generating resistance, which encourages your legs to move in a safe and controlled manner. Devotees also claim that aqua spinning can help smooth dimpled thighs. Aqua Studio’s founder Esther Gauthier, a French expat, says, “Moving in water generates a natural massage that drains the lymphatic system and improves the appearance of cellulite.” But most important, being in the water is simply fun. There’s something about throwing on a bathing suit and splashing in water that takes the typical emotional edge off of exercising: your muscles are getting a serious workout, while your mind feels buoyant and light. After my first session, I felt rejuvenated and energized, not wiped out (like I do after an intense run), and left the studio with a spring in my step. Sorry, guys: for the moment, Aqua Studio is for the ladies only.

lead_paragraph: “A lot of my stuff terrifies buyers,” Terry de Havilland says, chuckling. A desire to show the shoe-buying public what they’re missing spurred the designer, who made some of the most memorable footwear of the 1970s, to open a three-month-long pop-up boutique in London’s Carnaby Street area beginning on April 20. It’s his first stand-alone retail venture since his Kings Road shop, Cobblers to the World — where Led Zeppelin, Anita Pallenberg and Bianca Jagger bought their platforms — closed in 1979. Though he makes other styles, including a fetching Cuban-heeled boot for men, de Havilland will forever be associated with the platform, which he learned to make at his father’s knee; his parents had a shoe business that catered to showgirls in postwar London, and it was those original designs that prompted him to resuscitate the platform for the glam rock generation and again more recently for customers like Kate Moss. “I think they empower women,” he says. “They give you your own little stage to stand on.”

abstract: Real Madrid is the world’s most valuable soccer team, according to a new survey by Forbes.
lead_paragraph: The rich keep getting richer, and for now, Real Madrid is the richest of all.

headline: Strolling in Paris, With Menus in Mind
abstract: Using Notre Dame as a starting point, Mark Bittman goes looking for restaurants that are worth the walk. Here are his four winners (and three runners-up).
lead_paragraph: Paris is, of course, a walker’s city. But which direction to take? And to what destinations? With previously unknown (to me, at least) restaurants as my end points, I started at Notre Dame (essentially the center of town; all time allotments below are from there) and headed in different directions for different lengths of time.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Boston and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Boston, England, Pakistan and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Boston, England, Pakistan and India.

headline: Hearing the Benefits of Confronting Mozart
abstract: Christian Tetzlaff and several others explore contrasts in chamber music during “Contrasts” at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: When I spoke recently with the clarinetist and composer Jörg Widmann before his three-concert Contrasts series this week at the 92nd Street Y with the eminent violinist Christian Tetzlaff, he said that the series’ juxtapositions of his music and Mozart’s could bring out the knots in the great master that are often hidden in plain sight.

headline: Oilers President Decides Insulting Fans Was a Bad Idea
abstract: The Edmonton Oilers’ president of hockey operations, Kevin Lowe, apologized on Tuesday after he offended the team’s fan base on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Edmonton Oilers’ president of hockey operations, Kevin Lowe, apparently needed to learn a lesson this week taught in Sports Marketing 101: Never take potshots at your fans. There might be a special chapter in the marketing handbook about doing so in a news conference designed to inspire optimism among your fans, as when you hire a new general manager because the last one drove the franchise into a ditch.

headline: Clip: 'G.B.F.'
abstract: A scene from the high school comedy "G.B.F.," directed by Darren Stein.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the high school comedy "G.B.F.," directed by Darren Stein.

headline: Harry Reid’s Conscience
abstract: The Senate majority leader urged his colleagues to pass a gun-safety bill.
lead_paragraph: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid generally isn’t thought of as a conviction politician. He’s a vote-counter; a highly cautious pragmatist who not long ago ducked an opportunity to reform the filibuster, and with it the increasingly slow-to-non-existent legislative process.

headline: A Label Finds 99 Ways to Make Classical Profitable
abstract: The Swedish company X5 Music Group is the envy of the industry with its cheap, best-selling compilation packages.
lead_paragraph: Among iTunes’s top classical albums are plenty by Yo-Yo Ma and Glenn Gould. But the list is also filled with budget compilations, like “The 50 Most Essential Pieces of Classical Music” and “Beethoven: 100 Supreme Classical Masterpieces,” that pack in dozens of “1812” Overtures and “Für Elises” for as little as $6.

headline: New Gun Measures Considered by the Senate
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate voted on a series of amendments on Wednesday afternoon that may determine the shape of new gun legislation.
lead_paragraph: The Senate voted on a series of amendments on Wednesday afternoon that may determine the shape of new gun legislation.

headline: The F.B.I. Criticizes the News Media After Several Mistaken Reports of an Arrest
abstract: The agency said such unverified reporting, from which many news outlets later retreated, could have “unintended consequences” for its investigation.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. scolded several news outlets on Wednesday for mistakenly reporting that an arrest had been made in the Boston Marathon bombings, and warned that such unverified reporting could have “unintended consequences” for its investigation.

headline: This Script, They Think, Could Be the One
abstract: “According to Goldman” tells of problems encountered as a professor and a student work on a screenplay.
lead_paragraph: Writing a script is tough. But writing a script about writing a script — well, that’s a whole other story.

headline: Now Opening | Altai
abstract: Amaryllis Knight opens ALTAI, a new retail store and online platform for her consultancy and furniture studio in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Amaryllis Knight, a globe-trotting, British-born designer, has left her aesthetic fingerprints all over her adopted home of Los Angeles: in the homes, gardens and offices of private design clients; in her own house; and soon, in the smartly appointed restaurant that chef Josef Centeno is opening this summer (Orsa & Winston). Now, with the opening of Altai — the retail store (which opens April 18) and online platform for her consultancy and furniture studio — Knight’s eclectic vision is, at last, shoppable. “It’s a lot more than a store,” she says. “It’s a way to further explore my work and interests while contributing to a conversation in Los Angeles about varied worlds of design and how they intersect.” Situated on a stretch of 3rd Street that’s a retail desert — but a quick skip to LACMA and Regen Projects — the light-drenched, vaulted-ceilinged space sells everything from $14 Santa Maria Novella lozenges to a $600,000 1948 Vincent 1000cc Rapide Series B motorcycle with a legendary racing pedigree. (“It’s a wild machine,” Knight says.)

headline: Cerberus Owner Might Buy Its Gun-Making Group
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Stephen A. Feinberg, owner of Cerberus, is said to be considering buying a gun maker that the firm promised to sell in the wake of the slaying in Newtown, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Four months after the investment firm Cerberus put the country’s largest gun company up for sale in the wake of the school shootings in Connecticut, it has found a possible buyer in Cerberus’s owner, Stephen A. Feinberg.

headline: With Pulitzer, She Became a Composer
abstract: Not only is Caroline Shaw the youngest winner of a Pulitzer Prize for music, she doesn’t even call herself a composer.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Shaw, the winner of the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in Music, isn’t quite ready to own up to what she does.

headline: With Falsetto and Flash, a Band for Which Bigger Is Always Better
abstract: The English band Muse delivered big chords, big emotions and big stage lighting at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The English band Muse loves science concepts. It opened its Madison Square Garden concert on Tuesday night with “The 2nd Law: Unsustainable”: a warning, based on the second law of thermodynamics, that entropy makes an economy based on endless growth unsustainable. (The song, from Muse’s 2012 album, “The 2nd Law,” is also a trendy blast of dubstep, disrupting one of the band’s many somber keyboard introductions with a bass upheaval and a swooping synthesizer.)

headline: A Shower of Sparkles Amid a Haze of Smoke
abstract: Melodrama is the connective thread in Ballet Hispanico’s program at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Sortijas,” a premiere for Ballet Hispanico by the Spanish choreographer Cayetano Soto, opens on a darkened stage as Jamal Rashann Callender, a sinewy, shirtless wonder in black pants, lifts Lauren Alzamora from behind. Her legs splay awkwardly, while her top — a riot of sparkles by the German-American design team Talbot Runhof — glitters relentlessly. A haze of theatrical smoke clings to the stage, rendering it difficult to make out choreographic nuances. Perhaps that’s for the best.

headline: ‘Bravest Woman in Mexico’ Sees Her Story on a New York Stage
abstract: In her first visit to New York, Marisol Valles Garcia watches a “poetic impression” of her life story, which includes four months as the police chief in a community controlled by drug cartels.
lead_paragraph: Until last week, Marisol Valles García, a petite, soft-spoken 23-year-old with rather severe rectangular glasses, had never visited New York, never ridden in an elevator, never dined in an Italian restaurant. And she had never seen a play.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: April 18
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Giada Forte jewelry; offsetting bursts of spring color with a neutral bag; and Pas de Calais, a Japanese label with a Gallic inflection, opens its first United States store in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: Giada Forte jewelry; offsetting bursts of spring color with a neutral bag; and Pas de Calais, a Japanese label with a Gallic inflection, opens its first United States store in SoHo.

headline: In ‘Spuren,’ Glass Finds His Inner Bruckner
abstract: As last week’s world premiere of “Spuren der Verirrten” showed, Philip Glass seems to be no more minimalist these days than Bruckner was.
lead_paragraph: LINZ, Austria — How did Anton Bruckner, thought by some to have been the stodgiest of composers, suddenly become cool? Well, not cool himself, exactly, but he seems to be hanging out more with cool guys: namely, a couple of Minimalist pioneers.

headline: Editors’ Lab at The New York Times
abstract: This weekend, The New York Times is hosting an Editors’ Lab hack event, bringing together teams to build apps and projects around the theme of “newsgaming.”
lead_paragraph: This weekend, April 20–21, we’re hosting an Editors’ Lab hack event at the Times building. The worldwide Editors’ Labs series, organized by the Global Editors Network (GEN), invites teams to build apps and projects around a media-related theme. This weekend’s theme is “newsgaming”: projects at the intersection of games and journalism.

headline: Company Founder Makes Court Appearance in Breast-Implant Case
abstract: Jean-Claude Mas, of Poly Implants Prothèses, is accused of selling hundreds of thousands of defective implants to more than 65 countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The founder of a French company accused of selling hundreds of thousands of defective breast implants to more than 65 countries appeared on Wednesday in a courthouse in Marseille, with more than 300 victims in attendance.

headline: The ‘Weird Realism’ of H.P. Lovecraft
abstract: In this week’s briefs: finding philosophy in H.P. Lovecraft, a philosophy teacher leaves prison, and more.
lead_paragraph: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Scouting Report
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Brooks Brothers creates a capsule collection for “The Great Gatsby” premiere; Holst + Lee joins Plum Alley, a new luxury e-commerce platform and other shopping news.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based jewelry line Holst + Lee, created by Natalie Holst and Rochelle Lee, is the latest addition to the roster at Plum Alley, a new luxury e-commerce platform that curates products exclusively from companies founded by women. In honor of the occasion, Ms. Holst and Ms. Lee have designed three pieces exclusively for the site: glass crystal and nylon rope earrings ($175), a Swarovski crystal-studded necklace ($275) and a multistrand necklace made from nylon rope wrapped with pearl cotton thread ($225). This week, 10 percent of the proceeds on these items will go to Somaly Mam Foundation, an organization that works to end human trafficking.

headline: For Quinn, Weiner Is the Possible Candidate Who Must Not Be Named
abstract: As other candidates rushed to offer invitations for Anthony D. Weiner to enter the race, Christine C. Quinn answered all questions about him with responses about herself.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, is rarely reticent on the campaign trail, doling out rhetorical jabs and gibes and regularly earning laughter from crowds.

headline: EBay’s Profit Rises 19%, but Results Miss Estimates
abstract: The results, as well as second-quarter forecasts, fell short of Wall Street’s expectations, causing shares to fall a few points in after-hours trading.
lead_paragraph: EBay continues its turnaround, from troubled online auction site to a forward-looking, mobile-oriented e-commerce company.

headline: Times Talks: Ken Burns on Justice and ‘The Central Park Five’
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: The Times Talk discussion on Wednesday evening featured Ken and Sarah Burns, who made the documentary “The Central Park Five”; the reporter Jim Dwyer; and the five men who were wrongly accused of rape in the 1989 case.
lead_paragraph: Watch the discussion about the issues raised by “The Central Park Five,” the award-winning documentary about a 1989 rape in Central Park, the rush to judgment and the lives of those wrongly convicted.

headline: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Scrubbing your profile from a social networking site isn’t easy; more users make the site look better to advertisers. Here are some tools to make the break.
lead_paragraph: Ah, those online relationships.

headline: At Age 14, No Stranger to a Steal
abstract: Henry Kilpatrick sells vintage furniture he finds at estate sales and on Craigslist.
lead_paragraph: On the Internet, no one cares that you’re 13. That’s what Henry Kilpatrick discovered when he started his vintage-furniture retail site, Magic City Finds, in September 2011, at the dawn of his teen years. Mr. Kilpatrick, who is now 14 and lives in Birmingham, Ala., had no idea who Herman Miller was when he plucked a fiberglass armchair from his grandmother’s storage space, but one online search later, he knew he had a find. He plowed the $75 he made on that initial sale, along with some birthday money, back into furniture bought at estate sales and off Craigslist, including 20 more Eames chairs, which cycled through his parents’ garage. He mostly works on the weekends, as it is “tough to do schoolwork and business, and schoolwork comes first,” he said.

headline: Recalling a Chronicler of Combat as It Is
abstract: Sebastian Junger’s documentary about the war photojournalist Tim Hetherington, who was killed in 2011 in Libya, will be on HBO on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The British-born photojournalist Tim Hetherington starts and stops, groans and grimaces, as he tries to explain why he’s made a career of taking his cameras as close as possible to the places where men are killing each other. He manages to get out, “The important thing for me is to make work that is connected to people,” before shaking his head in disgust: “Blah blah blah blah blah.”

headline: Inspiration From a PB&J
abstract: Deborah Ehrlich, a glass designer, came up with a porch light based on a jelly jar.
lead_paragraph: When Deborah Ehrlich, a glass designer in Accord, N.Y., needed a new porch light almost four years ago, she designed one. “The idea was a jelly jar,” she said. But it is a refined version, made by artisans in Sweden with whom Ms. Ehrlich has worked for 13 years. The material is Swedish crystal. “You can blow it very thin, and it doesn’t break,” Ms. Ehrlich said. The light, which has a white glazed porcelain base and a rubbed brass shade holder, is now in production. Fully assembled, it measures 4 inches wide and 8 inches high, and sells for $225 at Artware Editions, 270 Bowery, second floor (Houston Street), (212) 463-7490; artwareeditions.com.

headline: He Wouldn’t Change a Thing
abstract: Christie’s is holding an auction of villa furnishings chosen by Michael S. Smith, the Obamas’ White House decorator.
lead_paragraph: On April 23 and 24, Christie’s will stage an auction of the contents of a Palladian-style villa in Malibu, Calif., that was designed by Michael S. Smith, the Obamas’ White House decorator. The auction includes many museum-quality pieces, including a Sean Scully painting and a Persian rug that once belonged to the Agnelli family of Italy. A Chinese brown lacquer altar table, shown, has an estimated sale price of $4,000 to $6,000. There’s also a trove of Asian art and antiques, Old Master paintings and historic European furniture (more than 450 lots) with an estimated sale value of $3.5 million to $5 million. It took Mr. Smith five years to accumulate all the treasures, and he may bid at the auction himself. “I’m not done with anything,” he said. “I’d buy it all again.” So attached is he to the project that he wrote a book about it, “Building Beauty: The Alchemy of Design” (Rizzoli, $55). Information: (212) 636-2000 or Christies.com.

headline: Designs That Help Redefine ‘Craft’
abstract: Limited-edition furnishings made from recycled materials.
lead_paragraph: By weekday, John Liston is a glass artisan working for other artists and architects in Oakland, Calif. But the rest of the time, he experiments with his own furniture and lighting in a cooperative studio in San Francisco. Out of these efforts have come burnt-recycled-wood cabinets ($11,000), lights with industrial-glass orbs perched on scrap-metal tripods ($25,000) and other mixed-media pieces, which he displays at craft shows. One of his cheeriest works is his bright orange Ribbon chair, shown, made of crisscrossed steel slats ($6,000).

headline: Need a Good Zinnia Recipe?
abstract: “The Flower Recipe Book” is a practical guide to flower arranging by Alethea Harampolis and Jill Rizzo.
lead_paragraph: Don’t be misled by the title: “The Flower Recipe Book,” by Alethea Harampolis and Jill Rizzo (Artisan, $24.95), is not a guide for making hibiscus enchiladas or scented-geranium sorbet. Rather, it’s a beautifully illustrated and practical guide to the ephemeral art of fresh-flower arranging.

headline: Sales at BoConcept, Niche Modern and Others
abstract: Discounts on furniture, rugs, lighting and more.
lead_paragraph: Furniture, lamps and decorative accessories are up to 70 percent off at BoConcept’s warehouse sale, on Saturday (the Cavona dining chair, regularly $199, will be $69); 20 Pulaski Street, Bayonne, N.J., (201) 433-4461, boconcept.us.

headline: Scare Me, Sure, but Also Make a Statement
abstract: The Midnight Section at the Tribeca Film Festival features a collection of horror films that have more than a little to say.
lead_paragraph: Propellers where faces ought to be. Woman-on-woman death matches. Celebrity chefs with a taste for human flesh. All you cinephiles who like to find grand statements and social criticism in horror movies, prepare to bloviate. It’s midnight at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Market Ready

lead_paragraph: Q. Would converting my basement into a man cave increase the resale value of my home?

headline: ‘A Pretty Shameful Day’ in Washington
abstract: President Obama was right to be angry as he decried the shockingly cowardly act by the Senate today.
lead_paragraph: That’s how President Obama characterized the shockingly cowardly act by which the United States Senate betrayed the victims of the Newtown massacre and every American who has been killed by gun violence since then. Ninety-percent of Americans support expanded background checks, but 45 percent of the Senate killed a bill that would have provided that expansion – without infringing in the slightest way on the Second Amendment.

headline: Partner Without the Prize
abstract: A bid to have the most prestigious award in architecture, the Pritzker Prize, give more acknowledgment to Denise Scott Brown, wife and partner of the 1991 winner, Robert Venturi, is gaining momentum.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-two years after being passed by, the architect Denise Scott Brown, 81, said at an awards ceremony for women in architecture last month that it was time she share in the 1991 Pritzker Prize that was given to her design partner and husband, Robert Venturi, with whom she had worked side by side.

headline: Obama Says Gun Lobby ‘Willfully Lied’
abstract: Following a Senate vote that defeated several gun-related measures, President Obama spoke in the Rose Garden of the White House.
lead_paragraph: Following a Senate vote that defeated several gun-related measures, President Obama spoke in the Rose Garden of the White House.

headline: A Single Vision
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']

lead_paragraph: In their new space, like every other home Teman Evans and his identical twin, Teran, have shared, nothing is costly or permanent.

headline: I’ll Be Your Mirror
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The designing twins Teman and Teran Evans can’t help being matchy-matchy.
lead_paragraph: As newborns, Teman Evans and his identical twin, Teran, looked so much alike that the doctor who delivered them had to put bracelets on them so their mother could tell them apart. (When they were 10, she confessed that soon after, she had taken the bracelets off to bathe the twins, and wasn’t entirely sure she had put them back on correctly.) At 33, those bracelets are long gone, but the twins remain almost indistinguishable.

headline: Obama Decries Senate’s Rejection of Gun Safety Measures
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a Rose Garden statement, President Obama decried a Senate vote defeating gun control legislation, saying a minority of senators “blocked common-sense gun reforms even while these families looked on from the Senate gallery.”
lead_paragraph: Flanked by family members of the Newtown, Conn., shooting victims and former Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, President Obama decried a Senate vote defeating gun control legislation, saying a minority of senators “blocked common-sense gun reforms even while these families looked on from the Senate gallery.”

headline: Impatiens, and Some Alternatives
abstract: Consider the collapse of your favorite annual as an invitation to experiment.
lead_paragraph: Consider the collapse of your favorite annual as an invitation to experiment.

headline: A Pox on Your Flowers
abstract: Impatiens, a favorite of home gardeners, is under siege in the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: A mysterious strain of downy mildew has been killing one of the home gardener’s favorite annual flowers, Impatiens walleriana, up and down the East and West Coasts, in the Midwest, Texas and Ontario.

headline: Settling Fee Dispute, Law Firm Denounces ‘E-Mail Humor’
abstract: The firm settled out of court with a client who accused it of overbilling in a case where internal lawyers’ e-mails suggested a lax attitude toward the size of the bill.
lead_paragraph: The law firm DLA Piper has settled a fee dispute with one of its clients, resolving a case that highlighted lawyers’ e-mails that discussed overbilling the client, in one instance using the phrase “churn that bill, baby!” to describe their work.

headline: Misconceptions Could Lead to Health Law ‘Train Wreck,’ Baucus Warns
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, gave a “failing grade” to the administration’s public information effort about the health care law.
lead_paragraph: A routine Senate budget hearing turned into a public scolding as a prominent backer of the health care overhaul warned that a lack of public information could cause a “train wreck” as the law’s implementation moves forward.

headline: Were You or Someone You Know at the Marathon Finish Line?
abstract: The Times needs your help to identify and tell the stories of the people in an image of the moment the first bomb exploded during the Boston Marathon.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several days, Times reporters and editors have been working on identifying and telling the stories of the people in the image above, a frame from video recorded at the moment of the first explosion at the Boston Marathon. We have found many of the people seen here, but would like your help in identifying more. Are you visible in any part of this image recorded on Monday afternoon or do you know someone who was there? Please fill out the form below and include your location. A reporter or editor will follow up on all relevant leads.

headline: Making the Best of It
abstract: At the International Furniture Fair, exhibitors struggle to stay fresh and commercially viable, despite a dismal economy.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The dog had spots.

headline: Highlights From the Milan Furniture Fair
abstract: From dalmatians to miniature fireplaces.
lead_paragraph: From dalmatians to miniature fireplaces.

headline: A Treat for Art Students: Leggy Models With Multicolor Coats and Fine Manes
abstract: A spring tradition continued Wednesday when two horses were taken to Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and drawn live by young artists.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Judd did something on Wednesday that art students do not usually do: He walked away with one of the models.

headline: Beauty Spots
abstract: Facials, haircuts and shaves, and a center dedicated to treating acne.
lead_paragraph: Groucho Marxwouldn’t join any club that would have him as a member, but he probably wasn’t as concerned about his complexion as the target customer for these deals.

headline: Rising Bank Profits Tempt a Push for Tougher Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Steady earnings growth on Wall Street could embolden the lawmakers and regulators who want to overhaul the banking system.
lead_paragraph: Banks have been reporting steady growth in earnings since soon after the financial crisis. With the latest reports rolling in, analysts think the banks’ first-quarter profits will be their best ever.

headline: Photo Replay: April 17
abstract: A view of the day in sports, full of leaps and strong finishes.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, full of leaps and strong finishes.

headline: An Afghan City’s Economic Success Extends to Its Sex Trade
abstract: Mazar-i-Sharif has become the country’s unofficial capital of prostitution — so much so that “going to Mazar” has become an expression for men looking to pay for sex.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — This verdant town is home to some of Afghanistan’s greatest treasures: It is the birthplace of the celebrated poet Rumi, and the site of one of the country’s most storied mosques. It is the first Afghan city to have been connected with another country by rail.

headline: Ricin: Poison of Choice Over the Years
abstract: This toxic chemical comes from the bright red castor plant and can be deadly if inhaled.
lead_paragraph: This toxic chemical comes from the bright red castor plant and can be deadly if inhaled.

headline: The Polo Rebuttoned
abstract: Uniqlo has asked the designer Michael Bastian to riff on the shirts; Walter Van Beirendonck’s first United States exhibition; and fashion figures are participating in Urban Greenwalk.
lead_paragraph: UNIQLO IS MAKING A BIG BET on polo shirts. Walk into the stores and you will find stacks of them, striped, solid, piqué and otherwise. Hold out until next week and you will find even more.

headline: Hedi Slimane’s First Year at Saint Laurent
abstract: Since he replaced the designer Stefano Pilati in a creative takeover that bordered on a coup, Mr. Slimane, 44, has introduced a vision for Saint Laurent.
lead_paragraph: Since he replaced the designer Stefano Pilati in a creative takeover that bordered on a coup, Mr. Slimane, 44, has introduced a vision for Saint Laurent.

headline: Mr. Provocative
abstract: Hedi Slimane has antagonized fashion critics and even friends. Customers, however, are making his collections best sellers.
lead_paragraph: Hedi Slimane could write a book on how to lose friends and still influence people.

headline: London to Harlem via Chelsea
abstract: Serena Bass, longtime society caterer and executive chef at Lido, takes stock of a remarkable life in night life.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the longtime society caterer Serena Bass was having lunch at Lido, the Italian restaurant in Harlem where she has been the executive chef since last fall, and reading a text message. “There is a book just out called ‘Best Chefs America,’ and I’m in it,” she said. “I’m quite surprised. So that’s good.”

headline: Stop Involving Red ‘Pelle Pelle’ Jacket
abstract: A wanted poster distributed to police officers the day of the stop and photographs of the witness who was stopped on the way home from his mother’s wearing a similar red jacket.
lead_paragraph: A wanted poster distributed to police officers the day of the stop and photographs of the witness who was stopped on the way home from his mother’s wearing a similar red jacket.

headline: Obama’s Remarks After Senate Gun Votes
abstract: The following is a transcript of remarks by President Obama and the father of a 7-year-old killed during the Sandy Hook shooting after the Senate rejected gun measures.
lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of remarks by President Obama and Mark Barden, the father of a 7-year-old killed during the Sandy Hook shooting, after the Senate rejected gun measures, as provided by the White House.

headline: The Senate Fails Americans
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: Bowing to the gun lobby rather than the public, lawmakers kill crucial gun control legislation a mere 18 weeks after the massacre in Newtown, Conn.
lead_paragraph: For 45 senators, the carnage at Sandy Hook Elementary School is a forgotten tragedy. The toll of 270 Americans who are shot every day is not a problem requiring action. The easy access to guns on the Internet, and the inevitability of the next massacre, is not worth preventing.

headline: Henry A. Prunier, 91, U.S. Soldier Who Trained Vietnamese Troops, Dies
abstract: Mr. Prunier, originally recruited by the Army as a translator, was part of a clandestine mission to teach 200 Viet Minh guerrillas how to use American weapons.
lead_paragraph: Henry A. Prunier taught Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese general who withstood the armies of France and the United States, how to throw a grenade.

headline: Italian Coachwork in American Proportions: the Dual-Ghia Convertible
abstract: Stemming from a Virgil Exner-designed, Ghia-built Chrysler concept, the Dual-Ghia convertible was a favorite among late-1950s Hollywood stars.
lead_paragraph: After seeing what sorts of concept-car tricks automakers were up to at the last few auto shows, it’s fun to dust off the pages of history and examine the concepts that designers dreamed up in the 1950s. Today, form usually follows function — with the possible exception of the huge, masculine grilles currently in vogue — but during the early years of the jet age, the Big Three fielded many flamboyant, sleek concepts with lines that brought to mind images of rockets blasting off into outer space.

headline: Kerry Encourages Venezuela Recount
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry suggested a recount in the presidential vote and said he had yet to evaluate whether Washington would recognize Nicolás Maduro’s victory.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Secretary of State John Kerry said Wednesday that Venezuela should hold a recount of votes cast in its presidential election, which the country’s electoral authorities say was narrowly won by a protégé of former President Hugo Chávez.

headline: As Italy Picks a President, Some Say It’s Time to Choose a Woman
abstract: While women hold a record 31 percent of the seats in Parliament, Italy has lagged other European countries in equality for women over all.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian lawmakers begin voting on Thursday for a successor to President Giorgio Napolitano amid growing debate about electing a woman for the first time in this male-dominated society, and even seemingly strong popular support for the idea.

headline: Just in Time, a Veteran Joins the Knicks
abstract: Quentin Richardson has been through a lot in his N.B.A. career, but on Wednesday he dealt with a new situation: Joining a team just before its regular-season finale.

headline: More Children in Greece Are Going Hungry

headline: Court Declines to Rule in Wikileaks Complaint
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: A military appeals court on Wednesday declined to rule on a lawsuit seeking greater access for journalists to court filings and proceedings in the criminal case against Pfc. Bradley Manning.
lead_paragraph: A military appeals court on Wednesday declined to rule on a lawsuit seeking greater access for journalists to court filings and proceedings in the criminal case against Pfc. Bradley Manning, who has admitted to leaking 700,000 confidential government documents to WikiLeaks. The Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces decided 3 to 2 that it did not have jurisdiction to hear the appeal, filed by a coalition of journalists and organizations, including the Center for Constitutional Rights, which said in a statement that the ruling meant that Private Manning’s trial, set for June 3, will be “fundamentally unfair.” Military officials initially withheld from the public all documents in the case, including some the judge read aloud in court. More recently, officials have released a selection of documents, but with names and other information blacked out.

The three-person commission will have 60 days to analyze why the prosecutor’s office has been unable to solve so many criminal cases, and will generate a plan to improve the trustworthiness of the institution. Honduras, which has become a major drug route to the United States, has one of the highest homicide rates in the world.

headline: Egypt: Mubarak to Be Moved to Prison
abstract: Egypt’s chief prosecutor on Wednesday ordered the transfer of former President Hosni Mubarak from a Cairo military hospital back to prison.
lead_paragraph: Egypt’s chief prosecutor on Wednesday ordered the transfer of former President Hosni Mubarak from a Cairo military hospital back to prison. Mr. Mubarak is expected to be held there pending a retrial on charges including complicity in the killing of protesters during the 2011 revolt that toppled him. He had been in the hospital since December after injuring himself during a fall in the prison shower, his lawyers said. The prosecutor ordered the transfer after Mr. Mubarak appeared Saturday in a Cairo courtroom, where, despite being on a gurney, the former president appeared in good health and high spirits, waving to supporters. A medical board subsequently ruled that Mr. Mubarak was well enough to be sent back to prison. A judge scheduled May 11 as the date for the new trial.

headline: Waking Up on the Wrong Side of a Ratings War
abstract: How a toxic clash of personalities cost NBC’s “Today” its No. 1 ranking. Matt Lauer may yet lead the show back to the top spot, but the morning is tougher now than ever.
lead_paragraph: One Wednesday last month, Ann Curry, camouflaged in a hat and trench coat, trudged into the art-deco lobby of 30 Rockefeller Plaza. It had been nine months since she was pushed out as co-host of the “Today” show. Curry was now NBC’s “national and international correspondent” and the anchor at large for “Today,” but these titles seemed honorary. Curry had appeared on “Today” only a handful of times since her ouster. She had no role in NBC’s coverage of election night or Inauguration Day. She taped a few stories for “Rock Center,” the prime-time newsmagazine show, but as she explained on Twitter, her bosses kept rescheduling them. Curry had moved to an office on the 27th floor of 30 Rock, far from her NBC News bosses on the third floor. On this morning, she was at work on a short “NBC Nightly News” segment about the anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s death. It would be only her sixth appearance on the network all year.

headline: John le Carré Has Not Mellowed With Age

Behind them drifted a loose formation of men and women perched atop well-groomed horses and wearing boots, breeches and hunting coats. As the fox hunt clopped through town, John le Carré, the pre-eminent spy writer of the 20th century, sipped from a paper cup of warm whiskey punch, doled out by a local pub to riders and spectators.

headline: At the Bruins Game, a Time to Rally
abstract: The game between the Bruins and the Sabres at TD Garden on Wednesday night was a chance for Boston to exhale.
lead_paragraph: While everyone rolls out the cliché that sporting events after tragedies serve as some sort of healing mechanism, the people involved always know better. No one went to the Bruins game at the TD Garden Wednesday night thinking it would ease the city’s pain from Monday’s Boston Marathon bombings. But like many clichés, it contains a kernel of truth. People went to the Bruins game Wednesday night because rallying together and doing something normal are at least steps into healing’s neighborhood. And so they came, and when the national anthem singer, Rene Rancourt, turned the song over to them, they all took a teary step forward. The Bruins had simply provided the gathering point.

headline: The Gun Report: April 18, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was dispiriting for the vast majority of Americans who, according to recent polling, want to see expanded background checks on gun sales. But another story that may have been overlooked, between the disappointing Senate outcome and the updates coming out of Boston, was this investigative piece from the Times’s National desk about Internet arms sales, dubbed “the gun show that never ends.” Reporters scoured online ads on Armslist, a self-described “firearms marketplace,” and found that several people who buy firearms are convicted felons who fail background checks, and many private Internet dealers simply look the other way. It’s an unregulated swath of the market that’s evaded government oversight, and, in the absence of new gun legislation, will continue to do so.

headline: Neighbor vs. Neighbor
abstract: Abijah GIlbert and the bloody, intimate guerrilla fighting in Civil War Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: The Confederate rout at Perryville in October 1862 squelched the South’s large-scale ambitions for the Bluegrass State. Afterward, Kentucky had its own internal proxy civil war, and its citizens had more to fear from one another than from some “foreign” invader. As the Southern war effort started to show early signs of futility in 1863, an untold number of Kentucky Confederates returned home, just as the Federal Army’s recruitment of former slaves disillusioned conservative Unionists. Together, they took out their frustrations on their Loyalist neighbors, some of whom gamely returned fire. In no other state, save perhaps Missouri, did this sort of “intimate” fighting determine the course of the war more than in Kentucky.

lead_paragraph: Tom Sturridge and Alec Baldwin in a scene from the Broadway play at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater.

headline: How Circumcision May Stem H.I.V.
abstract: Circumcision reduces a man’s risk of acquiring and transmitting H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases, possibly because the procedure reduces the quantity and diversity of bacteria at the head of the penis.
lead_paragraph: Circumcision reduces a man’s risk of acquiring and transmitting H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted diseases, and now researchers have found a possible explanation: the procedure reduces the quantity and diversity of bacteria at the head of the penis.

headline: John Derian for Astier de Villatte
abstract: John Derian’s latest collaboration with the French ceramic tableware company Astier de Villatte is user-friendly.
lead_paragraph: Early next month, the latest products of John Derian’s ongoing collaboration with the French ceramic tableware company Astier de Villatte will be available in the United States. They include a mug and teapot with an image of an eye that was taken from a 19th-century medical book, as well as a plate called Starfish at Night and a serving bowl covered with a coral-like pattern in blue. Unlike the designer’s famous decoupage plates, these pieces are dishwasher-safe (on the gentle setting). “I love the fact that they’re user-friendly,” Derian says.

headline: New Twitter Service Hopes to Capture Musical Trends
abstract: Twitter’s idea is to recommend songs based on personal contacts as well as on what is popular among the 200 million Twitter audience.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s music service is no longer just for Ryan Seacrest.

headline: Using Just One Word, Try to Describe Your Career DNA
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: George Hu, chief operating officer of Salesforce.com, looked for challenges as a student and hasn’t stopped since.
lead_paragraph: This interview with George Hu, chief operating officer at Salesforce, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: In Fine Print of ‘Spider-Man’ Settlement, Taymor Comes Out on Top
abstract: A result of the settlement of a legal battle over “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is enhanced billing for Julie Taymor.
lead_paragraph: Julie Taymor is back on top.

headline: This Week’s Links
abstract: The latest in the weekly series in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.
lead_paragraph: On Layout and Performance

headline: Pitch for a Coding Standard to Track Media Assets and Ads
abstract: An industry group says a new system for monitoring where, when and how digital videos are watched would be a boon to media companies and marketers.
lead_paragraph: For advertisers and media companies, keeping track and organizing the tonnage of media assets — from video clips to commercials — can be a challenge, particularly online. On Thursday, a media industry organization announced the findings of a two-year study that uses a coding system to monitor these assets, similar to how U.P.C. labels track consumer products from shipping to purchase.

headline: Where Finish Line Is a Crime Scene, No Talk of Defeat
abstract: Some runners expressed their hope that the Boston Marathon would retain its spirit and come back from the bombings bigger and stronger.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On marathon day, Boylston Street has always been a place of completion and celebration instead of tragic disruption, a straightaway toward home where medals are hung around satisfied necks, not where tourniquets are tightened around mangled legs.

headline: A Color Field Artist
abstract: Kenneth Noland painted some of the great emblems of the postwar American abstract style called Color Field painting.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Noland painted some of the great emblems of the postwar American abstract style called Color Field painting.

headline: In Boston, Obama Praises Spirit of City
abstract: Mourning the victims of the marathon bombings, President Obama spoke at a church service titled “Healing Our City” at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston. He also praised the spirit of the city.
lead_paragraph: Mourning the victims of the marathon bombings, President Obama spoke at a church service titled “Healing Our City” at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston. He also praised the spirit of the city.

headline: Officials in Israel Stress Readiness for a Lone Strike on Iran
abstract: In advance of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s visit, Israeli officials warned that Israel was prepared and able to carry out a strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities by itself.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With Chuck Hagel scheduled to begin his first visit to Israel as secretary of defense on Sunday, Israeli defense and military officials issued explicit warnings this week that Israel was prepared and had the capability to carry out a lone military strike against Iran’s nuclear facilities.

headline: Vision Festival Announces Its Lineup
abstract: For its 18th edition the event returns to Roulette in downtown Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The 18th edition of the Vision Festival, New York’s annual celebration built around the lineage of free improvisation and jazz’s non-mainstream languages, will take place from June 12 to 16, according to Arts for Art, the festival’s producers.  As it did last year, the festival will be staged at Roulette, in downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Bloomberg Criticizes Senators Who Opposed Broader Background Checks for Gun Buyers
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the lawmakers had acted out of political self-interest, and he predicted they would ultimately find their calculation to have been wrong.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Senate defeated a gun control measure that would have expanded background checks for gun buyers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday sharply criticized the lawmakers who voted against it.

headline: Sondheim and Marsalis to Collaborate on Show for City Center
abstract: Stephen Sondheim and Wynton Marsalis are collaborating on a new show that will feature jazz interpretations of Mr. Sondheim’s love songs.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Sondheim and Wynton Marsalis are collaborating on a new show to be staged at the New York City Center next November that will feature jazz interpretations of Mr. Sondheim’s love songs.

headline: Injury Sidetracks Mets’ D’Arnaud
abstract: A fractured bone in his foot has muddied the immediate future of Mets prospect Travis d’Arnaud
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Minor league catcher Travis d’Arnaud, the Mets’ top position player prospect, will fly to New York on Friday to see team doctors after fracturing a bone in his foot, General Manager Sandy Alderson said Thursday.

headline: Tip of the Week: Sending Huge E-Mail Attachments
abstract: Thanks to a combination of Web-mail and cloud-storage services, sending large files as attachments is easier these days.
lead_paragraph: These days, high-definition video recordings and high-resolution photographs are easier to make with smartphones and other affordable gear. While great for personal creativity, some people may be seeing more of that old “This file exceeds the attachment limit” message from their e-mail providers when they try to share the files privately with friends. To help users send files larger than the usual 10- to 25-megabyte limit, Google, Yahoo and Microsoft have all melded their Web-based mail with online storage services.

headline: The Other Gun Vote
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: A conceal-carry amendment received more votes, than the background check expansion. Both measures attracted a simple majority, but failed to reach the 60-vote threshold.
lead_paragraph: The Manchin-Toomey amendment to expand background checks could have passed: It received 54 ayes, and would have received 55 if Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid hadn’t voted no for procedural reasons. But the so-called “world’s greatest deliberative body” agreed to a 60-vote threshold for the gun-safety bill.

headline: Obama’s Remarks at Boston Service
abstract: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s remarks at an interfaith memorial service for the victims of the Boston Marathon bombing.
lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s remarks at an interfaith memorial service for the victims of the Boston Marathon bombing at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston on Thursday, as provided by the White House.

headline: On Whether the Rich Pay Too Little in Taxes
abstract: A majority of Americans believe that high-income people do not pay enough in taxes, but that majority has been shrinking over the last couple of decades, according to new data from Gallup.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday Bruce Bartlett mentioned that a majority of Americans believe that high-income people do not pay enough in taxes. That majority, though, has been shrinking over the last couple of decades, according to new data from Gallup.

headline: Video: Obama Praises Boston’s Spirit
abstract: Mourning the victims of the marathon bombings, President Obama spoke at a church service in Boston. He also praised the spirit of the city.
lead_paragraph: Mourning the victims of the marathon bombings, President Obama spoke at a church service titled “Healing Our City” at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston. He also praised the spirit of the city. Transcript »

headline: What’s at Stake in the Fight Over a REIT
abstract: The problem is not Maryland corporate law, but that CommonWealth has a bylaw provision that requires that all shareholder disputes be arbitrated.
lead_paragraph: If you want to see one possible dystopian future for takeovers, you should take a gander at what is going on in the takeover bid for CommonWealth REIT, a real estate investment trust that owns more than 500 office buildings. It’s not pretty, and it’s all a result of  CommonWealth’s claim that all its disputes with shareholders must be arbitrated.

headline: Noninvasive Cancer Test Is Effective, Study Finds
abstract: In a study involving about 10,000 people, the new test detected 92 percent of the cancers picked up by colonoscopy, according to the company that makes the test.
lead_paragraph: A new noninvasive screening test can detect most cases of colorectal cancer and also many precancerous polyps, potentially helping to sharply reduce the death toll from the disease, according to results of a study released on Thursday.

headline: One on One: Tim Jones of Buzzient, Hunting Chatter on Explosives
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Good Samaritans', 'Police', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Good Samaritans can be virtual, too. After the Boston Marathon attack, Tim Jones, an explosives expert and chief of a social media management company, began tracking Web chatter on explosives, offering the data to the Boston police, whom he has been working with since 2011.
lead_paragraph: When two bombs exploded at Monday’s Boston Marathon, good Samaritans of all sorts rushed in, from off-duty medical personnel to residents who opened their homes to evacuees. Tim Jones, the chief executive of Buzzient, a Boston-area social media management start-up, felt a similar urge to help, using his company’s ability to search Web history on forums, comments and social media, to focus on specific topics —  like explosives.

headline: Kepler’s Tally of Planets
abstract: NASA’s Kepler mission has discovered more than 1,000 confirmed planets orbiting distant stars.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Kepler mission has discovered more than 1,000 confirmed planets orbiting distant stars.

headline: Two Promising Places to Live, 1,200 Light-Years From Earth
abstract: Astronomers working with NASA’s Kepler mission said Thursday that a pair of newly discovered planets in the constellation Lyra appear capable of supporting life.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers said Thursday that they had found the most Earth-like worlds yet known in the outer cosmos, a pair of planets that appear capable of supporting life and that orbit a star 1,200 light-years from here, in the northern constellation Lyra.

headline: From Humiliation to Appreciation
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: My parents agreed that I tied them together for the rest of their lives. Divorce and all, sex change and all, this would be a loving family of three.
lead_paragraph: When I go home to Ohio for the holidays, I spend my time as many 20-somethings do: I sleep like a teenager, wander around my bedroom in my prom dress slightly tipsy, thumb through old yearbooks, and laugh, eat and occasionally bicker with my parents. The only not-typical aspect of my visit is that my parents are two women who are no longer together, one of whom used to be a man.

headline: Theater Talkback: In the Minority
abstract: A writer reflects on what it’s like not to agree with popular opinion, prompted by his lukewarm response to the much-celebrated “Matilda.”
lead_paragraph: I’ll admit, I don’t have it as bad as poor little Matilda. For her assorted deviances from the norm, she is called stupid at home and routinely humiliated at school. I, on the other hand, am merely made to feel uncomfortable, alienated, and perhaps a shade indignant on account of my most recent heresy: I didn’t much like “Matilda the Musical.”

headline: Last Votes Tallied in Gun Debate, Senate Looks to Move On
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate passed amendments on mental health care and penalties for divulging data on gun owners, but any effort to resuscitate the overall legislation seemed distant.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last whimpers of the gun control debate in the Senate played out in anticlimactic fashion on Thursday as lawmakers began the process of formally moving on.

headline: Monetary Fund Chief Warns Against ‘3-Speed’ Recovery
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, instead called for developing nations, the United States and Europe to move to a “full-speed” economy.
lead_paragraph: Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, called for moving the world into a “full-speed recovery” at a news conference on Thursday at the opening of the fund’s annual spring meetings with its sister institution, the World Bank.

headline: Life, Interrupted: A Chat With Suleika
abstract: Suleika Jaouad, “Life, Interrupted” columnist, answers questions about her treatment, why she sometimes takes breaks from writing and her new rescue dog, Oscar.
lead_paragraph: It was just about a year ago when Well readers first met Suleika Jaouad, who at 22 was facing a cancer diagnosis and a potentially lifesaving bone marrow transplant. Her first column “Life, Interrupted: Facing Cancer in Your 20s,” captivated readers and transformed Ms. Jaouad from an unknown writer to a national advocate for young people with cancer.

headline: The Long Celebrity Profile: Endangered, Yes, but Not Yet Dead
abstract: In this age of stage-managed interviews, there are still some celebrity profiles out there worth reading.
lead_paragraph: Recently on the Arts Beat blog, Dwight Garner recommended three collections of classic celebrity profiles — all of which, he notes, were “written before the celebrity-industrial complex was fully formed, when a journalist could still push past an artist’s P.R. phalanx and come back with a story that possessed real feeling and offbeat detail.” (The books in question are Rex Reed’s “People Are Crazy Here,” published 1974; Kenneth Tynan’s “The Sound of Two Hands Clapping,” published 1975; and Michael Lydon’s “Rock Folk: Portraits from the Rock ‘n’ Roll Pantheon,” published 1971.)

headline: Aid Agencies in Gaza Protest New Exit Rules
abstract: The aid organizations said the new permit requirements were an effort by the Hamas-led government to collect information that is none of its business.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — About two dozen international aid agencies that operate in Gaza have suspended travel by their local employees to Israel and the West Bank to protest new exit permit requirements imposed by the Hamas-led government.

headline: Stephen Curry and the Rise of the 3-Pointer
abstract: Golden State’s Stephen Curry set the N.B.A. record for 3-pointers, a shot that has risen in prominence over the past 10 seasons.
lead_paragraph: In the final game of the Golden State Warriors’ regular season, Stephen Curry broke the N.B.A. single-season mark for 3-pointers. His record-setting 270th came with 6:49 left in the second quarter, surpassing Ray Allen’s total from the 2005-6 season, but doing so with 61 fewer attempts.(Curry added two more 3’s later.)

headline: The Small Picture: A Sense of Community
abstract: Every Firehouse Subs restaurant features a custom, hand-painted mural that pays tribute to local firefighters.
lead_paragraph: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: One Man’s Currency Is Another Man’s Bet
abstract: To the faithful, gold is different from any other commodity. But its precipitous rise since the financial crisis, and its recent sharp fall, sure make it look like one.
lead_paragraph: What do you get when you combine evangelical fervor with leverage and rising speculation?

headline: Hello, Dear ‘Friend’?
abstract: Saying hi to ‘friends’; being grilled by the in-laws about money; the etiquette behind watching a wedding online; and what to do with all of those framed photos from relatives.
lead_paragraph: While walking through my neighborhood, I frequently pass familiar faces from high school and college. Often, these old friends have become more distant Facebook friends. Am I obliged to say hello to these people, whose honeymoons and pets are well known to me, even if we haven’t communicated face to face in years?

headline: Sleepy Jones
abstract: Andy Spade debuts a new line of sleepwear, Sleepy Jones, inspired by creative types and meant to be worn whether you’re in the bedroom or not.
lead_paragraph: A nod to the creative types of yore who weren’t afraid to pair intimate apparel with formal dress — the David Hockneys and Pablo Picassos of the world — the new “not-quite-ready-to-wear” label Sleepy Jones launches this week. Designed by Andy Spade, the fashion-world veteran who helped start Kate Spade (his wife’s namesake line) before opening the New York storefront and branding agency Partners & Spade, the colorful collection of men’s and women’s crisp pajama separates and jaunty underwear is meant to encourage luxuriating in the kinds of things that comfortable nightclothes inspire one to do. “Essentially, we’re designing an everyday uniform for reading, writing, painting, pondering and playing — whether you’re in the bedroom or not,” Spade says. With practical and stylish boxers features like a coin pocket for the men and Liberty of London fabric for the women, you may soon find yourself answering the door in your underwear.

headline: Seizing the Day
abstract: Pep Carrió’s new book, “Days,” documents four years of his daily visual meditations.
