abstract: People over age 65 with the lowest incomes rely on Social Security more heavily than people with higher incomes.
lead_paragraph: People over age 65 with the lowest incomes rely on Social Security more heavily than people with higher incomes.

headline: A British Musical Tradition Will Get Airtime in New York
abstract: WQXR will broadcast some of the BBC Proms concerts this summer.
lead_paragraph: Performances from the BBC Proms – an eight-week explosion of daily summer concerts, mostly at the Royal Albert Hall in London – will be broadcast by WQXR, the New York classical radio station, for the first time this summer, in an arrangement made possible by the station’s membership in the European Broadcasting Union.

headline: Park Avenue Armory Names Artists in Residence
abstract: The singer-songwriter Somi, the choreographer Faye Driscoll, the Trusty Sidekick Theater Company and the multidisciplinary artists Ralph Lemon and Okwui Okpokwasili and the visual artist Alex Dolan have been named as the Park Avenue Armory’s 2013 artists-in-residence.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter Somi, the choreographer Faye Driscoll, the Trusty Sidekick Theater Company and the multidisciplinary artists Ralph Lemon and Okwui Okpokwasili, and the visual artist Alex Dolan have been named as the Park Avenue Armory’s 2013 artists in residence. The residencies were established in 2010 and include space at the armory for the research and creation of new projects.

headline: Catching Whatever You Can While You Can
abstract: In “Everything You See,” Vicky Shick’s new dance at Danspace Project, the multiple solos, duets and trios may seem overwhelming but they’re never chaotic.
lead_paragraph: In Vicky Shick’s “Everything You See,” everything you see is intriguing or engrossing, but you can’t see it all.

headline: Military Says Hunger Strike by Detainees Is Growing
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Hunger Strikes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The military confirmed that 63 detainees are on a hunger strike, while defense lawyers contend that most of the 166 prisoners are participating.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY NAVAL BASE, Cuba — The number of detainees at the wartime prison here deemed to be on a hunger strike by the military spiked again on Friday, to 63. Defense lawyers contend that an overwhelming majority of the 166 prisoners have been participating in the protest.

headline: Movie Review | 'The Lords of Salem'
abstract: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews "The Lords of Salem."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews "The Lords of Salem."

headline: Big Ticket | A Reinvented Town House, Sold for $27 Million
abstract: An 1882 Upper East Side town house sold for $27 million after a mid-20th-century overhaul received a 21st-century rejuvenation.
lead_paragraph: An Upper East Side town house that in 1981 received the dreaded thumbs-down designation of being “a no-style structure” from the Landmarks Preservation Commission because of an unloved mid-20th-century revamping, sold for $27 million after undergoing a 21st-century rejuvenation, in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Italian Lawmakers Fail a 4th Time to Elect a President
abstract: The center-left candidate, former Prime Minister Romano Prodi, was unable to muster enough support in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian lawmakers failed for the fourth time to elect a president on Friday when the center-left candidate, former Prime Minister Romano Prodi, was unable to muster enough support among the 1,007 electors in Parliament.

headline: Crossing Dangerous Borders
abstract: Against long odds, the director Mira Nair brings “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” a novel about a long cafe conversation with a possible terrorist, to the big screen.
lead_paragraph: It seems far-fetched that “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” Mohsin Hamid’s 2007 best-selling novel, would be turned into a movie. First, there’s its narrative structure. A young man greets an American tourist in a cafe in the Pakistani city of Lahore and proceeds to tell his life story. That’s the entire book; we never hear from the American or anyone else.

headline: The Fastest Way to Caramelize Garlic
abstract: Melissa Clark shows how to caramelize garlic cloves while keeping their insides soft and sweet.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows how to caramelize garlic cloves while keeping their insides soft and sweet.

headline: A Bit of Kneading but a Lot of Versatility
abstract: Toppings like ramps or sweet rhubarb help turn focaccia from an ephemeral treat into something more memorable.
lead_paragraph: Despite an obsession with pizza and a great love of flatbreads, I’ve spent strangely little time making focaccia.

headline: A Prodigy’s Grownup Pieces
abstract: A concert in the Composer Portraits series at Columbia University’s Miller Theater reviewed the works of Oliver Knussen, the British composer and conductor.
lead_paragraph: It was clear on Thursday night before a concert at Columbia University’s Miller Theater that the Boston Marathon bombing has put security forces everywhere on high alert. Several blocks of Broadway near the entrance to the theater, on 116th Street, were cordoned off by the police. According to an officer, a package had been discovered in the area. After determining there was no danger, the police reopened the street.

headline: Woodson Urges Knicks to Seize Their Opportunity
abstract: At a preplayoffs luncheon, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson planned to emphasize how important this postseason would be for him and each of his players.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – The lunch was more about basketball than the food. After the Knicks practiced for more than two hours Friday, Coach Mike Woodson attended a luncheon with his team and assistant coaches. The team needed to eat, but Woodson wanted, and felt he needed, to emphasize how important this postseason, which starts Saturday, will be for him and each of his players.

headline: A Long Way From Tractors
abstract: Lamborghini, a sports car company started by a tractor maker — quite possibly out of spite — is still thriving after 50 years.
lead_paragraph: After becoming a wealthy industrialist in the 1950s, mainly through the success of his tractor company, Ferruccio Lamborghini was indulging his lifelong love of automobiles and buying Italy’s best: Alfa Romeo, Lancia, Maserati and, of course, Ferrari.

headline: 50 Years of Exotic Appeal
abstract: A gallery of John Lamm’s photographs features some of the highlights of Lamborghini’s colorful history.
lead_paragraph: A gallery of John Lamm’s photographs features some of the highlights of Lamborghini’s colorful history.

headline: Morris J. Kramer, Pioneer in Deal Law, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Kramer, a longtime partner at the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, helped revolutionize the mergers and acquisitions business and prodded Skadden to expand overseas.
lead_paragraph: Morris J. Kramer, who as a longtime partner at the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom helped revolutionize the mergers and acquisitions business, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 71.

abstract: Dealing with an inheritance with restrictions and resolving maintenance fee errors in a co-op.
lead_paragraph: An Inheritance, With Restrictions

headline: Pass the Salt, Dear. Now Let Me Look at That Cut.
abstract: Strindberg’s “Dance of Death” can feel like a turn-of-the-20th-century Scandinavian template for Edward Albee’s “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?”
lead_paragraph: The swirling strains of discordant music in “The Dance of Death,” August Strindberg’s pitch-black drama of domestic strife, come through in muted tones in the new revival from the enterprising Red Bull Theater company that opened Thursday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater, directed by Joseph Hardy and starring Daniel Davis and Laila Robins. Where thundering chords denoting burning hatred and the throes of spiritual despair are indicated, we hear instead the thinner textures of a piano sonata, albeit one liberally laced with dissonance.

abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: Americans Learn of Chechnya
abstract: Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’s editor, speaks to Clifford J. Levy, the former Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, about the Chechen origins of the suspected Boston Marathon bombers,Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’s editor, speaks to Clifford J. Levy, the former Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, about the Chechen origins of the suspected Boston Marathon bombers,Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

headline: Fulfilling Dreams and Nightmares
abstract: Amy Seimetz, who stars in the TV series “The Killing” and the movie “Upstream Color,” has written, produced, directed and coedited the noir “Sun Don’t Shine.”
lead_paragraph: Amy Seimetz has this recurring nightmare. She’s had it since she was a child. It’s a dream about guilt — maybe even about death. On a recent Sunday, on Skype, Ms. Seimetz described the dream. She was in Vancouver, British Columbia, where she’s been shooting new episodes of “The Killing,” and this was her first day off in a while. She ran her hands through her thick blond hair and began to explain.

headline: Revisiting Chechnya
abstract: Thoughts from Elizabeth Rubin on her 2001 magazine article on the conflict in Chechnya.
lead_paragraph: Like everyone else, I woke this morning to news of the shootout and the manhunt in Boston, which was soon followed by the revelation that the two suspects were Chechen — or born to Chechen parents — and that they were raised, before coming to the United States, in Dagestan, which borders Chechnya and was attacked in the late ’90s by Chechen rebels bent on creating a single Islamist state. What I thought of almost immediately was an article that Elizabeth Rubin wrote for this magazine back in the summer of 2001, which I was lucky enough to edit. “Only You Can Save Your Sons” is an extraordinary feat of reporting and writing, as powerful and haunting as any magazine article I’ve ever read. It turned out that other editors here at the magazine were thinking about Elizabeth’s story, too, and as the discussion on Twitter and elsewhere throughout the day turned to questions of whether the Tsarnaev brothers were influenced by the Chechen war — and as the Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, announced that the root of the Tsarnaev’s “evil” lay in America and not in Chechnya — it seemed like a good idea to reach out to Elizabeth and get her thoughts, which follow below, on the Chechnya she experienced then and its connection, or lack of connection, to the men thought to have bombed the Boston Marathon.

headline: From Israel, Breaking Boundaries
abstract: Delicacy was a theme of the evening when the Israeli new-music Meitar Ensemble played new works by Bryan Jacobs, Enda Bates, Ofer Pelz, Marcin Stanczyk and Christopher Bailey.
lead_paragraph: It is normal to be asked to turn off your cellphone before a concert begins. But Yotam Haber, the artistic director of the MATA Festival, went further than that at the festival’s opening concert on Thursday evening at Roulette in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Subway Trains Soon to Stop Again at a Gowanus Station
abstract: Nearly two years after closing for repairs, and one year after it was expected to reopen, the Smith-Ninth Street subway station in Brooklyn will return to service next Friday morning, transit officials said.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years after closing for repairs, and one year after it was expected to reopen, the Smith-Ninth Street subway station in Gowanus, Brooklyn, will return to service next Friday at 10:30 a.m., transit officials said.

headline: An E.V. That Wraps Around a Wheelchair
abstract: Austin-based Community Cars hopes to begin building the Kenguru, a wheelchair-accessible single-passenger vehicle, later this year.
lead_paragraph: For years, Stacy Zoern, a Texas lawyer who lives alone and uses a 400-pound power wheelchair, yearned for more independence. Because of a neuromuscular condition, Ms. Zoern, 33, has never walked, and for a while drove a custom van. But the van was destroyed in a crash, and she didn’t have $80,000 to buy another.

headline: Fertilizers Meet Fire, With Disastrous Consequences
abstract: The devastating explosion in Texas is a reminder that for all the good that fertilizers do in increasing crop yields, they can also prove lethal under certain conditions.
lead_paragraph: While it is still not clear what caused the explosion at a fertilizer plant that killed at least 14 people and destroyed or damaged much of West, Tex., last week, the disaster is a reminder that for all the good that fertilizers do in increasing crop yields, they can also prove lethal under certain conditions.

headline: Caramelized Garlic and Garlic Oil
abstract: This method only caramelizes the cloves around the edges, but the center does mellow and sweeten.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video I demonstrate a short cut method for caramelizing garlic. This is a handy tip for someone who doesn’t want to wait for an entire bulb to slowly roast in the oven, the traditional way of getting garlic that is golden through and through. This method only caramelizes the cloves around the edges. But the center does mellow and sweeten and you can use this this for any recipe that calls for caramelized or roasted garlic, like the one for potato, sage and lemon zest focaccia in my column this week.

headline: Islanders Expect Playoff Atmosphere in Winnipeg
abstract: The Islanders, who are 7-1-1 in their last nine games away from Nassau Coliseum, visit the Jets, who have won six of their last seven at MTS Centre, as both teams battle for a playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Islanders star John Tavares said he expected Saturday’s meeting with the Jets in Winnipeg to have the intensity of a playoff game.

lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: Bereaved and Incited by Malaria
abstract: “Mary and Martha,” a film drama on Saturday night on HBO, enlists Hilary Swank and Brenda Blethyn to highlight the deadly menace posed by malaria.
lead_paragraph: “Mary and Martha,” a message film about the devastation caused by malaria, zeros in on a central part of the problem even while being an example of it.

headline: Budget Negotiating Chip Has Big Downside for Old and Poor
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Social Security (US)', 'Retirement', 'Elderly', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many of those who would be affected by President Obama’s Social Security proposal face higher health costs and have little hope of working again.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has put Social Security on the table in an attempt to reach a bipartisan agreement on the federal budget deficit, a move that would hit the program’s beneficiaries when they are at their most vulnerable.

headline: Magic Potion for a Mom on a Mission
abstract: Jane Seymour plays a mother trying to derail her daughter’s wedding and push her into a performing career in “Lovestruck: The Musical.”
lead_paragraph: “Lovestruck: The Musical” might attract the “Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman” demographic because Jane Seymour is one of its stars and it’s on a network with the word “family” in its name. But any such viewers are likely to be rushing for the remote when the movie reaches a bachelorette-party scene in which young women compare notes on when and how they lost their virginity.

headline: Social Security’s Contribution to Your Income
abstract: This week’s Your Money column discusses a proposal included in President Obama’s budget that would slow the rate at which Social Security benefits increase over time.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column looks at a proposal in President Obama’s budget that would weaken one of Social Security’s best features: the inflation adjustment, which enables retirees to maintain their purchasing power over time.

headline: Son-in-Law of Bin Laden Denied More Phone Calls
abstract: Lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, said one monthly phone call was not sufficient to remain in contact with family members who live in three different countries.
lead_paragraph: Many inmates treasure their ability to call family members, and that appears to be no different for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a prisoner in Manhattan who is also a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, a letter from his lawyers shows.

headline: Brain Research, as Only Vegas Can
abstract: Larry Ruvo knows how to present a flashy Vegas gala, in this case to raise money for the brain research center he founded.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Beyond the booze-soaked Strip, past a thicket of pornography stores and near the Heart Attack Grill, where people who weigh more than 350 pounds eat for free, sits one of the world’s foremost clinics for ... brain health?

headline: Fitness Playgrounds Grow as Machines Go
abstract: Sandbags, ropes and climbing areas are taking over the floor space as part of functional fitness movement.
lead_paragraph: Simple exercises with no-tech equipment (call them paleo or playground exercises, depending on how much fun they are) have long found disciples at niche gyms and in movements such as CrossFit. But in the last year and a half, major health-club chains have begun making hefting sandbags and shaking 25-pound ropes the standard, ditching the fancy weight machines that have dominated gym floors for more than 30 years.

headline: A Mingling of Morocco and Old France
abstract: Tagine Restaurant and Wine Bar has a prewar feel with a North African inflection, and classic dishes and décor.
lead_paragraph: Tagine Restaurant and Wine Bar, the newest venture from the longtime restaurant innovators Jonathan Pratt and Craig Purdy (who together own Peter Pratt’s Inn and Umami Café), brings a North African inflection to traditional French bistro food in Croton-on-Hudson. Mr. Purdy, an enthusiastic traveler, said that he and Mr. Pratt wanted the prewar look of the unpretentious brasseries he came across in Paris, in the Provence region of France and in Morocco. Tagine is not Rick’s Café Américain, but it has many details that recall a time gone by.

headline: An Incubator of Jazz Improvisation
abstract: Karl Berger’s Improvisational Orchestra blended phrases played in unison with expressive solos and duets at ShapeShifter Lab in Brooklyn on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Karl Berger, the jazz pianist, vibraphonist and conductor of improvisers, ran a workshop for his orchestra before its performance at ShapeShifter Lab in Brooklyn on Thursday night. He uses a few simple hand signals for duration, attack and pitch, and the musicians wanted to be sure they were interpreting the specifics correctly. But Mr. Berger seemed more concerned with telling them something very general.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Weightless Water, and Google Meets Wikileaks
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include the growing use of facial recognition software by law enforcement, a transcript of a meeting in 2011 between Julian Assange and Eric Schmidt, and a video that shows how water behaves when gravity isn’t around.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Secret War Heroes, Hiding New Work From Husbands
abstract: World War II codebreakers, all of them women, get together to solve a serial murder in “The Bletchley Circle” on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Churchill called the thousands of puzzle-solvers and clerks who spent World War II at Bletchley Park secretly breaking enemy codes “my geese that laid the golden eggs and never cackled.”

headline: Eating and Drinking Among the Grapes
abstract: A bistro at Chamard Vineyards provides a glorious view of vines, a rustic décor and a locally sourced menu.
lead_paragraph: There’s something glorious about eating amid the grapes in a working vineyard. Though the vines are still bare and the ground is brown at Chamard Vineyards, the view through the windows of the new bistro is exceptional and promises to become even more so as spring takes hold.

headline: When a Pouf Skirt Said It All
abstract: Christian Lacroix’s plan to create a limited line for Schiaparelli has his former customers recalling an era when people with money were eager to show it off in a big way.
lead_paragraph: Every era has a designer who perfectly embodies its ethos. Halston defined the disco days of the late ’70s with velvet hip-huggers and slinky silk shirts. In the early ’80s, Giorgio Armani draped working women in beige power suits.

headline: Friday Night No Music
abstract: Not in the mood.
lead_paragraph: Sorry, but the nightmare in Boston, where I lived for 20 years of my life, has just put me off today; everything I thought about posting felt wrong. I took some time off this afternoon and visited the Tenement Museum, which is better than ever, and I have further thoughts on a bunch of issues; it can all wait for tomorrow.

abstract: In the days immediately after the April 2013 Boston bombing, social media posts by the suspects and their acquaintances provided an early digital portrait of them.
lead_paragraph: In the days immediately after the April 2013 Boston bombing, social media posts by the suspects and their acquaintances provided an early digital portrait of them.

headline: Happiness Inc.
abstract: How the author Sonja Lyubomirsky — a psychology professor who hates smiley faces, kittens and rainbows — has become the latest apostle of mirth.
lead_paragraph: According to Sonja Lyubomirsky, you have a happiness set point. It’s partly encoded in your genes. If something good happens, your sense of happiness rises; if something bad happens, it falls.

headline: Wanting More Work
abstract: About 7.6 million Americans working part-time jobs are doing so reluctantly, and would rather have a full-time job. People stuck in such positions are one reason a broader measure of unemployment — which includes reluctant part-timers as well as people without a job who have looked for work in the past year, but not in the last four weeks — is so much higher than the standard jobless rate, which stands at 7.6 percent.
lead_paragraph: About 7.6 million Americans working part-time jobs are doing so reluctantly, and would rather have a full-time job. lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The judge presiding over the genocide trial of Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, a former Guatemalan dictator, refused Friday to follow another judge’s ruling that would have forced prosecutors to retry the whole case.

headline: Pleasing and Educating the Palate
abstract: Wine bars opened on Long Island in recent months offer extensive selections of wines by the glass, as well as artisanal cheese and charcuterie to pair with them.
lead_paragraph: BABYLON, N.Y. — On a recent evening, Jennifer O’Brien sat on a white leather barstool at Molto Vino, a stylish six-month-old wine bar in Babylon, ready to celebrate her 37th birthday with a girls’ night out. The wine list was handwritten on a smoky mirror behind the polished walnut bar, but she and her four friends relied instead on suggestions offered by the bartender. After the women each chose a glass of wine, they ordered a cheese platter to share.

lead_paragraph: Officials provided the latest information on the search for suspected Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

headline: No Charges for Police Commanders Over Actions During Protests

Muammar el-Qaddafi, into Mexico was released from a Mexican prison on Friday. SNC-Lavalin remains the subject of police investigations in Canada and Switzerland, and two of its former executives have been charged with fraud, conspiracy and forgery in Montreal.

His self-diagnosis was that he was “looking for something,” so he put down his baseball bat and glove for three and a half years and went on a personal journey.

headline: The Music of ‘Flow’
abstract: From Debussy on, non-musical systems have influenced composers. Here’s how Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi’s concept of flow shaped my work for strings.
lead_paragraph: As a composer who studied music and mathematics, I have always found numbers, structure, and science accessible touch-points. But something more interesting evolved over the past several years as I returned to the Hungarian psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi’s work on “flow.” Coined in 1969, he defined flow as “the state in which people are so involved in an activity that nothing else seems to matter.” No surprise then that some of his first participants were composers: this is a constant aspiration. Composers have a reputation for working methods that include long sessions alone in their workplace with intense focus on their work, occasionally — indeed, arguably ideally — eventually losing a sense of time. I was attracted to this idea and felt a kinship, less to my working method but more in the way I thought and organized my music. But how was I to use “flow” in any musically meaningful way?

headline: Becoming Mark Twain
abstract: Before he chose the name Mark Twain in the late winter of 1863, Samuel Langhorne Clemens played at the edges of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: By early February 1863, Samuel Langhorne Clemens must have felt glad that he was more than 18 months removed from any direct participation in the Civil War. No longer risking his life in a guerrilla war in northern Missouri, he was a newspaper editor in the Nevada Territory, causing some local scandals with his acerbic political commentary and tall tales. Although he occasionally wrote about the war raging back East, Clemens mainly focused his columns on mocking the territorial legislature or relating humorous anecdotes about the citizens of Nevada. Surely, though, he must have sometimes thought about his own war experiences in the summer of 1861.

headline: E.P.A. Issues Plan on Tainted Water From Power Plants
abstract: Power producers would have to curb the tainted water they discharge into waterways under a proposal issued by the Environmental Protection Agency on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Power producers would have to curb the tainted water they discharge into waterways under a proposal issued by the Environmental Protection Agency on Friday, the latest in a series of rules focused on utilities that burn coal. The agency proposed four options for regulating the waste from power plants, which are the top source of pollutants in streams, rivers and other waters. The final rules would have the most impact on coal-fired plants, which are the primary source of the pollutants, and would be phased in beginning in 2017. The Sierra Club, which sued the agency to issue the rules, said the announcement was an important step. “When finalized in their strongest form, the Environmental Protection Agency’s common-sense and affordable standards will save lives, prevent children from getting sick, and ensure our water is safe to drink and our fish safe to eat,” said Michael Brune, the group’s executive director.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) SEEKING A FRIEND FOR THE END OF THE WORLD (2012) As global calamity looms, Dodge (Steve Carell), a nebbishy New York insurance salesman whose wife has fled, embarks on a road trip with the girl next door (Keira Knightley, above with Mr. Carell) to find his long-lost high school love in this comedy directed by Lorene Scafaria. Connie Britton, Rob Corddry and Patton Oswalt round out the cast as Dodge’s friends, who encourage him to react to imminent doom the way they would: by throwing off all inhibitions. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film a “sweet, whimsical and seriously misguided romp through end times, which goes very gentle into that good night.” The problem is not that Ms. Scafaria “takes her grave subject too lightly,” he said. “Laughter is an entirely appropriate response to something so abstractly awful as an unstoppable meteor speeding toward earth.” But, he added, “it seems downright unfair that billions of people have to die so that a middle-aged sad sack can cop a cuddle with a cute, younger bohemian neighbor.”

lead_paragraph: On the streets of Watertown, Mass., residents and police officers celebrated after a suspect was brought into custody.

headline: Rape of 5-Year-Old Girl Sets Off New Furor in India
abstract: An attack and the police response struck a chord in the nation, still dealing with the trauma of another brutal rape case.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Hundreds of demonstrators besieged New Delhi’s police headquarters on Saturday to protest the kidnapping, rape and torture of a 5-year-old girl last week.

headline: Meanwhile, Sunil Tripathi Is Still Missing
abstract: Family of missing Indian American student horrified to see his name falsely connected with Boston attacks.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK CITY —In a bizarre twist in an ongoing mysterious yet tragic story, Sunil Tripathi, the 22-year-old Brown University student who has been missing since March 16, was one of America’s most wanted criminals for several hours early Friday, at least in the eyes of the media. The 6’2’’ 130-pound senior, who is from Radnor, Pa., and has an Indian father and an American mother, was falsely cited on social media as one of the Boston Marathon bombers before his name was cleared in connection with the attacks.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 20
abstract: Arrest in Boston bombing; new risky investments; drug maker under scrutiny, and moves against tax evasion.
lead_paragraph: The teenage suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, whose flight from the police after a furious gunfight overnight prompted an intense manhunt that virtually shut down the Boston area all day, was taken into custody Friday night after the police found him in nearby Watertown, Mass., officials said. The suspect, Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, 19, was found hiding in a boat just outside the area where the police had been conducting door-to-door searches all day, the Boston police commissioner, Edward Davis, said at a news conference Friday night. Katharine Q. Seelye reports from Boston and William K. Rashbaum and Michael Cooper report from New York.

headline: Bombing Inquiry Turns to Motive and Russian Trip
abstract: With one suspect dead and the other lying wounded in a hospital, the investigation into the Boston bombings turned to the men’s motives, and to a trip one of them took to Chechnya and Dagestan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With one suspect dead and the other captured and lying grievously wounded in a hospital, the investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings turned on Saturday to questions about the men’s motives, and to the significance of an overseas trip one of them took last year.

headline: Ex-President of Pakistan Ordered Held 2 More Weeks
abstract: Pervez Musharraf, the country’s former military leader, is expected to face charges on May 4 over his decision to fire senior judges while he was president in 2007.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani antiterrorism court on Saturday extended by two weeks the detention of the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf, ensuring that the legal wrangling surrounding the retired general will continue in the run-up to elections on May 11.

headline: The Non-Secret of Our Non-Success

lead_paragraph: Chris Giles of the FT reports that central bankers are worried that they are “flying blind”; he quotes Lorenzo Bibi-Smaghi, formerly of the ECB governing board, saying “We don’t fully understand what is happening in advanced economies.”

headline: The Good Glitch
abstract: Trivial breaks through where years of analysis didn’t.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been cynical about the likelihood that the Reinhart-Rogoff fiasco would lead to any real change in policy, and I still have doubts. But reflecting on the debate so far, I’m wondering a bit if I have been too cynical — or at any rate, cynical in the wrong way. For my vague, unquantifiable sense is that the debacle is changing the conversation quite a lot, even among the guys in suits. And it was the coding error that did it.

headline: Suspects With Foot in 2 Worlds, Perhaps Echoing Plots of Past
abstract: The case of the Boston suspects recalls that of other young men who, caught between life in America and loyalty to fellow Muslims in a distant homeland, turned to violence.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was assigned by his high school English teacher to write an essay on something he felt passionate about, he chose the troubled land of his ancestors: Chechnya. He wrote to Brian Glyn Williams, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth.

headline: Mike Mills: A Rock Star of Fantasy Sports
keywords: ['Fantasy Sports', 'Baseball', 'Music', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Mike Mills has increased his fantasy team activity since R.E.M. broke up in 2011. “There is nobody I know who is into it like I am,” he said.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Mike Mills rose from a chair and strolled out to his car, but not to fetch a musical instrument to perform songs from the catalog of R.E.M., his seminal alternative-rock band. A fantasy draft of Masters golfers, involving Mills and a dozen others at a house not far from Augusta National Golf Club, had just concluded. And with baseball games in the East winding down, Mills was retrieving a laptop to take stock of his fantasy teams.

Inside, on a recent morning, psychologists and social workers were leading group therapy sessions for inmates in large, brightly lighted rooms while individual meetings were being held in smaller offices.

headline: With Rangers, Nash Still Finds Playoffs Playing Hard to Get

lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be easy for Rick Nash this year with the Rangers, but he is the protagonist in another uphill struggle to the playoffs, as he has been every season since joining the N.H.L. in 2002.

headline: Mixed Martial Artist Is Mighty, Yet Measured
abstract: Although Jon Jones contends “I don’t enjoy hitting people; I enjoy outsmarting them,” there are far more accurate representations of his strategy and tactics.
lead_paragraph: Jon Jones’s signature move, the spinning elbow, is a relatively high-risk martial arts strike that he delivers toward an opponent’s head with no regard for his own safety. It’s the kind of maneuver that can make a highlight show — for better or worse.

headline: A Texas Town Mourns the First Responders Who Paid With Their Lives

abstract: Days after a fertilizer plant explosion destroyed homes and killed at least 14 in West, Tex., the magnitude of the human toll had barely started to settle in.
lead_paragraph: WEST, Tex. — Three-tenths of a mile from this town’s own ground zero, barely more than 24 hours after an explosion at a fertilizer plant tore through people’s houses and hearts, dozens of firefighters and emergency responders stood at attention.

headline: Two Cheers for Web U!
abstract: Take away the dorm rooms, the classroom banter, the brown-nosing, the keg parties and the tuition, and is it still college?
lead_paragraph: I LEARNED many fascinating things while taking a series of free online college courses over the last few months. In my history class, I learned there was a Japanese political plot to assassinate Charlie Chaplin in 1932. In my genetics class, I learned that the ability to wiggle our ears is a holdover from animal ancestors who could shift the direction of their hearing organs.

headline: Moving Ahead With Common Core
abstract: Test scores will fall at first in schools where the new and more rigorous state tests have been rolled out, but the long-term payoff is what matters.
lead_paragraph: New York City parents are understandably nervous about tough new state tests that were rolled out last week. And some parents whose children have already taken the tests are outraged. They shouldn’t be: the tests, which measure math and English skills, are an essential part of rigorous education reforms known as Common Core that seek to improve reasoning skills and have been adopted by 45 states.

headline: The Right to Remain Silent
abstract: The Supreme Court should extend the right to silence to questioning that happens before a suspect is arrested and given Miranda warnings.
lead_paragraph: Under the Constitution’s Fifth Amendment, no one can be compelled to be a witness against himself in a criminal case. The prosecution cannot use a defendant’s decision not to testify in court as evidence of guilt. Nor, as a result of the landmark Miranda case, can it use as evidence of guilt a suspect’s decision to remain silent after being arrested.

headline: The Man Who Saved CUNY
abstract: Matthew Goldstein elevated academic standards at the City University of New York during his tenure and made it a more vital institution.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Goldstein walked into a deeply troubled place when he became chancellor of the City University of New York 14 years ago. The political infighting and chaotic management at CUNY had become so destructive that a task force report described it as “an institution adrift,” one caught “in a spiral of decline.” Now, after successfully reorganizing what had become a disjointed academic jumble and slowly restoring the prestige of a giant public university that serves nearly half a million students, Mr. Goldstein has said he will retire this summer.

headline: Immigration and Fear

abstract: Want a safer country and stronger rule of law? Pass comprehensive immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: Much of the country was still waking up to the mayhem and confusion outside Boston on Friday morning when Senator Charles Grassley decided to link the hunt for terrorist bombers to immigration reform.

headline: A New, Flexible Kerry
abstract: On a trip through Asia, the outlines of John Kerry’s style of diplomacy emerged.
lead_paragraph: John Kerry made his first trip to Asia as secretary of state this month amid rising tensions with North Korea and returned home on Monday with things a bit quieter, although with North Korea nobody really knows what’s next. Bouncing from Seoul to Beijing to Tokyo, the new secretary showed a commendable impulse for common-sense diplomacy, including engagement with adversaries like the North. The policy questions are: Will a White House with a proclivity for adversarial responses support his diplomatic approach? And how well will it play not only in the Oval Office but with troublesome states like North Korea?

See below for a full roster of teams and participants, and you can read our blog post from earlier this week for more details about Editors’ Lab and the Global Editors Network.

headline: Daring to Knock on the Boardroom Door

lead_paragraph: STEVEN ROMICK didn’t set out to be a shareholder activist. As managing partner of First Pacific Advisors and overseer of the $11 billion FPA Crescent fund, Mr. Romick has more than enough on his plate. Keeping a low profile is usually fine with him.

headline: Doubted by Scouts, a College Ace Rises Quickly
abstract: Michael Roth, a ninth-round pick, became the first American League player from the 2012 draft class to reach the majors.
lead_paragraph: Michael Roth pitched his first game above rookie ball on April 9, working five innings for the Class AA Arkansas Travelers. Three nights later, after a game in Frisco, Tex., Roth was called into an office with Manager Tim Bogar and the pitching coach, Mike Hampton. He had no reason to expect what was coming.

headline: Some Iraqis Doubt Benefits of First Vote Since U.S. Departure
abstract: Limiting violence is one gauge of success, but observers are also waiting to see whether the results will embolden the prime minister to expand power along sectarian lines.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq held its first election since the withdrawal of American troops under security so tight on Saturday that the only way for many voters to reach polling places was to walk. But the election, for local councils, was carried out largely free of violence, even as apathy prevailed among many Iraqis who questioned what benefits they have received from a young democracy still marred by political dysfunction, corruption and violence.

headline: The Tangle of the Sexes
abstract: The Mars/Venus view of men and women describes a world that does not exist, at least here on earth.
lead_paragraph: MEN and women are so different they might as well be from separate planets, so says the theory of the sexes famously explicated in John Gray’s 1992 best seller, “Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus.”

headline: How to Put America Back Together Again
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Global Warming', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: We need to redouble our efforts to make our country stronger and healthier. A good place to start is with a carbon tax.
lead_paragraph: UNTIL we fully understand what turned two brothers who allegedly perpetrated the Boston Marathon bombings into murderers, it is hard to make any policy recommendation other than this: We need to redouble our efforts to make America stronger and healthier so it remains a vibrant counterexample to whatever bigoted ideology may have gripped these young men. With all our warts, we have built a unique society — a country where a black man, whose middle name is Hussein, whose grandfather was a Muslim, can run for president and first defeat a woman in his own party and then four years later a Mormon from the opposition, and no one thinks twice about it. With so many societies around the world being torn apart, especially in the Middle East, it is vital that America survives and flourishes as a beacon of pluralism.

headline: Maya Angelou
abstract: Some of Maya Angelou’s pleasures: Poe, Bach, Chopin, country music, watching people dance and chardonnay.
lead_paragraph: Maya Angelou is a best-selling author, poet, historian, civil rights activist, playwright, actress, filmmaker and professor. Her most recent book, “Mom & Me & Mom,” was published this month.

headline: In New York, No Ping to the Sound of Bat Hitting Ball
abstract: In 2007, safety concerns prompted the New York City Council to require public high school teams to return to wood bats, overriding the veto of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: The old-fashioned crack of bats hitting baseballs has returned in force this spring in New York, as youth baseball leagues, especially in Brooklyn, have been shifting away from metal bats. The latest to change is the Prospect Park Baseball Association, among the city’s largest youth organizations with about 2,100 players, which switched to wood bats for those as young as 9 this season.

lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Worlds Away From Here
abstract: Amid a miserable week on Earth, a glimpse of distant planets.
lead_paragraph: AND now for some counterprogramming. You probably missed it, what with the Boston Marathon bombing, the ricin-laced letters, the fertilizer plant explosion and an entire city locked down while cops hunted the bombing suspect, but we discovered another world last week. Two, actually — both somewhat larger than Earth, circling a star with the sadly unromantic name of Kepler 62, 1,200 light-years away.

headline: Is It Time for Off-the-Shelf Birth-Control Pills?
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Oral contraceptives are arguably safer than many over-the-counter medicines.
lead_paragraph: WHEN a federal judge recently ordered the Food and Drug Administration to make the morning-after pill available to women of all ages without a prescription, the ruling was a political embarrassment for the Obama administration and unleashed protests from abortion foes and abstinence advocates. But that controversy may look like a tempest in a teapot compared with a broader and no less heated discussion that is roiling the medical community: should birth-control pills of any type require a doctor’s prescription? Or should they be available, like Tylenol, on pharmacy shelves?

headline: The Benefits of Church
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Going to church is good for your health. The exact reasons are unclear, but there are several likely explanations.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the most striking scientific discoveries about religion in recent years is that going to church weekly is good for you. Religious attendance — at least, religiosity — boosts the immune system and decreases blood pressure. It may add as much as two to three years to your life. The reason for this is not entirely clear.

headline: Boston Attacks Turn Spotlight on Troubled Region of Chechnya
abstract: With the Chechen background of the suspects in the Boston attacks, questions arise about a connection to the bloody conflict in the Russian republic of Chechnya, which has appeared calm for some time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The possible motivations of the two brothers linked to the Boston Marathon bombings are as yet publicly unknown. Of Chechen heritage, they lived in the United States for years, according to friends and relatives, and no direct ties have been publicly established with known Chechen terrorist or separatist groups.

headline: Nets’ Ploy: Intimidate With Shirts

lead_paragraph: Barclays Center has a somewhat forbidding atmosphere for visiting teams. The music pumped through the arena’s loudspeakers, hand-selected by the mix-tape artist J. Period, has an aggressive attitude. The black-clad Brooklynettes dance team has a decidedly adult attitude. And the Nets, in black home uniforms that are in stark contrast with typical N.B.A. fashion, certainly look tough, even if their game is based on offensive execution more than any sort of intimidation.

headline: A New Nets Era, but Much Has Been Left Behind

headline: Need Motivation? Declare a Deadline
abstract: If you’re a procrastinator, consider setting deadlines for yourself that have tough consequences if you miss them.
lead_paragraph: AT a meeting last Tuesday, I told my colleagues that I would finish this column — which is about deadlines — by noon on Thursday. I spent part of Tuesday afternoon searching the word “deadlines” on Google, but didn’t make much progress. By late afternoon, I felt a tiny knot of fear in my stomach. What if I let my co-workers down? So I wrote something silly just to get started. This paragraph.

headline: Before Housing Bubbles, There Was Land Fever
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Land Use Policies', 'United States Economy', 'Series']

headline: In Memory of a Friend, Teacher and Mentor
abstract: A eulogy for Philip Roth’s homeroom teacher, his legendary and noble friend Bob Lowenstein.
lead_paragraph: I WAS 12 years old when I entered the Hawthorne Avenue Annex in February 1946. The Annex, a 15-minute bus ride for me from the main high school, was where you went in those days as a freshman at Newark’s Weequahic High. The first teacher I had to face on the first hour of my first day at the Annex was Bob Lowenstein. Dr. Lowenstein. Doc Lowenstein. He was fresh from serving in World War II, unlike most high school teachers he was unassumingly in possession of a Ph.D., and what was recognizable even to a 12-year-old was that this was a formidable man who did not gladly suffer fools.
