lead_paragraph: Megan Joan Roberts and Philip Matthew Mabe Jr. were married Saturday at Skytop Lodge, a resort in Skytop, Pa. The Rev. Bethany A. Hannon, an aunt of the bride and a minister in the Church of the Movement of Spiritual Inner Awareness in Los Angeles, officiated.

headline: Melissa Williams, John Omartian
abstract: The bride is the Sierra Club’s political director; the groom is an information technology consultant.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Mae Williams and John Crawford Aram Omartian were married Saturday at the Inn at Willow Grove in Orange, Va. Donald L. Hughes, a marriage commissioner of Orange County, Va., officiated at a secular ceremony that was led by Antha Nicole Williams, the bride’s sister. The ceremony included a reading of “Union,” an essay by Robert Fulghum.

headline: Lancy Fuller and Matthew Wright
abstract: The bride is a media manager for an advertising agency, and the groom is a content manager for a company that writes articles for real estate Web sites and magazines.
lead_paragraph: Lancy Denise Fuller and Matthew Keith Wright were married Saturday evening at the Gwinnett Environmental and Heritage Center in Buford, Ga. The Rev. Bobby Bolton, a minister at Victory World Church, officiated.

headline: Lincy Cherian, Michael Hartman
abstract: The bride is a pediatrician on Long Island, and the groom is a lawyer in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lincy Ann Cherian and Michael Patrick Hartman were married Saturday in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Michael Lopez, a minister affiliated with All Saints Universal Church, officiated.

headline: Penelope Daulton, Thom Sesma
abstract: The bride, the company manager for the Broadway production of “Lucky Guy,” and the groom, an actor, met in 2002 when he was in the Broadway revival of “Man of La Mancha” and she was its company manager.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Oldham Daulton and Thom Sesma were married Saturday at St. Malachy’s, a Roman Catholic Church in New York known as the Actors’ Chapel. The Rev. Richard D. Baker, its pastor, performed the ceremony with assistance from the Rev. George Drance, a Roman Catholic priest.

headline: Writing His Way Into Her Heart
abstract: The bride is an actress; the groom is a playwright and teaches screen and playwriting to high school students.
lead_paragraph: Blair Courtney Baker, a daughter of Wendy A. Baker and Douglas C. Baker of Altadena, Calif., is to be married Sunday to Zachary Wolf Kline, the son of Thomas R. Kline of Philadelphia and the late Paula Wolf Kline. Rabbi Melissa Buyer is to officiate in the New York apartment owned by the groom’s father.

headline: In China, the Shared Grief of Losing a Single Child Like Lu Lingzi
abstract: With their daughter’s death in the Boston Marathon attack, the parents of Lu Lingzi joined a growing group in China — parents who lose a single child in a country that mandates one child for many.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a dignified letter, the parents of Lu Lingzi, the 23-year-old Chinese student killed in the Boston Marathon attack, asked people to remember their daughter by helping “make the world a better place,” as she had wanted to.

headline: Clowning Around
abstract: Kim Jong-un’s nuclear act fails to convince China or the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un’s nuclear act fails to convince China or the U.S.

headline: Hagel, in Israel, Presses U.S. Agenda on Deterring Iran
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel argued for patience in dealing with Iran but emphasized Israel’s right to self-defense.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel opened a weeklong visit to the Middle East on Sunday by pressing an American agenda focused on deterring Iran — including a significant new weapons deal for Israel — coupled with a strong caution that it would be premature for Israel to opt for unilateral strikes on Tehran’s nuclear program.

headline: No City for Little Boys
abstract: Little boys like mine need to move their bodies, to explore and wrestle and chase each other around. They need to shake the ants out of their pants, and city life just doesn’t allow for it.
lead_paragraph: We live in New York City by choice. The idea was that it would be an informative experience for our children. City kids are hip and cultured and privileged to a purview that inspires worldliness. For the most part, I agree with those points, but I’m starting to think that, ultimately, this is not the best place for little boys to be raised.

headline: San Francisco Hangout Becomes Casualty of Tech Boom
abstract: Residents see the closure of a popular San Francisco restaurant as the latest confirmation that the tech boom has made their city unlivable, and is pricing long-time businesses and residents out of the market.
lead_paragraph: Since 1999, The Grove restaurant, with its warm, woodsy interior and comfort food, has marketed itself as “San Francisco’s living room.” Its customers, who have a habit of lingering for hours, seem to agree.

headline: A Deal That Seemed Inevitable: Revis Is a Buccaneer
abstract: The Buccaneers acquired the Jets’ All-Pro cornerback, Darrelle Revis, who agreed to terms with Tampa Bay on a new long-term contract, for six years and $96 million.
lead_paragraph: The day after the Jets’ season ended, cornerback Darrelle Revis said he expected to play for the team in 2013. More than that, Revis said that he wanted to lead the Jets’ return to prominence and that there was “nowhere else” he would rather be.

headline: Editors’ Lab: Newsgaming Ideas
abstract: Here’s a summary of the ideas generated on day one of the Editors’ Lab hack event at the Times building.
lead_paragraph: The latest hack event in the Editors’ Lab series kicked off yesterday at the Times building. Eleven media teams got right to work and generated some ideas on the theme of “newsgaming.” Project ideas are subject to change, but here’s a summary of the brain waves thus far:

headline: On the Train, or at the Laundromat, Your Poem Begins … Now
abstract: The performance group Poets in Unexpected Places has been using its ties to a thriving poetry slam community to encourage others to deliver their works in public.
lead_paragraph: New York City is invited to a poetry reading.

headline: Scientific Management Redux: The Difference Is in the Data
abstract: Companies are increasingly using data-driven testing and measurement in the hiring and evaluation of employees — a field called work force science. The enthusiasm for worker measurement and testing is not new, but the ability to collect and mine so much data on worker behavior is. It could open the door to new insights into what makes workers productive, innovative and happy on the job.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a Sunday column about the rise of what is being called “work force science.” Lots of companies are embracing the trend, but anyone familiar with business history might reasonably ask, What’s really new here?

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13, 49) THE BLETCHLEY CIRCLE Nine years after putting their extraordinary talents to use at Bletchley Park, Britain’s code-breaking headquarters during World War II, four seemingly ordinary women piece together clues they hope will solve a series of murders. Leading the charge is Susan (Anna Maxwell Martin, above), now a homemaker and mother of two, who wangles her way into Scotland Yard when she thinks she has detected a pattern to the killings. But when the police dismiss her theory, she turns for assistance to her former colleagues — Millie (Rachael Stirling), conversant in 14 languages and good with maps; Lucy (Sophie Rundle), with her photographic memory; and Jean (Julie Graham), their onetime supervisor — who, like Susan, have returned to civilian life and kept their intelligence work secret from even those closest to them. “While the solving of the mystery is fairly conventional, these amateur detectives aren’t,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. The three-part mystery “doesn’t have a preachy tone, but it does have a message, and it’s similar to the one in ‘Call the Midwife,’ “ the British series, leading in at 8, “that follows young nurses who after the war helped women in the poorest sections of London deliver babies, usually in tenement homes, on top of rags and newspapers,” she said, adding that “both series find a clever, entertaining way to pay tribute to women who in their time were often overlooked and underestimated, and nevertheless found ways to never be ordinary.”

headline: Destructive Creativity
abstract: Plain ordinary macro has worked fine.
lead_paragraph: Still thinking my way through the Reinhart-Rogoff debacle and related issues, and I think there’s an important point to be made here about the state of macroeconomics.

headline: Kerry Asks Turkish Leader to Postpone Trip to Gaza
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concern that a visit by Turkey’s leader could harm efforts to restart the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday that he had urged Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to put off his visit to Gaza to avoid disrupting efforts to revive peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Small Majority Approved of Miranda Rights for Terror Suspects
abstract: Surveys conducted when this debate was last in the news found that a small majority of Americans favored informing terrorism suspects of their Miranda rights.
lead_paragraph: The capture of Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, 19, a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, has revived a debate over how terrorism cases are handled in the United States, including whether suspected terrorists should be read their Miranda rights, which include the right to an attorney and the right to remain silent, and how quickly.

headline: ‘Oblivion’ Tops Weekend Box Office
abstract: Tom Cruise’s latest big-screen adventure was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, with ticket sales of about $38.2 million.
lead_paragraph: The celebrity tabloids continue to pick apart Tom Cruise; moviegoers continue not to care. “Oblivion,” Mr. Cruise’s latest big-screen adventure, was a stronger-than-expected No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, with ticket sales of about $38.2 million.

headline: Barbra Streisand in Pictures
abstract: A look back at the career of Barbra Streisand, who is being honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the career of Barbra Streisand, who is being honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Boston Begins to Say Goodbye to Victims of the Bombings
abstract: Bostonians received assurance that danger is past, but the investigation continued, with officials struggling to learn whether the two suspects had help or operated alone.
lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Mass. — Boston began to say goodbye on Sunday to those it lost last week. Its leaders — religious as well as political — fanned out, in front of naves and cameras, to do what they could to reassure grieving parishioners and constituents that the danger had passed. Or that for those who are gone, “life,” as Cardinal Sean P. O’Malley put it, “is not ended, merely changed.”

headline: Taliban Attacks in Northwest Pakistan Are Reshaping Ballot
abstract: An intense campaign of attacks in the region has all but derailed the governing party and has struck fear in its candidates.
lead_paragraph: NOWSHERA, Pakistan — When Shahid Khan started talking, his gunmen clambered onto a school’s rooftop, scanning the surrounding hills with flashlights, anticipating a possible attack.

headline: City Report Shows More Were Near Poverty in 2011
abstract: An analysis by the Bloomberg administration says that almost half of New York City’s population was poor or near-poor in 2011, raising concerns about any cutbacks in federal relief programs.
lead_paragraph: The rise in New York City’s poverty rate as a result of the recession has apparently eased, but not before pushing nearly half of the city’s population into the ranks of the poor or near-poor in 2011, according to an analysis by the Bloomberg administration.

headline: China Presses Crackdown on Campaign Against Graft
abstract: Six more activists were detained after demanding that Communist Party officials disclose their personal wealth, another sign of the limits of the leadership’s war on graft.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have detained six anticorruption activists in recent days, expanding their crackdown on a citizen-led campaign that, on the surface at least, would appear to dovetail with the new leadership’s war on official graft.

headline: Mets Designate Laffey in Anticipation of Marcum’s Debut
abstract: The Mets recalled the left-hander Robert Carson from the minors and designated the left-hander Aaron Laffey for assignment. The move reflected the expectation that Shaun Marcum would be ready to make his debut Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Mets recalled the left-hander Robert Carson from the minors and designated the left-hander Aaron Laffey for assignment.

headline: The 6 People Streisand Wants at Her Dinner Party
abstract: Ahead of receiving a lifetime achievement award from the Film Society of Lincoln Center, Barbra Streisand answered some questions from Times readers.
lead_paragraph: At a gala on Monday night Barbra Streisand will receive the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Chaplin Award for lifetime achievement. The society cited in particular her work on “Yentl,” the first movie to credit a woman as director, writer, producer and star, along with other big-screen turns behind the camera (“Prince of Tides” and “The Mirror Has Two Faces”) and in front of it (“Funny Girl” and “For Pete’s Sake”).

headline: A Comedy Show That Comes via a Hashtag
abstract: Comedy Central will use Twitter to host a comedy festival. The partnership between the two companies represents the evolving relationship between television and social media.
lead_paragraph: Next week, Comedy Central will host a five-day comedy festival that includes a lineup of legends like Mel Brooks and Carl Reiner alongside popular young comics like Amy Schumer and the director Paul Feig.

headline: Luis Suárez Bites an Opponent, Again
abstract: Liverpool striker Luis Suárez appeared to bite Chelsea defender Branislav Ivanovic during their Premier League game on Sunday, the latest shocking on-field decision for a player who has made a career out of them.
lead_paragraph: Video: Suarez bites Ivanovic?

headline: Festive and Defiant, London Runs a Marathon for Boston
abstract: Six days after the Boston bombings, the London Marathon was held Sunday with no security scares and the minds of nearly all on the victims of last week’s attack.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Six days and 3,300 miles from the bombings in Boston, the London Marathon was held Sunday under an azure sky, in what runners called perfect conditions, with no security scares and the minds of virtually all involved soaring westward to the victims of last Monday’s attack.

headline: Greenhouse for French Baroque Opera
abstract: William Christie and his ensemble Les Arts Florissants presented “Le Jardin de Monsieur Rameau,” a program of semi-staged French Baroque opera selections by Rameau and his contemporaries.
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening the conductor William Christie and his period-instrument ensemble Les Arts Florissants presented “Le Jardin de Monsieur Rameau” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a program of semi-staged French Baroque opera selections by Rameau and his contemporaries. The title, “The Garden of Mr. Rameau,” is a pun on Mr. Christie’s vocal training program, Le Jardin des Voix (The Garden of Voices), which in turn alludes to the “flowering” of the instrumental group’s name, itself taken from a Charpentier opera.

headline: A Table for One, Please
abstract: Rosie Herrera’s “Dining Alone” was inspired by what she saw as a child in her father’s restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Before the official start of Rosie Herrera’s “Dining Alone” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Friday night, one of its performers, the debonair Octavio Campos, was already planted at the head of a long table and speaking to his guests. But there was a catch. Mr. Campos’s friends were life-size cutouts.

headline: Boldly Navigating Schumann’s Forest
abstract: Mitsuko Uchida set the parameters of the Germanic keyboard tradition with works by Bach, Schoenberg and Schumann at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Mitsuko Uchida can easily fill Carnegie Hall with a blockbuster program: the last three piano sonatas of Schubert, say, which she played in 2012, or the last three of Beethoven, which she performed there most recently in 2009. But this superb pianist showed on Thursday evening that her fan base will by now follow wherever she wants to go.

headline: A Moment of Silence in London
abstract: London Marathon runners observed a moment of silence on Sunday to honor the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings.
lead_paragraph: London Marathon runners observed a moment of silence on Sunday to honor the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings.

headline: The Way to Slay Wagner’s Dragon
abstract: Robert Lepage’s production of Wagner’s “Siegfried” returns to the Metropolitan Opera stage.
lead_paragraph: In Wagner’s “Siegfried” the young title hero eventually learns the meaning of fear. It seems believable that he manages to emerge confidently from his encounter with the cartoonish dragon of Robert Lepage’s staging, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon with Jay Hunter Morris in the role. That he succumbs to fear in the final scene, however, seemed less credible.

headline: Exploring Some Ties, People and Situations That Bind
abstract: Jasmin Vardimon Company of London made a rare American appearance, at Montclair State University in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The choreographer Jasmin Vardimon, born in Israel, formed her company in 1997 in London, where she has found much popular success and a post as associate artist at Sadler’s Wells. Except for once, in Texas, though, her troupe had not appeared in the United States until a run last week in the Peak Performances series at Montclair State University here. First impression: Ms. Vardimon is familiar with the work of Pina Bausch.

headline: How Shakespeare Shuffled Off This Mortal Coil
abstract: “The Last Will,” directed by and starring Austin Pendleton, is Robert Brustein’s speculation on the death, and bequests, of William Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: Robert Brustein lovingly kills off William Shakespeare in “The Last Will,” a speculative version of the end of Shakespeare’s life that completes Mr. Brustein’s trilogy on him.

headline: Slaughter Reported Near Damascus
abstract: Syrian opposition activists said Sunday that government forces had killed at least 80 people in Jdaidet al-Fadl and then made mass arrests as residents tried to bury the bodies.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian opposition activists said Sunday that government forces had killed at least 80 people in a town south of Damascus, and then carried out mass arrests as the residents tried to bury the bodies.

headline: Lopez and Nets Dominate Game 1, but Their Work Is Not Finished
abstract: Brook Lopez repeatedly sneaked undetected into the heart of the Bulls’ defense, but Coach Tom Thibodeau is expected to make adjustments to limit Lopez in Game 2 on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: At 7 feet tall, with broad shoulders and tree-trunk legs, Brook Lopez is massive even by N.B.A. standards. But in the Nets’ 106-89 Game 1 victory against the Chicago Bulls on Saturday night at Barclays Center, Lopez repeatedly sneaked undetected into the heart of the Bulls’ defense. He had six layups in the first half alone, often by expertly drifting to the blind spots of Bulls defenders to create passing angles for his teammates.

headline:
Struggle at Home
Intrudes on Chechen
Haven in America
abstract: After the suspects in the Boston bombings were identified as being of Chechen origin, Chechens in the United States said the attack had left them feeling exposed and embarrassed.
lead_paragraph: NEEDHAM, Mass. — Four days after the Boston Marathon bombings, Ali Tepsurkaev was at work on a construction site on Nantucket when his boss approached him to deliver the news: the two prime suspects had been identified as ethnic Chechens.

headline: Police Release Thermal Imaging Video of Boston Suspect’s Capture
abstract: The Massachusetts State Police released new video showing the final moments of Friday night’s standoff with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, before he was taken into custody.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts State Police on Sunday released new video showing the final moments of Friday night’s standoff with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, before he was taken into custody.

headline: Mets Get Contributions From Unlikely Sources, Including a National
abstract: The back end of the Mets’ rotation, their bullpen and their defense all played crucial roles in taking the rubber game of a series against one of the league’s elite teams.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ 2-0 victory against the Washington Nationals on Sunday afternoon was formed from an amalgam of strange and pleasant surprises.

headline: Appalachian Strains With a Bach Twist
abstract: Ben Sollee, the cellist-singer-songwriter and the closing performer for this season of the American Songbooks series, performed at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The environment of his native state of Kentucky is a palpable presence in the lyrics of the singer, songwriter and cellist Ben Sollee, whose concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday evening was the season finale of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series. In “Prettiest Tree on the Mountain,” the image of a former lover, a redhead who moved to California, was compared to a glimpse of a robin outside his window and to the reddening of leaves as he walks through the hills.

headline: After Freedom, Peace Is at Stake
abstract: “Rectify,” the Sundance Channel’s first wholly owned drama series, is about a Georgia man who is freed after 19 years on death row.
lead_paragraph: “Rectify,” a new series about a Georgia man who is freed after 19 years on death row, traces the history of the Sundance Channel in reverse. For about an episode and a quarter, it’s very good television. But over the rest of its six-episode first season it resembles nothing so much as a bad indie film, the kind of slow and tepid bummer that used to fill Sundance’s late nights and afternoons when it was a full-time movie channel.

headline: Nova Loses Control, and Yankees Lose Finale
abstract: The struggling Blue Jays scored four times in the sixth inning to salvage the final game of their three-game series with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Ivan Nova knew that the best words to describe some of his errant pitches this season, including a few on Sunday, would not have been appropriate for the television camera that was trained on his face. He refrained from using them but left no doubt about their content.

headline: A Chechen Family Reacts to Bombings
abstract: A Chechen family that settled in the suburbs of Boston over a decade ago is particularly disheartened to hear that the marathon bombing suspects have been linked to Chechnya.
lead_paragraph: A Chechen family that settled in the suburbs of Boston over a decade ago is particularly disheartened to hear that the marathon bombing suspects have been linked to Chechnya.

headline: Russia Wins NEC Cup in Yokohama
abstract: The final of the NEC Cup in Yokohama, Japan, on Sunday was easily won by Russia.
lead_paragraph: The final of the NEC Cup in Yokohama, Japan, on Sunday was easily won by Russia: Andrei Gromov, Alexander Dubinin, Evgeni Gladysh and Mikhail Krasnosselski from Russia; and Sjoert Brink from the Netherlands. They defeated Mixed (Sabine Auken from Denmark; Roy Welland, Reese Milner, Hemant Lall and Jacek Pszczola from the United States; and Michal Kwiecien from Poland) by 153.5 international match points to 53. Mixed conceded after 48 of the scheduled 64 boards. The winners shared $12,000 and the runners-up $6,000.

headline: Tales From the Prison of International Notoriety
abstract: Amanda Knox — charged, convicted and acquitted in an Italian murder, with more to come — reveals her perspective in a memoir that is by turns sympathetic and enigmatic.
lead_paragraph: “She’s a complete blank,” the playwright John Guare once said, trying to explain the public fascination with Amanda Knox, the American student accused (along with two men) of murdering her housemate Meredith Kercher during a sex escapade gone awry in Italy. “You can project anything on to her. Is she Henry James’s Daisy Miller, an innocent young girl who goes to Europe for experience? Or is she Louise Brooks, the woman who takes what she wants and destroys everything? Or is she Nancy Drew caught up in Kafka?”

headline: Volume Set to Fortissimo
abstract: The Japanese avant-garde musician Keiji Haino brought his loud but tightly controlled explorations for guitar and voice.
lead_paragraph: Keiji Haino lives among the class of improvisers who roam so far from what we usually call form — meaning, basically, rules — that they make you question whether what they’re doing is music. When you arrive at that question, generally, the joke’s on you. If you feel nothing for the music, you can walk away. If you feel something for it, you may start to notice that it possesses its own unity, its own rules. Anyway, it’s not Mr. Haino’s problem. “I am not an anarchist,” he has said. “I am anarchy.”

headline: Cambodian Toe-Tapping Going Global
abstract: Kong Nay played the chapei dang weng, a lute, during a Season of Cambodia concert at the Asia Society.
lead_paragraph: The troubadour wielding a stringed instrument and singing praises, dance tunes, love songs, histories or wry comments is a nearly universal figure in traditional music, from Appalachian banjo pickers to Moroccan gnawa musicians to West African griots to Japanese minyo singers. Kong Nay, who performed at the Asia Society on Saturday night, is one of them, playing the Cambodian style called chapei: singing in a hearty voice and playing the chapei dang weng, a long-necked, two-stringed lute.

headline: You Said It, Brother
abstract: A Monday puzzle by Allan E. Parrish.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Vowel run. Talk amongst yourselves.

headline: Facing a War Zone Rife With Cartels and Zombies
abstract: Laura Butler Rivera stars in “so go the ghosts of méxico, part one,” a Matthew Paul Olmos play inspired by a female sheriff of a town dominated by drug cartels in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: In 2010 a 20-year-old criminology student with a new baby volunteered for a job no one else would take: chief of police in the tiny Mexican border town of Práxedis Gilberto Guerrero, a place overrun by rival drug gangs. (To give you a sense of either the courageousness or foolhardiness of her decision: her predecessor had been tortured and beheaded.) The international news media quickly anointed this remarkable young mother, Marisol Valles García, as “the bravest woman in Mexico.” She proceeded by publicly withdrawing from the drug war, which she said she would leave to the feds; hiring more female officers, who didn’t carry guns; and focusing her police force’s efforts on community building and teaching family values, which she hoped would keep the gangs at bay.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Government Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Fox Renews ‘Glee’ for 2 More Seasons
abstract: The Fox musical “Glee,” which defied the ratings odds when it had its debut in 2009, will remain on the network through 2015 in a deal announced on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Fox musical “Glee,” which defied the ratings odds when it had its debut in 2009, will remain on the network through 2015 in a deal announced on Friday. The network ordered two more seasons of the series, giving the co-creator Ryan Murphy and the other producers an unusual opportunity to plan story lines for the characters well into the future. The current season of “Glee,” its fourth, attracts about 8.7 million viewers a week and routinely ranks among TV’s top 10 shows for 18- to 34-year-olds. In a statement Mr. Murphy thanked Fox and the studio that produces the series, 20th Century Fox Television, for their support. The fourth season has toggled between the high school glee club in Ohio and the graduates who are at a performing arts college in New York. Mr. Murphy has hinted in interviews that he wants the fifth season to focus on just one of the locations, but he has not said which one.

headline: Reporter for Government Radio Is Killed in Somalia
abstract: Mohamed Ibrahim Rageh had fled Mogadishu, the Somali capital, in 2009 after a spate of killings, but returned to continue his career.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A Somali journalist was shot to death on Sunday outside his home in Mogadishu by unknown gunmen, becoming the fourth journalist killed in his country this year, officials said.

headline: Free Downtown Blues
abstract: The blues musician B. B. King and the rock group Los Lobos will be the headliners at the third annual Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival.
lead_paragraph: The blues musician B. B. King and the rock group Los Lobos will be the headliners at the third annual Lowdown Hudson Blues Festival, which will be held on July 10 and 11 in a plaza outside the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan. Other acts include the rock trio Los Lonely Boys, Alejandro Escovedo and the rhythm-and-blues group the James Hunter Six. The concerts, presented by Brookfield Office Properties, are free to the public.

headline: Anna Merz, Rhino Guardian and Champion, Dies at 81
abstract: Mrs. Merz founded a wildlife reserve in Kenya that has helped the black rhinoceros come back from the brink of extinction.
lead_paragraph: Anna Merz, who went to Kenya seeking a serene retirement but became so appalled by the slaughter of black rhinoceroses that she helped start a reserve to protect them, becoming a global leader in the fight against their extinction, died on April 4 in Melkrivier, South Africa. She was 81.

headline: The Pressure to Be the TV News Leader Tarnishes a Big Brand
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Television', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: When big news breaks, a common impulse is to turn to CNN, but the network suffers from self-inflicted damage.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of Americans, when I woke up on Friday morning and found out there was a manhunt in the Boston area for the remaining suspect in Monday’s bombing at the marathon, I turned on CNN.

headline: The Falling Price of Carbon Credits
abstract: The European Union’s Emissions Trading System was intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by setting a market price on them. The system, set up in three phases, requires polluters to acquire credits to offset their emissions. A glut of credits, combined with lower demand because of the weak economy, has driven down the price to close to zero.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s Emissions Trading System was intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by setting a market price on them. The system, set up in three phases, requires polluters to acquire credits to offset their emissions. A glut of credits, combined with lower demand because of the weak economy, has driven down the price to close to zero.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Push to Have Boston Suspect Questioned as Enemy Combatant
abstract: Several senators want the ability to question the suspect at length without any lawyer, intensifying a recurring debate over how to handle terrorism cases arising inside the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some Republican lawmakers want President Obama to declare the surviving Boston bombing suspect an enemy combatant in order to question him without a lawyer and other protections of the criminal justice system, intensifying a recurring debate over how to handle terrorism cases arising inside the United States.

headline: Electric-Taxi Experiment Asks if City’s Cabbies Can Spare the Time to Plug In
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Some drivers have expressed doubts about the viability of using the vehicles, arguing that any charging break would undercut earnings.
lead_paragraph: The taxis are not entirely yellow. Their drivers are allowed to refuse certain fares. Even the smell is different, with no oil-rich odor greeting riders at the door.

headline: Officials’ Visit to Japanese Shrine Could Anger Neighboring Countries
abstract: Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, sent an offering to the shrine for Japan’s war dead but did not visit with his cabinet ministers, possibly to avoid provoking China and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Members of the cabinet of Japan’s conservative prime minister visited a war shrine in Tokyo over the weekend, local news reports said Sunday, symbolic gestures that could anger South Korea and China at a time when Japan’s relations with both nations have been rocky.

headline: Princeton Chooses Its Provost to Become Its Next President
abstract: Christopher L. Eisgruber, an alumnus, will succeed Shirley M. Tilghman, the university announced.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) THE ISLAND PRESIDENT (2012) The director Jon Shenk visits the Maldives, an archipelago of about 1,200 low-lying islands in the Indian Ocean, and follows the efforts of Mohamed Nasheed, above, the country’s president from 2009 to 2012, as he tries to save the nation, a haven for wealthy tourists, from being swallowed by rising seas thought to be caused by global warming. “It is in the nature of political leaders, especially in democracies, to be optimistic, to insist that solutions can be found to even the most intractable problems,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Topical, politically engaged documentaries, particularly those made by American filmmakers, share in this tendency, offering implicit reassurance even as they deliver bad news about the state of the world.” Mr. Shenk’s film, presented here by “Independent Lens,” “is buoyant and spirited enough to keep those demons temporarily at bay,” Mr. Scott added. “It is impossible, while watching it, to root against Mr. Nasheed or to believe that he will fail. But the hope that infuses this movie makes it all the more upsetting to walk out of the theater and contemplate a looming disaster that the world’s leaders seem unable to prevent.”

headline: Now Showing | ‘Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion’
abstract: A new exhibition at The Museum of Art Rhode Island School of Design capitalizes on the recent surge of interest in the artistry and craftsmanship of menswear.
lead_paragraph: Peacocking, the preening of fastidiously dressed males of the fashion flock, has been exhaustively documented of late by international street fashion photographers who track willing prey in their natural habitats: outside fashion shows, fabulous parties and glitzy store openings where the rare birds tend to gather. The origin of this dandy species, Beau Brummel (1778-1840), and his fanciful progeny are the subject of the exhibition “Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion” at the Museum of Art Rhode Island School of Design, opening April 28. The curators, Kate Irvin and Laurie Brewer, from the school’s department of costume and textiles, have capitalized on this recent surge of interest in the artistry and craftsmanship of men’s wear with their study of clothing and ephemera honoring the aesthetic provocateur. Aided by an archive that includes the personal wardrobe of Richard Merkin, a legendary RISD professor, painter and dandy-in-residence, the curators constructed a thematic, rather than chronological, exploration into what they term the “always provocative dandy stance.” Delving deeper than the decorative surface, they contrast the social subversion of dandy “revolutionaries,” who express political views through their personal wardrobes, with a dandy “historian’s” appreciation of tailoring tradition, while a “connoisseur” prides self-expression over societal conformity. Thom Browne says in the accompanying catalog’s preface that “Rebellion comes from being perfectly comfortable doing my own thing and having the drive to make challenging statements in men’s wear.” According to the curators, by “kicking at the boundaries of taste,” the dandy is indeed much more than the commonly criticized “superficial person devoted only to the outer shell.”

headline: Original Pilots, Judged by the Masses
abstract: In another foray into original content, Amazon streams pilots for eight new comedies and invites visitors to influence their fate by rating them.
lead_paragraph: Amazon delivered its first bundle of original content on Friday, pilots for eight comedies (and six children’s shows) that could become series on Amazon Instant Video. The digital twist is that not only can the public see these pilots, but it can also rate and review them, information Amazon says it will weigh in deciding which series are made.

headline: Subtly Married Flavors
abstract: The Staatskapelle Dresden, which performs rarely in the United States, presented an all-Brahms program and Bruckner’s Eighth Symphony on separate evenings at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Staatskapelle Dresden, which played at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Friday evenings, is an orchestra with a great history and reputation, but it has never appeared in the United States often enough to become really familiar here.

headline: A Star, Vital and Vulnerable
abstract: The pop star Kesha comes across as a fun-chasing woman on the road with moments of vulnerability in the new MTV documentary series “Kesha: My Crazy Beautiful Life.”
lead_paragraph: Of today’s pop stars, Kesha is the most irregular, the most collaged — it can seem as if she were made from factory-overrun parts. And her talent is purposefully slack. She can sing and rap and do plenty of other things well, but she’d rather hide behind a lecherous sneer and a snotty attitude, projecting a sense that things might fall apart at any moment, just as they should.

headline: Serving Up a Spectrum of Chopin: Preludes, Ballades, Mazurkas, Études
abstract: The pianist Maurizio Pollini played a program of Chopin and Debussy works at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Some artists are almost universally admired, while others evoke wildly different reactions in listeners. The Italian pianist Maurizio Pollini has long conjured a disparate response: Some hear profundity in his work, others dispassion.

headline: Building A Mystery
abstract: I was wrong – and it’s the world’s fault.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein shakes his head at what he calls “weirdness” at the Washington Post, citing an editorial and a commentary by Robert Samuelson. I second his views, but I’d like to point out something else about Samuelson’s piece.

headline: Study Charts 2,000 Years of Continental Climate Changes
abstract: Researchers find that most continental climates cooled ahead of recent warming.
lead_paragraph: A comprehensive new analysis of temperature changes over the continents through 2,000 years has found that a long slide in temperatures in most regions preceded the unusual global warming of recent decades, but with a lot of regional variability and other fascinating details. A National Science Foundation news release has ample background.

headline: Wanted: Mistresses, Must Be Married
abstract: Marie Lenormand and Philippe Talbot star as besotted street singers caught up in the schemes of the viceroy of Peru in Christopher Alden’s staging of Offenbach’s satirical “La Périchole.”
lead_paragraph: Among Offenbach’s many operettas “La Périchole” is generally considered his most charming. Well, charming is not the word to describe the director Christopher Alden’s new production for the New York City Opera, which opened on Sunday afternoon at City Center. It’s zany, demented, surreal, strangely dark — anything but charming.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Mark Sanford’s Ad
abstract: His wife claimed in family court that he trespassed on her property. He has a different story, and it has something to do with the Alamo.
lead_paragraph: Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina best known for disappearing in 2009 to “hike the Appalachian trail” (actually to go on vacation with his mistress), was never going to have an easy time getting elected to Congress. But his job prospects dimmed considerably last week when allegations came to light that he’d trespassed on his ex-wife’s property.

headline: Game Theory: Jane Austen Had It First
abstract: Jane Austen was a seminal thinker in the as-yet-unnamed science of game theory, the author Michael Chwe maintains in his new book.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that someone stumbles upon a major new strategic thinker during family movie night. But that’s what happened to Michael Chwe, an associate professor of political science at the University of California, Los Angeles, when he sat down with his children some eight years ago to watch “Clueless,” the 1995 romantic comedy based on Jane Austen’s “Emma.”

abstract: Because of belt-tightening in Washington and a strengthening economy, the federal deficit is quickly contracting, as reflected in new estimates from Goldman Sachs.

The city has started its celebration of its history called Fiesta, whose signature event is the Battle of the Flowers parade on Friday.

headline: Flights Delayed Across Country Amid Budget-Cut Furloughs of Air Controllers
abstract: Pilots, gate agents and others blamed budget cuts, but the F.A.A. said it was too soon to assign blame for delays of up to two hours.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Flights were delayed by up to two hours across the country on Monday, the first weekday that the nation’s air traffic control system operated with 10 percent fewer controllers. Pilots, gate agents and others were quick to blame furloughs caused by mandatory across-the-board budget cuts, but the Federal Aviation Administration said it was too soon to tell.

On walls of the tiny arena are images of his father, Slobodan Jankovic, who was known as Boban and who was paralyzed in a fluke accident in a game 20 years ago. Miss Hawaiian Tropic bikini pageants, for example, began in 1983, while the 1995 DVD “Playboy: The Girls of Hawaiian Tropic, Naked in Paradise,” dispensed with swimwear altogether. And from 2006 to 2010, the Hawaiian Tropic Zone near Times Square, featuring waitresses in bikinis, called itself “the hottest place on earth.”

headline: How Writers Interact With the World
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Many writers label Wi-Fi and all that goes along with it a distraction, but the impulse to connect with the outside world is an ancient one.
lead_paragraph: The image has been handed down throughout the long iconography of the West, most effectively transmitted in the image of Saint Jerome: the writer as a recluse, weaving spirited collocations of words in hushed seclusion. Jerome may have a lion at his feet, but he lacks other company — and, of course, he has no Wi-Fi. His condition is distinctly different from that of the modern writer; her room is not only well-lighted and likely lion-free, but also furnishes an Internet connection, through which the world’s tumult pours.

abstract: Are victims of industrial explosions different from victims of terrorism?
lead_paragraph: JUST after lunch break one infernal Houston afternoon in 1995, I slammed the door of the company truck, cranked the engine, and punched the gas so hard that the truck fishtailed onto Jensen Drive. Beside me sat my co-worker Charlie. In his lap, he clenched a blood-drenched wad of paper towels over what had been, minutes before, his left thumb. The severed thumb, packed hurriedly on ice in a cup, rode in the center console.

And while Vermonters take pride in their fall foliage and Washingtonians love their cherry blossoms, Texans can be near fanatical about bluebonnets, sometimes ignoring property laws and personal safety to wade into their fragrant midst.

headline: China: Prison for Preachers

abstract: Chinese authorities have sentenced to prison seven underground church leaders arrested last April and charged with belonging to an illegal cult, according to a Christian rights group.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese authorities have sentenced to prison seven underground church leaders who were arrested last April and charged with belonging to an illegal cult, according to a Christian rights group. The preachers, who officiated illegal Pentecostal congregations in Henan Province, were given terms from three to seven-and-a-half years, according to court documents released by ChinaAid, a Texas-based group. headline: Some Call It ‘Pop’

They speak an entirely different language up there, and it soon became apparent to me that I was going to get myself in trouble if I ventured out without someone who was willing to translate for me. SODA became “pop,” sprinkles on ice cream became “jimmies” (I misheard that one, and assumed that the young man asking me if I wanted jimmies just had an odd, third-person way of coming on to women), and I’m sure there were more that I’m forgetting. My point is, never send your kids off to school in another region without a dictionary.

lead_paragraph: One of the first things you learn when living in New York is that what qualifies as wealthy somewhere else seems barely middle-class here. On the Upper West Side, where I live, it’s hard not to feel as if Manhattan is impossibly expensive for young professionals. The average nondoorman, one-bedroom apartment in the neighborhood rents for about $2,500 a month. Oatmeal-raisin cookies at Levain Bakery cost $4 each. A pair of sensible, unstylish walking flats from Harry’s Shoes can set you back $480. I suppose, by comparison, that the $198 chef’s menu at Jean-Georges doesn’t sound so ridiculous.

headline: Separate but Equal

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The rain didn’t deter many observant Jews from visiting the Western Wall on a recent Sunday. After all, the men have the luxury of access to a spacious covered area, where only they can pray, as long as they don’t stray from Orthodox customs. Women have a much smaller covered area and on rainy days many are forced to weather the elements.

headline: ‘Dangerous Liaisons’ Meets AC/DC
abstract: A band called the Upper Crust had a schtick that sounded ridiculous until you witnessed it — they dressed up as 18th-century aristocrats and played heavy metal.
lead_paragraph: In the Lives essay I wrote for last Sunday’s magazine, a brilliant live band from Boston called the Upper Crust makes an important cameo. I knew about them because my friend Ted Widmer used to be one of their three guitarists (he also wrote for me at George magazine), and they had this shtick that sounded ridiculous until you witnessed it — they dressed up as 18th-century aristocrats and played heavy metal. Actually, it was ridiculous after you witnessed it too, but that was the point. The reason it worked, among other things, was that their songs were surprisingly great, and the band could fill a room with an energy that inspired villainy. The altercation I wrote about at a 1996 show at Brownie’s in the East Village was apparently not uncommon. “We had a lot of extremes, people who loved the humor, and then a lot of people who got out of control,” Widmer says. “It seemed to make people go crazy. There were a lot of fights breaking out at gigs in the early days.”

We’d love to hear more ideas, especially if, like these tools, they’re free.— Katherine Schulten

headline: The Exploding Floral Inevitable
abstract: Fong Qi Wei’s photographs of disassembled flowers seem apt for the type of spring we’re having.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a never-ending winter this year in the Northeast. Every time warm weather emerged in the past few weeks, another blast of cold quickly followed, leaving us skeptical as to whether spring would ever really come. Perhaps that’s one of the reasons why Fong Qi Wei’s series “Exploded Flowers” seemed so apt when I came upon it on one one of my favorite art and design blogs, Colossal. Wei disassembled and photographed 20 varieties of flowers, arranging each blossom’s pieces to emphasize its radial symmetry. It’s a graphic and colorful way of looking at one of nature’s most recognizable symbols of spring. Wei started the series in 2011 and finished last November; the images have been making the rounds on various design blogs recently because five of the pictures won second place as a series in the 2012 International Photography Awards. For more of Wei’s images, check out the entire series.

He may have been the effective warm-up act for his friend Barbra Streisand, to whom he was about to present the 40th annual Chaplin Award. headline: For a Clam Dish, Wines With a Snap
abstract: The combination of olive oil, garlic and clam broth boiled in a rich, briny sauce practically demands a lively white.
lead_paragraph: Pasta with clams, one of the recipes in Mark Bittman’s new Flexitarian column, is one of my favorite dishes and is easy as can be when it comes to wine. The combination of olive oil, garlic and clam broth boiled in a rich, briny sauce practically demands a lively, lean, high-acid, somewhat austere white. Italy is full of good examples; just distinguish between mundane industrial bottles and those made with care. Good pinot grigio, Soave or Orvieto, to name three frequently abused wines, are fine choices, as are fianos and falanghinas from Campania. Avoid oakiness and lush textures; the wines want to have snap. Alternatives from farther afield? Chablis comes immediately to mind: a fresh, young modest Chablis. You have beauty in all these combinations.

headline: In Iceland, a Festival of Present and Future
abstract: The three-day Tectonics Festival of contemporary music made imaginative use of an equally imaginative new performance complex in Reykjavik.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Visitors to Thingvellir National Park, just over 30 miles outside of Reykjavik, can stand on the North American continental plate one minute, and Eurasia the next, by simply crossing a rocky gorge: it’s a divergent boundary where the world’s face is ripping apart slowly. In Reykjavik a different kind of upheaval was evident last weekend, as the Iceland Symphony Orchestra presented its second annual Tectonics Festival at the Harpa Concert Hall and Conference Center here on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The festival also engaged in shifting borders, but convergence, rather than separation, was the chief process in play.

headline: Court Backs E.P.A. Veto of Mining Permit
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Water Pollution', 'ANIMALS', 'Mountaintop Removal Mining', 'Coal', 'Clean Water Act', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to revoke a mining permit to protect streams and wildlife, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to revoke a mining permit to protect streams and wildlife, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday. The decision was a victory for the agency, which in 2011 retroactively vetoed a permit granted by the Bush administration in 2007 to allow a subsidiary of Arch Coal of St. Louis to dump tons of mining waste into several West Virginia rivers and streams. The veto was declared illegal in a 2012 decision by Judge Amy Berman Jackson of Federal District Court, who called it an illegal power grab. But on Tuesday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled unanimously that the Clean Water Act and Congressional intent gave E.P.A. the authority to retroactively revoke a mining permit. The ruling affects a proposed mine known as Spruce No. 1, which would have involved dynamiting the tops off mountains to get at coal. Kim Link, a spokeswoman for Arch Coal, said in an e-mail: “We’re disappointed in the decision, which was related to the procedural aspects of the proceeding. The case will now go back to the district court for a decision on the merits.”

lead_paragraph: A British businessman who sold the Iraqi security forces more than 6,000 fake bomb detectors based on $20 golf ball finders bought from the United States was convicted of fraud on Tuesday in Britain’s central criminal court. The businessman, James McCormick, 56, was described in court as having made more than $75 million from sales of the fake device in Iraq and Georgia, among other places, claiming they could detect bombs, drugs, currency and ivory, and track objects up to 3,280 feet below ground. The devices, sold for up to $40,000 each, had no working electronics and were completely useless. They were widely used at checkpoints in Iraq, giving a false sense of security. An Iraqi general, Jihad al-Jabiri, former head of the Baghdad bomb squad, has been jailed in the scam, along with other police officials.

headline: Goodbye to All That

lead_paragraph: On April 13, Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority resigned. It was an easy development to miss, but not one to be ignored. It was very bad news, because Salam Fayyad was the “Arab Spring” before there was an Arab Spring. That is, he was what the Arab Spring was supposed to lead to: a new generation of decent Arab leaders whose primary focus would be the human development of their own people, not the enrichment of their family, tribe, sect or party. That Fayyad’s brand of noncorrupt, institution-focused leadership was not sufficiently supported by other Palestinian leaders, the Arab states, Israel and America is really depressing. It does not bode well for the revolutions in Egypt, Syria or Tunisia — none of which have a Fayyad-quality leader at the helm.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:35 P.M. (Starz) THE IDES OF MARCH (2011) George Clooney, Grant Heslov and Beau Willimon received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for this political drama, which Mr. Clooney, above, also directed and stars in as Mike Morris, a Pennsylvania governor turned dream candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. Ryan Gosling plays Stephen Meyers, a strategist who becomes involved with an intern (Evan Rachel Wood) with a powerful father and a secret that could derail Stephen’s career and the Morris campaign. Philip Seymour Hoffman and Paul Giamatti are senior advisers battling for Stephen’s loyalty. And Marisa Tomei is a reporter trying to get at the truth. “Mr. Clooney handles the plot complications with elegant dexterity,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Mr. Willimon’s play “Farragut North,” loosely based on Howard Dean’s 2004 Democratic presidential primary campaign. “As an actor he works best in long, understated scenes that allow him to play with nuances of charm and menace, so it is not surprising that, as a director, he gives the rest of the cast room to work,” Mr. Scott added. “But the parts of ‘The Ides of March’ — quiet scenes between Mr. Gosling and Ms. Wood; swirling, Sorkinesque exchanges of banter; any time Ms. Tomei or Max Minghella (as a campaign worker grooming himself to be the next Stephen Meyers) are in the room — are greater than the whole.”

And it’s the same Mike Brown who lasted five games into his second season as the clearly wrong choice to coach the Lakers.

headline: Richie Havens, 1941 – 2013
abstract: I heard Havens’ version of “Here Comes the Sun” after Harrison’s. Why did the two versions make me feel so different?
lead_paragraph: In 1971, around when I first heard the voice that was Richie Havens, I was 7 years old. Radio was the way you formed your musical brain and mine was hungry. It was a good time for that. The pop airwaves were almost completely integrated. The Stones, the Beatles, and CCR mingled with Stevie Wonder, Marvin Gaye, the Temptations, the Isleys, the Jacksons and even the Osmonds into one dizzying sonic mix. I learned to love practically everything. But some things leapt out.

Each side accused the other of responsibility for the destruction at the Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo’s walled ancient city, a Unesco World Heritage site.

But with the list of more environmentally friendly cars and trucks at an all-time high, choosing the best one can be tough.

headline: Documenting a Growing Force in Fashion
abstract: Exhibitions at the Museum of Chinese in America show the creative range of Asian-Americans in fashion and other fashion news this week.
lead_paragraph: THROUGHOUT THE RECENT and meteoric rise of Asian-Americans in fashion, there have been numerous milestones, as when Alexander Wang was named the creative director of Balenciaga last year, or when Jason Wu designed Michelle Obama’s first inaugural gown in 2009 (and her second one this year). Before them, beginning in the 1980s, came a handful of pioneers, like Vera Wang and Anna Sui.

But the company has delayed the release of the software until summer, according to two people briefed on the company’s plans.

headline: Ireland’s New International Food Festival
abstract: The inaugural Ballymaloe Literary Festival of Food and Wine celebrates the art of food writing.
lead_paragraph: Between them, the collected works of the presenters at the inaugural Ballymaloe Literary Festival of Food and Wine, taking place from May 3 to May 6, would constitute the beginnings of a library, or at least a very impressive cookbook collection. Darina Allen, arguably Ireland’s most famous cook and visible advocate of its food culture, has lured many of the world’s most revered and prolific food writers to attend the three-day event outside the Irish city of Cork. This is an international food festival with a difference. Far from being staged in the usual hotel ballroom or university lecture hall, it will take place among the bucolic surrounds of Ballymaloe, the family estate made famous first by Myrtle Allen’s seminal country house restaurant, and then by her daughter-in-law Darina’s cooking school and picturesque organic farm.

It is called accountable care, and the general idea is to enlist doctors and nurses in the fight to control spending.

headline: ‘Nice Work’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: The Broadway musical “Nice Work if You Can Get It” will close on June 15 after 27 preview performances and 478 regular performances.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “Nice Work if You Can Get It,” a venture involving the heirs of George and Ira Gershwin and several veteran theater producers to showcase famous songs by the brothers, will close on June 15 after 27 preview performances and 478 regular performances, the producers announced on Wednesday. The Jazz Age-style show, which originally paired Tony Award winner Matthew Broderick as a playboy with Tony nominee Kelli O’Hara as a bootlegger, opened last April to mixed reviews and never caught real fire at the box office. (Ms. O’Hara’s role is now played by Tony nominee Jessie Mueller.)

lead_paragraph: For the second time in a matter of weeks, a group of researchers reported a link between the food people eat and bacteria in the intestines that can increase the risk of heart attacks.

lead_paragraph: Some artists shun the spotlight, letting galleries promote their work while they keep to their studios. Others are savvier, stoking just enough buzz to get the art cognoscenti’s attention.

headline: Luminous Time Capsule, Bobbing Alongside the Present
abstract: In “Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man,” the director Jonas Mekas, now 90, splices together luminous moments that he filmed in the past.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Mekas calls his blissed-out new movie “Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man.” It’s an honest, direct title for a transcendently lovely and delicate work created from images that didn’t make it into the filmed diaries he made from 1960 to 2000. During those years, he produced some of his most enduring films, like “Walden” and “Lost Lost Lost.” He also published “I Had Nowhere to Go,” his often haunting memoir that traces his early life as a Lithuanian refugee during World War II, and his later struggles both as a displaced person in Europe after the war and then as an immigrant living, working, yearning and shooting his first films in New York City.

lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Welcoming the Gods Back to Their Majestic Gloaming
abstract: “Götterdämmerung,” with Deborah Voigt, completes the “Ring” cycle at the Met.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it is time to stop talking about the machine. Sure, Robert Lepage’s 45-ton set for the Metropolitan Opera‘s current production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle is loud, gimmicky and exorbitantly expensive. But so are many top restaurants in this city and that has never stopped New Yorkers from clambering over one another to get a table.

headline: All Systems Are Go, and Tested
abstract: The alto saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman, working with his band Five Elements, began a weeklong residency at the Stone on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The alto saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman puts his trust in systems, though he’s too rigorous to let any premise go untested. During his first set at the Stone in the East Village on Tuesday night, he kept setting up patterns and disrupting them, in variable cycles. Working as usual with Five Elements, his flagship band, he created the feeling of a meticulously honed aesthetic subjected to unrelenting pressure.

headline: Scaling Up a Classic Style
abstract: The New England Collection reproduces classic American hooked rugs in modern sizes.
lead_paragraph: People looking for vintage hooked rugs can’t always find what they want in the size they need. “Our customers were always asking for something larger,” said Ramin Hakimi, a partner with Kevin Rahmanan in Rahmanan Antique & Decorative Rugs, a dealer in antique and vintage carpets. To meet the demand, the men started an offshoot company, the New England Collection, reproducing, in modern sizes, designs taken from their inventory of classic American hooked rugs. The range now also includes rag rugs, needlepoints and flat-woven styles, including dhurries, Aubussons, and Persian-style kilims. The monochromatic design shown here was adapted from a 19th-century New England model, with tweaks to the palette and pattern. It was woven in cotton on different-size hooks to create a variation in depth. The 6-by-9-foot carpet is $3,942. Information: (212) 683-0167 or necrugs.com.

headline: A Table That Is Pure but Not Simple
abstract: The Frazier side table is made of materials originally intended for telescopes and lab equipment.
lead_paragraph: If the Frazier side table, by the architecture and furniture design firm Khouri Guzman Bunce Ltd., looks old, that may be because its materials are borrowed from other industries. The top is borosilicate glass intended for telescope lenses and lab equipment. (The glass is available with a mirrored finish, which makes the subtle, character-building imperfections stand out even more.) The base is silicon bronze, with a 95 percent copper content, the most durable of all bronzes, and one that is used primarily for sculpture casting. (The base is also available in brass, blackened steel and nickel.) Rather than welded, these two pieces are screwed together, which produces a visually light effect and reveals that the frame is solid metal, rather than plated. “You can go anywhere and find a plated table,” said David Khouri, a partner in the firm. “I want people to think about how this one’s made.” A standard-size table is 22.5 inches high and 19.5 inches wide. Prices start at $7,250: (212) 420-7866 or kgb-limited.com.

headline: Brightening Up a Cancer Center’s Thrift Shop
abstract: A store benefiting the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will also serve as a pop-up boutique.
lead_paragraph: In February, the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center asked the textile and carpet designer Madeline Weinrib to transform its charity thrift shop on the Upper East Side into an occasional pop-up boutique for designer sample sales. “With all the consignment shops around, and people selling their furniture on eBay, it has taken a lot of business away from the charity thrift shops,” said Ms. Weinrib, who is based in Manhattan. From May 3 to 5, she will fill the 2,500-square-foot space at 1440 Third Avenue with pillows, rugs, rolls of fabric to be sold by the yard, clothing, handbags, totes, napkins and furniture. Products will be sold at 40 to 70 percent off retail. Eighteen-inch-square pillows, shown above and below, originally $350 to $575, will be $179 to $299. Home delivery is not available, but even rugs and furniture pieces will be small enough to carry. The sale will take place from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 535-1250.

headline: How a Dogg Became a Lion

Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, said on Wednesday that she would not support a proposed bill to open state courts to claims of racial profiling by the Police Department, but would allow the bill’s sponsors to submit it for a vote.

abstract: After the civil rights movement, once-surreptitious artwork by African-Americans in Alabama could finally be shared. And yet, paradoxically, the era for this art was already vanishing.

His scruffy three-bedroom house filled up most of a small city lot, just up the hill from Martin Luther King Jr. Drive. But somehow he made it work.

headline: The Art of Digging In

abstract: The tenants of one Dumbo building  have turned their apartments into otherworldly environments. But after filing for legal protection, they are at odds with their once-benevolent landlord.
lead_paragraph: The ceiling of Mark Winkel’s apartment sprouts foam flowers as big as a man’s torso, several trapeze swings and a half-dozen chandeliers and pendant lights entwined with 1,000 roses. These last flourishes are the remnants of a Valentine’s Day brunch that Mr. Winkel, a puckish 37-year-old events producer who favors suits and ties (even at home), held for a few friends.

headline: How Does a Chair Look Presidential?
abstract: Aaron Moser, one of four sons of the name-supplying founder of Thos. Moser, answers questions about furnishing the George W. Bush Presidential Center.
lead_paragraph: In the Bush family, Texas jockeys with Maine as the favored homeland, a theme that seems to have continued with the George W. Bush Presidential Center, on the campus of Southern Methodist University, in Dallas. It opens May 1 and is furnished throughout by Thos. Moser, the Auburn, Me., producer of handmade furniture.

headline: Your Chance to Snoop
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Dust off your walking shoes: it’s time to stroll through hidden gardens, contemplate a reflecting pool and admire a connoisseur’s art collection.
lead_paragraph: Spring, when nature puts itself on open display, is also the season for peeking into private havens. Scores of house and garden tours are being organized, from Brooklyn to San Francisco, and will continue through the fine months. Here’s your chance to see hidden gardens in Boston or midcentury modern houses in Philadelphia. Or you can take in kitchen-focused residences in Larchmont, N.Y. (with tastings from local chefs). Many of the events are fund-raisers, so while you’re contemplating a reflecting pool or admiring a connoisseur’s art collection, your entry fees will be at work. Unless otherwise noted, all tours are self-guided.

headline: Gawking Encouraged
abstract: A guide to house tours around the country.
lead_paragraph: A guide to house tours around the country.

headline: Now Listening | Luke Winslow-King
abstract: The New Orleans-based musician Luke Winslow-King releases a new LP this today and plays live around New York this weekend.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 19, the New Orleans-based musician Luke Winslow-King, originally from Cadillac, Michigan, set out for a domestic tour with his blues band singing Woody Guthrie songs. But when they finally made it to the Big Easy, their car was stolen, with all their instruments inside. Most everything was later recovered, and so the city — coupled with the fact that they were able to borrow instruments from supportive locals to continue their tour — left a big impression on the young artist. “It’s almost like these things happened in my life that changed my course, but put me back to where I needed to be,” says Winslow-King, who then quickly moved to the Crescent City, where he started busking on Frenchmen Street while studying music at the University of New Orleans.

headline: Scientist Says Pollution From China Is Killing a Japanese Island’s Trees
abstract: Osamu Nagafuchi has warned for years that a die-off among pine trees on Yakushima island is caused by pollution from China. Now he is being taken more seriously.
lead_paragraph: YAKUSHIMA, Japan — A mysterious pestilence has befallen this island’s primeval forests, leaving behind the bleached, skeletal remains of dead trees that now dot the dark green mountainsides. Osamu Nagafuchi, an environmental engineer with a passion for the island and its rugged terrain, believes he knows the culprit: airborne pollutants from smog-belching China, hundreds of miles upwind.

lead_paragraph: One day after he was knocked out of a game when he took a comebacker to his right ankle, Jon Niese said he expected to make his next scheduled start, Sunday against the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Harvard Medical School Plans to Close Primate Research Lab
abstract: About 2,000 monkeys at the troubled New England Primate Research Center in Southborough, Mass., will be relocated to other laboratories.
lead_paragraph: About 2,000 monkeys at a Harvard Medical School research center will be moved to other laboratories around the country as the school shuts down the troubled center, an official with the National Institutes of Health said Wednesday.

headline: Playing With Light in the Darkness
abstract: For this Swiss photographer, taking pictures is better when the shades are drawn.
lead_paragraph: Every other year, the Festival des Arts Visuels, which is devoted to photography and held in Vevey, Switzerland, selects an artist to receive $42,000 to fund a new project. As a member of the festival’s jury last week, I helped review the work of 750 photographers from 63 countries. The winner was Augustin Rebetez, a young Swiss whose photos, videos and drawings can be frightening yet weirdly playful and touching. Awkward home scenes, with walls that come to life and beds that breathe, are filled with demented twists and creepy characters. The fairytale world of his videos is as unsettling as the early work of David Lynch and the claymation art of Nathalie Djurberg — but also tender in the way that Tim Burton’s work can be.

headline: Some Love for 3 Achy Workhorses Linking Staten Island and New Jersey
abstract: The Goethals Bridge, the Bayonne Bridge and the Outerbridge Crossing lack the charm of some other area bridges, but they have their supporters, and are to get $2.8 billion in construction work.
lead_paragraph: As a child, Angela Goethals had a fantasy about the 7,100-foot-long structure between Staten Island and Elizabeth, N.J., that she still calls “my bridge,” even though it no more belonged to her than the George Washington Bridge belonged to Washington’s heirs or the Lincoln Tunnel belonged to Lincoln’s.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Quinn, Development Interests and the Closing of a Hospital
abstract: An attack ad that asserts that Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, allowed St. Vincent’s Hospital to close three years ago packs a punch, but its assertions are not fully supported by evidence.
lead_paragraph: Critics of Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on Wednesday released an attack ad asserting that Ms. Quinn allowed St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village to close three years ago. The critics’ political committee, called NYC Is Not For Sale 2013, says that its mission is to defeat Ms. Quinn’s mayoral bid and that it does not represent any particular candidate. Its leaders are from Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group which opposes horse-drawn carriages; and Wendy Kelman Neu, chief executive of Hugo Neu Corporation, a recycling company. The ad is to air on television.

headline: New Technology Inspires a Rethinking of Light
abstract: Beyond the energy and cost savings, new types of lighting are now envisioned as ways to heal, soothe, invigorate or protect people.
lead_paragraph: AFTER the joy of the birth itself, parenthood sometimes brings the unwelcome news that a newborn has jaundice and must wear goggles and be placed under special lights. Imagine how different this experience might be if there were no goggles, just a warm blanket covering the tiny body, a healing frequency of blue light emanating from its folds.

lead_paragraph: When I was a kid I carried around a little backpack that held my Nintendo Gameboy, a Sega Game Gear and several dozen game cartridges for each portable system. Today’s children simply carry around a smartphone and can play hundreds of thousands of games on a single device. No backpack or external game cartridges are required.

It appears that gradually, over time, editors have begun the process of moving women, one by one, alphabetically, from the “American Novelists” category to the “American Women Novelists” subcategory. So far, female authors whose last names begin with A or B have been most affected, although many others have, too.

headline: Evidence and Economic Policy
abstract: Does it matter who was right and who was wrong?
lead_paragraph: Henry Blodget says that the economic debate is over; the austerians have lost and whatshisname has won. And it’s definitely true that in sheer intellectual terms, this is looking like an epic rout. The main economic studies that supposedly justified the austerian position have imploded; inflation has stayed low; the bond vigilantes have failed to make an appearance; the actual economic effects of austerity have tracked almost exactly what Keynesians predicted.

Oliver had made a series of impolitic remarks about the efforts to block the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which, if it’s ever built, would import oil from the tar sands of Alberta to refineries along the Gulf Coast — and which Canadians believe that the United States would be nuts to reject.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision that triggered an avalanche of corporate political spending also contained a proposal for greater public disclosure from corporations that would prefer to write their checks in the shadows. Transparency, the court advised, would let voters decide for themselves “whether elected officials are ‘in the pocket’ of so-called moneyed interests.”

headline: Were Chemical Weapons Used in Syria?
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Obama administration must carefully investigate the charges before deciding how to respond.
lead_paragraph: It’s not hard to imagine that President Bashar al-Assad, desperately clinging to power, might use chemical weapons against the Syrian people. He has already pummeled them with warplanes and missiles and shows no signs of ending a bloody onslaught that has lasted more than two years. But while he may be capable of using weapons of mass destruction, there is no proof that he has done so.

headline: Moving Past the Last Balkan War
abstract: Though the European Union fumbled the euro crisis, the agreement it brokered between Serbia and Kosovo shows the good work it can do.
lead_paragraph: At a time of disillusionment about the state of the European Union, a diplomatic deal between Serbia and Kosovo highlights some of the more positive features of the institution that won last year’s Nobel Peace Prize but fumbled the euro crisis. The tentative agreement signed last Friday not only shows that the European Union can perform well but also that it remains an attractive destination for countries that aspire to membership.

headline: On Beyond Fear
abstract: The secretary of homeland security explained how immigration reform would strengthen security at the borders and expand enforcement of the laws.
lead_paragraph: The homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, testified on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the Senate’s bipartisan immigration bill. For hours, in a calm and methodical manner, she flipped each confrontational line of questioning on its head. No, the bill would not loosen security at borders and ports. It would tighten it. The bill would not weaken immigration enforcement, but strengthen it — adding resources and improving the government’s ability to keep unwanted people out and to catch fugitives, identify thieves and terrorists.

headline: Yes, You Treat Customers Well. But How Do You Treat Employees?
abstract: The example you set may be more important than you realize.

It took me 10 years to learn this lesson, but once I did, our customer service went from O.K. with lots of effort to great with minimal effort.

headline: The Tea Party Caucus: It’s Baaack!
abstract: Connoisseurs of Republican disorder should cheer the group’s “relaunch.”
lead_paragraph: For the better part of a year, the country has survived, somehow, without a House Tea Party Caucus. A group that once boiled with anti-government furor went dormant last summer as the Tea Party’s popularity plummeted and its leader, Michele Bachmann, struggled to get re-elected. Ten caucus members lost their jobs in November. The sniping about the House Republican leadership — not to mention President Obama — quieted down, and so did the tweets championing Barry Goldwater’s still-radioactive support of extremism.

But as this comedy stretches toward an hour and a half, the only thing that the title invites is an easy attempt to sum up the show.

lead_paragraph: To describe “Pain & Gain” as a Michael Bay movie on steroids would be accurate but also redundant and a little misleading. Pumped-up, aggressive, muscle-headed entertainment is Mr. Bay’s specialty, after all, and while this grisly true-crime drama is partly about performance-enhancing drugs and the bulky men who love them, it is also, compared with “Armageddon” or the “Transformers” series, a stripped-down, modest enterprise in which no major American city is reduced to rubble.

It certainly does form the line in football fandom between the folks who have gone a bit around the bend and those who just want to know who will be on their team come September.
