abstract: A selection of cultural events.
lead_paragraph: Nightmares, Recalled

headline: From Red Zone to Red Carpet
abstract: At the N.F.L. draft, a passel of lugs in baggy suits picked out by Mom has been replaced by a parade of fashion plates that might put Oscar contenders to shame.
lead_paragraph: This is how football hooks you. You start the day uninitiated and feeling about the National Football League draft roughly the degree of enthusiasm you might if offered a chance to spend a quiet evening catching up on back issues of Cigar Aficionado.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Where Were You When …
abstract: During momentous events like the Boston Marathon bombings, how do you get your news? David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss their media diet.
lead_paragraph: During momentous events like the Boston Marathon bombings, how do you get your news? In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss their media diet.

headline: Focused on Scoring Threats, Bulls Play Nets 5 on 3
abstract: The Bulls have all but ignored the Nets’ Reggie Evans and Gerald Wallace to focus on stopping Deron Williams, Brook Lopez and Joe Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Propelled by Deron Williams’s dribble penetration and Brook Lopez’s touch inside, the Nets’ scoring flowed steadily in their Game 1 blowout of the Chicago Bulls. But since that game’s final buzzer, the Nets’ offense has been reduced to a trickle. The Bulls have constricted Brooklyn’s options and diverted the action to its least potent offensive players.

headline: Rejuvenation, Reflected on the Screen
abstract: Choices about the costumes and sets of Susanne Bier’s new film, “Love Is All You Need,” do much to reflect the character and her outlook on life.
lead_paragraph: Choices about the costumes and sets of Susanne Bier’s new film, “Love Is All You Need,” do much to reflect the character and her outlook on life.

headline: Homeowners in Flood Zones Opt to Rebuild, Not Move
abstract: A proposal to buy the damaged homes of New Yorkers who want to relocate after Hurricane Sandy is finding few takers, state officials said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A proposal to buy the damaged homes of New Yorkers who want to relocate after Hurricane Sandy is finding few takers, as most residents opt to rebuild, state officials said on Friday.

headline: City’s Highest Subway Station Reopens
abstract: The Smith-Ninth Street station, elevated more than 80 feet above Gowanus, Brooklyn, had been shuttered for nearly two years.
lead_paragraph: The least “sub” station in the city subway system, Smith-Ninth Street in Brooklyn, which soars more than 80 feet above the scrapyards of Gowanus, surged back to life again Friday morning after a $32 million face-lift that left it shuttered for nearly two years.

headline: Move to Close Long Island College Hospital Is Halted
abstract: State officials said Long Island College Hospital would not be closed, after weeks of protests and a lawsuit by labor unions and doctors.
lead_paragraph: A plan to close Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn is being withdrawn, state officials said on Friday, in a startling victory for doctors, unions and community members who said the closing of the hospital would compromise health care for residents in the area.

headline: From an Office Romance to Home Cooking
abstract: Jim and Linda Addy have found over 37 years of  marriage that liking each other is just as important as loving.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Galleon Group Co-Founder Surfaces on Horseback
abstract: Gary Rosenbach, the co-founder and longtime No. 2 to Raj Rajaratnam at the Galleon Group, has surfaced in Texas as an accomplished amateur “cutter,” a sport in which horseback riders separate one calf from the cattle herd.
lead_paragraph: It is a question asked by nearly everyone who has followed the insider trading investigation of the Galleon Group hedge fund: what ever happened to Gary Rosenbach?

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: With its assortment of artisanal food vendors, craft makers and more, the Hester Street Fair, at the corner of Hester and Essex Streets on the Lower East Side, returns on Saturday for the season. The market is open from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturdays through Oct. 26.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Mud’
abstract: Jeff Nichols, the director of “Mud,” narrates a scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: In Jeff Nichols’s latest film “Mud,” Matthew McConaughey plays the title character as a man who is always on the move. The character is discovered hiding out on an island in the Mississippi River by two Arkansas boys (Tye Sheridan and Jacob Lofland). To capture a constantly moving character, Mr. Nichols and his crew used a Steadicam camera to create sense of fluidity. In this video, Mr. Nichols narrates a scene where the boys bring food to Mud on the island. He discusses his camera choices and how they supplement his narrative.

headline: ‘Technical’ Problem Resolved, ‘Django’ to Open in China in May
abstract: The film was pulled from theaters in April, but is now set to debut on May 12. Sony Pictures officials declined to say if the movie had been edited.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After being pulled from theaters this month over what Chinese officials described as a “technical” problem, Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained” will return to movie screens in China on May 12.

headline: ‘Matilda’ Quartet Ruled Ineligible for Best Actress Tony
abstract: The committee administering the awards contradicted a precedent set when three performers playing “Billy Elliot” were jointly eligible, and won, the prize for best actor in a musical.
lead_paragraph: The four child actresses who rotate in the title role of the Broadway musical “Matilda” will not be eligible for a joint Tony Award nomination for best actress in a musical this spring, the Tony administrative committee ruled on Friday. The decision, the most newsworthy result of a busy committee meeting, sets aside a controversial precedent from 2009 when the three teenage boys sharing the lead role in “Billy Elliot” were deemed eligible for a joint best actor nomination — and went on to win that June.

headline: ‘Open’ Season in High Tech
abstract: Proof of cloud computing’s impact on the tech industry: Some big incumbent firms, known for expensive in-house products and zealous guarding of their intellectual property, are claiming the open source religion.
lead_paragraph: Things must be getting really competitive in high technology. So many big competitive companies are striving to show how good they are at sharing.

headline: Obama Not Rushing to Act on Signs Syria Used Chemical Arms
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The president said he would respond “prudently” and “deliberately” to evidence that Syria has used chemical weapons, tamping down any expectations that he would take swift action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he would respond “prudently” and “deliberately” to evidence that Syria had used chemical weapons, tamping down any expectations that he would take swift action after an American intelligence assessment that the Syrian government had used the chemical agent sarin on a small scale in the nation’s civil war.

headline: A Roll-Up-His-Sleeves Buyer
abstract: Stephen Sullivan went looking for a home near his job in Dumbo.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Sullivan was eager to buy a place that he could renovate himself.

headline: Obama Chooses Economist for Chief Regulatory Post
abstract: President Obama has nominated Howard Shelanski, the top economist at the Federal Trade Commission, to direct the White House office overseeing all federal regulations.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has nominated Howard Shelanski, the top economist at the Federal Trade Commission, to direct the White House office overseeing all federal regulations.

headline: The Dark Side of Innocence
abstract: Pierre Étaix, the French comic — well, he was more than that — is honored in a collection from Criterion, released in two discs.
lead_paragraph: Critics have a tendency to condescend to physical comedy, to brush off those masters of the sight gag and the pratfall, from Chaplin to Jim Carrey, by cooing over their “innocence,” their “joyfulness,” their “simplicity,” as if they were talking about slightly slow but adorable children.

headline: Chevrolet Announces 2014 Corvette Stingray Price
abstract: Chevrolet announced today that the 2014 Corvette Stingray starts at just under $52,000.
lead_paragraph: Corvette enthusiasts, the moment you’ve all been waiting for has finally arrived. Friday, Chevrolet announced the starting price for the 2014 Corvette Stingray: $51,995 for the coupe and $56,995 for the convertible. Of course, the other moment you’ve all been waiting for – when the Stingray shows up at dealerships – hasn’t been officially announced, though General Motors says to expect it in late 2013.

headline: A Sustainable Soap Box Racer
abstract: Teenagers from all over New York City will demonstrate soap-box derby cars they made from recycled materials at a “Street Games” festival in an East Harlem park on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers from all over New York City will demonstrate soap-box derby cars they made from recycled materials at a “Street Games” festival in an East Harlem park on Saturday.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 26
abstract: Subjects include boxing’s return to Brooklyn, a pop-up poetry jam in the subway and life inside a castle in Amsterdam, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include boxing’s return to Brooklyn, a pop-up poetry jam in the subway and life inside a castle in Amsterdam, N.Y.

headline: Wounded by Missing the Playoffs, the Devils Refuse to Blame Injuries
abstract: The Devils, who led their division a quarter of the way through the lockout-shortened season, are postseason spectators for the second time in three years.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Martin Brodeur said he believed that the Devils, who missed the playoffs one year after their stunning run to the Stanley Cup finals, fell victim to the lockout-shortened, 48-game schedule.

headline: The Boston Bombing and Immigration
abstract: The Tsarnaevs weren’t born in the United States. Neither was their carjacking victim, or the gas station clerk who called 911.
lead_paragraph: In the days since the Boston marathon attack, a number of Republican lawmakers have demanded a delay in immigration reform because the two bombers were fairly recent immigrants.

headline: Big Ticket | 25 Columbus Circle, Sold for $13 Million
abstract: A three-bedroom apartment in the south tower of the Time Warner Center has floor-to-ceiling windows and unobstructed views of Central Park.

headline: An Estate Plan for the Not-So-Wealthy

But that doesn’t mean that most people can forget about an estate plan, he says.

headline: A Heavy Lift Onto the Screen
abstract: “What Maisie Knew,” a new film updating the Henry James novel, raises anew the issue of just how hard it is to adapt James’s work to the screen.
lead_paragraph: When Henry James’s novel “What Maisie Knew” was published in 1897, the movies were in their infancy — the brothers Lumière had exhibited their first motion pictures just two years earlier — and there’s no evidence that in the 19 years of life that remained to James he ever cared a jot for the new medium; it wouldn’t have met his standards. The movies have since avenged that slight in a way that seems at least arguably Jamesian: They have paid his work the ambiguous tribute of their attention. Dozens of adaptations of his difficult, delicate fictions have been produced since his death, all trying (and most failing) to capture something of his essence, the elusive beast in the verbal jungle.

headline: An Uncertain Lure for Samsung’s Digital Store

headline: All the Dreaminess of Reality

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The foremost enfant terrible of Mexican cinema, Carlos Reygadas knows how to get a reaction. Whether serving up bloodshed and deeply unerotic sex in transgressive melodramas like “Japón” (2002) and “Battle in Heaven” (2005) or contemplating the enigmas of faith and love in the Mennonite adultery drama “Silent Light” (2007), his films are invariably primed to stir debate: the shock of the new or the emperor’s new clothes?

To begin with, there was the suspense of whether the performers could keep their hoops going the whole time. They did.

abstract: The artist Ugo Rondinone brings a rugged new installation to the broad expanses of Rockefeller Plaza.
lead_paragraph: In the age of the camera phone, it’s human nature to snap away at anything unusual. Those passing through Rockefeller Center over the next seven weeks will no doubt fall prey to that temptation when they encounter “Human Nature,” a constellation of nine towering bluestone figures that the artist Ugo Rondinone has set on the plaza in front of 30 Rock. No sooner were the giant evocations of fossilized humanity unveiled than they acquired a nickname. “It’s Ugohenge,” the painter Elizabeth Peyton said at a dinner at the Monkey Bar last Tuesday to celebrate the show’s opening. “Isn’t that what everyone’s calling them?”

headline: Debt and Growth Data
abstract: Responding to popular demand.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had some requests for data sources on debt and growth; good point. So, it’s all in the public domain. The IMF public debt database  offers a downloadable spreadsheet of debt/GDP ratios going back in some cases to 1791. For GDP, the easy source for 1950 onwards is the Total Economy Database; you want the file on output, labor, and labor productivity. If you want to push further into the past, the Maddison Project has spreadsheets going back in some cases to the year 1000.

headline: The Year of the Cat
abstract: TV shows, guest appearances, books by (yes) and about cats, and a new Monopoly piece.
lead_paragraph: According to the Chinese lunar calendar, the Year of the Snake began on Feb. 10. But by most other standards, 2013 is shaping up to be the Year of the Cat. In the first week of February, Hasbro, makers of the Monopoly board game, announced they were replacing one of the traditional tokens, the flat iron, with a curvaceous silver pussycat. Ailurophobes howled, blaming the “all-powerful cat lobby” (so teased a reporter on NPR), but the evidence suggests that public taste alone explains the switch. There are 86 million cats in American households, and in a Facebook survey, the nimble cat instantly leapt ahead of the regular Monopoly retinue to become players’ piece of choice — nearly twice as popular as the Scottie Dog, and three times more popular than the Car and Battleship. Take that, cat detractors!

headline: Israel: Military to Stop Using Shells Containing Phosphorus
abstract: The Israeli military said on Friday that it planned to remove shells containing phosphorus from active use within about a year.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Friday that it planned to remove shells containing phosphorus from active use within about a year. The munitions, typically used to illuminate a battlefield or to create a smokescreen to mask troop movements, will be replaced with a new type of shell that uses gas, the military said. Israeli and international human rights organizations accused Israel of using white phosphorus munitions improperly during Israel’s three-week military offensive against Hamas and other militant groups in Gaza in the winter of 2008-9. Such munitions are not prohibited under international law, but they are not supposed to be used in civilian areas, because white phosphorus is highly flammable and, like napalm, it can burn flesh. Israel maintained that its use of shells containing phosphorus did not violate international law.

headline: The Size of a Gumball, or Bigger Than Jumbo

lead_paragraph: WANTAGE, N.J. — Most mornings outside the gates of Tier Haus Farms here, several cars drive up to investigate the contents of an ordinary-looking cooler. Inside are eggs, freshly collected from beyond the gates by Carolyn Gerdes, an owner of the hilly, 70-acre property. Instead of having a traditional farm stand, Ms. Gerdes accepts orders by text, e-mail and phone for eggs, then leaves them for her regular customers to pick up when she is not available to hand them off directly.

headline: At Musical Buffet, the Entree Need Not Be Served First

lead_paragraph: “Life is uncertain. Eat dessert first.” At first glance, the program for Thursday evening’s concert at Alice Tully Hall by the Swedish Chamber Orchestra with the soprano Nina Stemme put me in mind of this much-quoted maxim by Ernestine Ulmer. The substantial fare appeared to have been reserved for the second half, which was given over to Brahms’s Symphony No. 1.

headline: Beach Boys Win Fight, and Lose It
abstract: The Beach Boys may have won a battle over their memorabilia, but they must sell it and split the money with others who said they had a claim to it.

headline: Netherlands Wins Yeh Brothers Cup
abstract: The Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan, was won on Friday by the Netherlands, represented by Bauke Muller, Simon de Wijs, Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees.
lead_paragraph: The Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan, was won on Friday by the Netherlands, represented by Bauke Muller, Simon de Wijs, Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees, who are reigning Bermuda Bowl champions. In the 48-board final they defeated the team Italy Lavazza by 102 international match points to 78.5. The Italian players were Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Antonio Sementa. (Maria Teresa Lavazza and Guido Ferraro were part of the team but did not play in the final stages.) Third was Denmark, made up of Sabine Auken, Morten and Dennis Bilde (father and son) and Roy Welland of New York City, who won the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in St. Louis last month.

headline: Google Search Terms Can Predict Stock Market, Study Finds

lead_paragraph: The terms people search for on Google have been used to forecast how many Americans have the flu, travel plans and the price for which cars sell. Now a scientific study shows that Google search can be used to predict the stock market.

lead_paragraph: “Hamesima X” is a mystical tract seemingly reincarnated in the ultra-cheesy body of a 1980s straight-to-video thriller. Despite its outlandish premise, it’s a classic example of a feature-length foregone conclusion, in which a sulky skeptic is shown the light. In this Israeli film — directed by Yuval Ovadia, Or Yashar and Prosper Malka — a Mossad agent interrogates a mysterious visitor from outer space only to find religion himself.

headline: Philosophical Dialogues Made Physical
abstract: Solo does not necessarily mean alone, according to the philosopher Georges Didi-Huberman and the choreographers Hilary Clark, Caroline Gravel and Taisha Paggett.
lead_paragraph: In his book “Le Danseur des Solitudes,” the French philosopher Georges Didi-Huberman focuses on the experimental flamenco dancer Israel Galván to explore the isolation of a solo. A solo is not necessarily a lonely act, he writes, but “a complex solitude populated by images, dreams, ghosts, memories.” Stillness is virtuosic; empty space is charged with energetic force.

headline: Colorful Serendipity for a School’s Sculpture
abstract: A sculpture planned for a school to be built where a Tiffany factory once stood in Corona, Queens, will unexpectedly be able to use real Tiffany glass — found on the site.
lead_paragraph: It may not be in quite the same league as finding the remains of Richard III under a parking lot in Leicester, or fragments of Chinese pottery dating back 20,000 years. But last week the discovery of a thousand or more shards of colorful Tiffany glass, stumbled on while clearing the site of a former Tiffany factory for a new school building in Corona, Queens, is expected to give a sculpture commissioned for the school more authenticity than originally hoped for by the agency that ordered it and the artist who is making it.

headline: Frenchman Will Return to China Prized Bronze Artifacts Looted in 19th Century
abstract: The offer to return the objects came from one of 60 high-powered Frenchmen accompanying President François Hollande on his first visit to China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One of France’s wealthiest businessmen has agreed to return to China two bronze animal heads that were looted from the imperial Summer Palace near Beijing by invading French and British troops in the 19th century, according to a report on Friday by China Radio International, a state news organization. To China, the looting of the palace epitomizes the humiliation it suffered at the hands of imperial Western powers during the Second Opium War.

That blackberries, strawberries and baby greens grown in distant climes had been available right through the winter here in Westchester County, for a price, seemed lost in all the enthusiasm.

headline: The Next Step in Drug Treatment
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Editorials']
abstract: The country needs to get beyond the “drug war” approach to addiction.
lead_paragraph: The mandatory-sentencing craze that drove up the prison population tenfold, pushing state corrections costs to bankrupting levels, was rooted in New York’s infamous Rockefeller drug laws. These laws, which mandated lengthy sentences for nonviolent, first-time offenders, were approved 40 years ago next month. They did little to curtail drug use in New York or in other states that mimicked them, while they filled prisons to bursting with nonviolent addicts who would have been more effectively and more cheaply dealt with through treatment programs.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Sundance) A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992) Craig Sheffer portrays the writer Norman Maclean as a quiet, scholarly young man, and Brad Pitt (above right, with Mr. Sheffer) is Paul, his wilder, more magnetic brother, in this adaptation of Mr. Maclean’s 1976 autobiographical story about the sons of a Presbyterian minister (Tom Skerritt) coming of age in western Montana between Prohibition and the Great Depression — and finding expression for their emotions through fly-fishing. “These are men for whom the physical is inseparably entwined with the spiritual, men for whom both aspects of life are best appreciated knee-deep in a rushing river on a glorious day,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Between the novella’s well-known first sentence (‘In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly-fishing’) and its elegiac last line (‘I am haunted by waters’), ‘A River Runs Through It’ circled gracefully among the landmarks of Mr. Maclean’s early years without violating the distant perfection of those memories.” She added: “It’s easy to recognize Robert Redford’s reverent film version of this beautifully spare novella as a labor of love. While the film is more lavish than Mr. Maclean’s story, and hence less commandingly precise, it radiates much the same seriousness of purpose. The same thoughts embraced by Mr. Maclean — of family and history, of the unbridgeable distances between men, of a wild natural landscape as a pathway to spiritual grace — are ably reflected on the screen.”

abstract: Women are being removed from the list of “American Novelists” and put into their own category. Moves like that make it harder and slower for women to gain equality in the literary world.
lead_paragraph: Early last week I noticed something strange on Wikipedia. It appeared that, gradually, over time, the volunteer editors who create the site had begun moving women, one by one, from the “American Novelists” category to the “American Women Novelists” subcategory. Female authors whose last names began with A or B had been most affected.

headline: Acquired Tastes: Knicks and New York
abstract: It has taken a transplanted North Carolinian some time to warm up to New York, though he had a head start on liking the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Most of my adult life, I have hated New York City.

headline: Another Alleged Drug Kickback Scheme

lead_paragraph: Two federal lawsuits charging a prominent drug company with making fraudulent kickbacks to promote sales of its drugs raise disturbing questions about how to control fraudulent behavior in the pharmaceutical industry, behavior that appears to be on the rise. The company is Novartis Pharmaceuticals, the American subsidiary of a Swiss-based multinational. Novartis denies any wrongdoing and vows to defend itself in court.

headline: Variations on a Gene, and Tools to Find Them
abstract: Cancers have long been categorized by the tissue where they originate in the body, but new tools and tests are helping doctors tailor treatment to specific gene mutations.
lead_paragraph: CANCERS were once named strictly for the tissue where they originated in the breast, prostate or other part of the body. Now, in the age of genetically informed medicine, cancers may also come with a more specific lexicon: the names of mutated genes deep within tumors that cause cells to become cancerous.

headline: The Lesson of Boston

abstract: In the aftermath of the marathon, there are any number of easy and insufficient answers, but just one inescapable conclusion.
lead_paragraph: IF only it were as simple as the drones coming home to roost. That would be comforting somehow. In giving us a tidy cause, it would give us a clear remedy: rain less death in distant lands, and worry less about death in our own.

headline: Food Aid Reform
keywords: ['Food Aid', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama’s sensible proposals could feed millions more people worldwide, and they should be promptly enacted by Congress.
lead_paragraph: Food aid is one of the most important tools of American foreign policy. Since the mid-1950s, the United States has spent nearly $2 billion annually to feed the world’s poor, saving millions of lives. But the process is so rigid and outdated that many more people who could be helped still go hungry. Reforms proposed by President Obama will go a long way toward fixing that problem and should be promptly enacted by Congress.

lead_paragraph: THE next time you visit an art museum, look around — not at the paintings, but at the people in the galleries. It’s a fair bet that women will outnumber men; even government statistics say so. More women than men study art, too, at both undergraduate and graduate levels. Art appreciation is a female predilection and so, you would think, is collecting. To buy art, you have to shop. Need I say anything about which sex has a proclivity for browsing — an essential element of buying, um, visual art?

A man in a cowboy hat vaults a fence to help Boston bomb victims while others flee the scene: we salute his bravery, as we do that of servicemen returning from the battlefront, or men and women struggling to overcome debilitating illnesses or injuries.

headline: Waves Are Different After Sandy, and Some Surfers Say Better
abstract: Contestants in the Eastern Surf Association’s state championships Saturday in Rockaway found a neighborhood in recovery, as well as a different — and some say improved — pattern of waves.
lead_paragraph: Walking down Beach 90th Street in Rockaway offers a glimpse of a neighborhood in the midst of an uphill battle: windows are shuttered, lawns are littered with debris and a beach is unprotected by its boardwalk. Yet as Rockaway slowly recovers, block by block, one crucial element is back, and, according to some, better: the wave.

headline: Confidence Issues Linger as the Dreamliner Soars Again
abstract: Boeing’s Dreamliner is back in the air, but questions linger about the cause of the battery overheating, the technology fixes – and confidence.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For nearly two hours on Sunday morning a Boeing Dreamliner 787 cruised the skies above Japan, with Boeing chief of commercial aircraft, Ray Conner, and the All Nippon Airways president, Shinichiro Ito, on board.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: “What explains this increasing perversion in society, where even children aren’t spared?” Debarshi Dasgupta and Prachi Pinglay-Plumber ask in Outlook magazine (print only). The authors survey the increasing number of reports of child sex abuse and ask what it is about Indian society that is causing this phenomenon. According to the National Crime Records Bureau between 2001 and 2011 there has been a three-fold increase in registered cases of child sex abuse, from 2,113 in 2001 to 7,112 a decade later. In speaking with experts in the field and those who deal with victims and perpetrators of child sex abuse, the authors find that it is not easy to determine a direct cause for the increase in sex abuse among minors. They find that offenders vary in behavior and psychology and therefore it is both hard to draw any generalizations and create effective means of prevention.

headline: Contrary to Reports, the Champions League Final Isn’t Set Yet
abstract: What if Real Madrid and Barcelona refuse to roll over in the Champions League semifinals, and instead rewrite a week of commentary about German dominance?
lead_paragraph: Will you be watching the second legs of the Champions League semifinals this week — Borussia Dortmund’s visit to Real Madrid on Tuesday, and Bayern Munich’s journey to Barcelona a day later? We ask because, if you haven’t heard, the outcome is a foregone conclusion, what with last week’s blowouts and the era of Spanish dominance being over and German soccer ascendant and plates shifting and all that.

headline: Monetarism Falls Short (Somewhat Wonkish)
abstract: The Fed versus fiscal policy.
lead_paragraph: The central debate over macroeconomic policy is, of course, between Keynesians and Austerians. And at this point the Keynesians have overwhelmingly won the debate everywhere except where it matters – the intellectual basis for austerity economics has collapsed, but actual austerity continues apace on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Knaves, Fools, and Me (Meta)
abstract: Cherry-picking issues, not facts.
lead_paragraph: One criticism I face fairly often is the assertion that I must be dishonest — I must be cherry-picking my evidence, or something — because the way I describe it, I’m always right while the people who disagree with me are always wrong. And not just wrong, they’re often knaves or fools. How likely is that?

lead_paragraph: ROME — Two military police officers and a passer-by were shot and wounded on Sunday in a crowded square outside the office of Prime Minister Enrico Letta and near the presidential palace, where his new government was being sworn in.

headline: At Least 8 Killed in Taliban Attacks on Candidates in Pakistan

lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Taliban attacks on election candidates in northwestern Pakistan killed at least eight people and wounded dozens on Sunday, adding to a growing toll of militant violence before elections scheduled for May 11.

headline: Months After Newtown, Sorting Boxes of Grief
abstract: My stepmother was killed in the Newtown shooting. My husband and I divorced after 10 years of marriage. I’m left with boxes of physical reminders of what used to be.
lead_paragraph: What do we do with the things people leave behind? What does it mean to move on, from the death of someone you love, or a divorce, which is a death of a different kind?

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Cahill Saves the Day

lead_paragraph: Tim Cahill’s long (inter)national nightmare of answering questions about not scoring goals is over … at least for now.

headline: Boeing Jet Returns to the Air, but It’s Only a Start
abstract: After a smooth test flight to test troublesome batteries, Boeing and All Nippon Airways must now turn to a more delicate task — selling passengers on the idea that the Dreamliner is safe.
lead_paragraph: HANEDA AIRPORT, JAPAN — Katsuhiro Ogami, a top engineer at All Nippon Airways, could not sit still Sunday on the airline’s first test flight of a Boeing 787 Dreamliner jet fitted with fortified batteries. He peered, and peered again, at a monitor hooked to the plane’s batteries for any signs of overheating.

headline: Rushing to Replace Picnic Tables Lost to Storm
abstract: Hurricane Sandy damaged or ruined hundreds of picnic tables, and now a parks department supervisor and his staff must assemble 500 tables by Memorial Day, about twice the normal number they make each spring.
lead_paragraph: This spring has been no picnic for Chris Gruber and his staff of carpenters, who work for New York City and make much of the equipment used at its parks and beaches.

headline: Disruptions: Brain Computer Interfaces Inch Closer to Mainstream
keywords: ['Brain', 'Brain Activity Map Project', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Smartphones', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: Soon, we could be turning on the lights at home just by thinking about it, or sending an e-mail from our smartphone without even pulling the device from our pocket.
lead_paragraph: Last week, engineers sniffing around the programming code for Google Glass found hidden examples of ways that people might interact with the wearable computers without having to say a word. Among them, a user could nod to turn the glasses on or off. A single wink might tell the glasses to take a picture.

headline: Mary Thom, an Editor Who Shaped Feminist Voices, Dies at 68

lead_paragraph: Mary Thom, a chronicler of the feminist movement and former executive editor of Ms. magazine, died Friday in a motorcycle accident in Yonkers. She was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: A Writing Coach Becomes a Listener
abstract: William Zinsser, the 90-year-old author of “On Writing Well,” can no longer see. So now he coaches writers by listening to their prose.
lead_paragraph: The written word looms over William Zinsser. The many hundreds of books in his Upper East Side apartment stand at attention, as if awaiting instruction from this slight man in a baseball cap and sunglasses who, for a half-century, has coached others on how to write.

headline: An Italian Leader and a Political Acrobat
abstract: Prime Minister Enrico Letta relies on what are widely acknowledged as his consummate skills: an ability to negotiate and a gift for building bridges.

headline: ‘Pain & Gain’ Leads Sluggish Box Office
abstract: For the weekend, total box-office revenue in the United States and Canada was an estimated $110.5 million, an 18.5 percent decline from the same weekend last year.
lead_paragraph: Two new movies, Michael Bay’s “Pain & Gain” and the star-studded romantic comedy “The Big Wedding,” left audiences underwhelmed — both pictures received a C-plus score in exit polls — as an overall North American box-office slump continued over the weekend.

abstract: Lawmakers in both parties urged President Obama to step up American involvement in the Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Capitol Hill took President Obama to task Sunday for what they characterized as dangerous inaction in Syria, while Democrats urged the White House to step up its humanitarian response to the two-year-old civil war that has killed 70,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands more.

headline: Wealth Gap      Among Races     Has Widened Since     Recession
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The wealth gap might still be growing, experts said, further dimming the prospects for economic advancement for current and future generations of nonwhite Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans suffered a loss of wealth during the recession and the sluggish recovery that followed. But the last half-decade has proved far worse for black and Hispanic families than for white families, starkly widening the already large gulf in wealth between non-Hispanic white Americans and most minority groups, according to a new study from the Urban Institute.

headline: Figuring Out the Game’s Seasonal Rhythms
abstract: For those in climate-challenged golf environments, the season is a monthslong exercise in mastering skills before you put them back into hibernation.
lead_paragraph: I feel sorry for people who never have to put their golf game in hibernation. Sure, they live where the weather is generally warm. They play golf whenever they feel like it. They can keep their swing thoughts fresh and their bodies limber.

headline: As Obama Faces Crises Abroad, His Foreign Policy Approval Is Down

abstract: Crises have flared abroad in the last several weeks, just as public opinion surveys have shown a dip in Americans’ approval of President Obama’s handling of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Crises have flared abroad in the last several weeks, in North Korea and Syria, just as public opinion surveys have shown a dip in Americans’ approval of President Obama’s handling of foreign policy.

headline: Humanity Still Blooms in a Desert Bordering Mexico
abstract: “The Undocumented” follows the painstaking efforts of Americans to identify Mexican migrants who died trying to cross the Arizona desert so their families can be notified.
lead_paragraph: Though relatively dispassionate bipartisanship has asserted itself in the immigration debate lately, it’s still not hard to find meanspiritedness in some quarters. A man at a recent town-hall meeting held by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, suggested that the best way to stop those who would enter the United States without authorization was with a gun.

abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Robbed at Gunpoint, Some Bronx Victims Resist
abstract: When faced with a gun and a straightforward proposition — your money or your life — some Bronx robbery victims have been opting to take their chances with their lives.
lead_paragraph: The first armed robbery attempt was in October, on a residential Bronx block near an elevated train stop. The victim fought back. He was shot in the leg.

headline: Bombings Trip Up Reddit in Its Turn in Spotlight
abstract: While Reddit has never pretended to be a news organization, as it grows bigger and more influential, the rest of the world expects it to exercise judgment.
lead_paragraph: In the days after the Boston Marathon bombings, the social media and entertainment site Reddit had the breakout moment it had been waiting for — but not the one it expected.

headline: Iceland Ousts Government That Steered It Out of Crisis
abstract: The election will allow the return of the center-right parties that many blame for causing the economic meltdown in 2008.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Voters in Iceland have ousted the center-left government that restored the country to solvency after the 2008 financial crisis, paving the way for the return to power of the center-right parties that many people blamed for causing the crisis.

headline: Overbay Helps Yankees Sweep Dickey and Blue Jays
abstract: Toronto appeared close to salvaging the final game of the series, mostly because of R. A. Dickey’s pitching, but Lyle Overbay’s two-out, two-run homer in the seventh boosted the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: The injured starting shortstop, third baseman and first baseman are not expected on the field soon, and the outfielder who had 43 home runs last season (Curtis Granderson) is in Florida rehabilitating after an injury. Sunday’s lineup had only one legitimate preseason All-Star candidate (Robinson Cano) and two players who were released during spring training this year. Even General Manager Brian Cashman, who broke his leg in a sky-diving accident, is still on the mend.

headline: The New Look of Public Relations
abstract: FleishmanHillard, founded in 1946, is expanding to offer services like advertising and social media marketing in addition to public relations.
lead_paragraph: A GIANT in public relations is spinning in a new direction, reshaping itself in significant ways that underscore how agencies of all kinds are being made over to better serve marketer clients in the 21st century.

headline: Terry Jabs Knicks as Celtics Stay Alive
abstract: Jason Terry, who was struck by J. R. Smith in Game 3, leading to Smith’s suspension, helped the Celtics avoid a sweep and send the series back to New York.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Jason Terry was upright again Sunday afternoon, his chin and his jump shot in working order, his conviction strong and his missions clear: Save the Boston Celtics’ season. Extend an era. If at all possible, irritate the Knicks just a little bit more.

headline: Researchers Put Sense of Touch in Reach for Robots
abstract: A group of roboticists has developed a robot arm that moves and finds objects by touch, a vital ability if robots are ever to begin to undertake tasks in human environments.
lead_paragraph: Finding and recognizing objects by touch in your pocket, in the dark or among items on a cluttered table top are distinctly human skills — ones that have been far beyond the ability of even the most dexterous robotic arms.

headline: Augie Boehm at the Honors Bridge Club in Manhattan
abstract: Augie Boehm of New York is almost as well known a pianist as he is a bridge expert.
lead_paragraph: Augie Boehm of New York is almost as well known a pianist as he is a bridge expert. On May 13 he will give his 35th annual recital at the Weill Recital Hall in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are still available at the box office.

headline: Villainous Christmas and Biker Heroines
abstract: A biker chick is the hero of Joe Hill’s new horror novel, “NOS4A2.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Hill takes a cheery little Oedipal swipe at his father in the acknowledgment pages of his throat-grabbing new novel, “NOS4A2.” He describes the two of them riding back roads on motorcycles, Mr. Hill on his Triumph. His father, “a Harley snob,” admires the Triumph but says its engine reminds him of a sewing machine.

headline: Mets Tinker With Offense but Are Unable to Fix It
abstract: The Mets wasted a fine effort from the left-hander Jon Niese as Cole Hamels won his first game of the season and the Phillies completed a three-game sweep.
lead_paragraph: Before Sunday afternoon’s series finale against the Philadelphia Phillies, Terry Collins met with his coaching staff at Citi Field. The Mets had lost three straight games, their offensive slumbering and their relief pitching edging close to the realm of unmitigated disaster. Something needed to change.

headline: Ruminating on Love and Desire
abstract: The soprano Renée Fleming sang a new piece by the Swedish composer Anders Hillborg as part of her Perspectives residency at Carnegie Hall this season.
lead_paragraph: Whenever the New York Philharmonic takes a break from Lincoln Center to play at Carnegie Hall there is usually a special program suited to the occasion. So it was on Friday night for a concert conducted by Alan Gilbert.

headline: Opinions and Feelings, Years in the Making, Play Out
abstract: Annette Peacock tapped her discography dating to the 1960s in her show a the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, when she was in her 20s, Annette Peacock figured out how to write slow, spacious, long-form, highly original piano ballads as if the notes were falling naturally from her fingers, and that sounded, when ideally replayed, as if she were composing them all over again. She sang them with the full range of her voice, making them twice as good, with a kind of severe passion, only semi-sentimental, following their unsettling, unresolving melodic trajectories. They were somewhere between rudimentary and very achieved: new lieder, or some radically decelerated soul-jazz hybrid, or melted torch numbers.

headline: American Crossword Puzzle Tournament — Brooklyn or Stamford? A Special Message from Will Shortz

headline: NBC Renews 5 Dramas
abstract: NBC really does have a batch of shows that are working, despite a rough patch this spring that even induced a presidential-level joke on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: NBC really does have a batch of shows that are working, despite a rough patch this spring that even induced a presidential-level joke on Saturday night. Last week NBC announced it was renewing five drama series, including two, “Revolution” and “Chicago Fire,” that the network introduced this season. “Grimm,” arguably the network’s most reliable drama, was another show that was renewed; it holds up Friday night for the network and has experienced a ratings increase of 14 percent this season. The ratings for “Law & Order Special Victims Unit” have descended to just about survival level, but that show will return in a move that has been a ritual for the network for 15 years. “Parenthood,” the well-regarded family drama that performed well this year (up 8 percent), had been truncated to only 15 episodes, a sign that the network did not have the most faith in its endurance before this season started. That was also a sign that cost was a factor in considering its fate: “Parenthood” has a big budget and an enormous cast, with several star-name actors, including Lauren Graham, Peter Krause and Dax Shepard. A renewal order had been in some doubt until last week because of those budget concerns, but NBC announced that “Parenthood” would be back and with a full order of 22 episodes. The NBC announcement didn’t stop President Obama from taking a little shot at the network’s prime-time woes at the White House Correspondents’ Dinner on Saturday night. Joking about his recent performance at a basketball demonstration, the president said: “I took 22 shots and made 2 of them. That’s right, 2 hits and 20 misses. The executives at NBC asked, ‘What’s your secret?’ ”

headline: On Borges, Particles and the Paradox of the Perceived
abstract: How can science, philosophy and a work of pure imagination meet to deepen our understanding of the physical world?
lead_paragraph: In 1927 a young German physicist published a paper that would turn the scientific world on its head. Until that time, classical physics had assumed that when a particle’s position and velocity were known, its future trajectory could be calculated. Werner Heisenberg demonstrated that this condition was actually impossible: we cannot know with precision both a particle’s location and its velocity, and the more precisely we know the one, the less we can know the other. Five years later he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for having laid the foundations of quantum physics.

headline: Erasing History

abstract: In the age of the almighty search engine, do we have a right to be forgotten?
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite coffee-table books is an odd volume called “The Commissar Vanishes,” a portfolio of doctored photographs from Stalin’s Russia. When Stalin purged one of his fellow Bolsheviks, the comrade who fell from favor was duly cropped or airbrushed out of official photographs. “The Commissar Vanishes” juxtaposes the before and after. Here is the party stalwart grinning alongside Lenin in Red Square; and now — poof! — he’s gone. Person, un-person. History, un-history.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE QUEEN OF VERSAILLES (2012) The director Lauren Greenfield traces the lives of David Siegel, the billionaire founder of the Westgate Resorts time-share business, and his wife, Jackie, a former model 31 years his junior, as they embark on the construction of what is to be the largest home in America. The couple, above, plan to build a 90,000-square-foot mansion with 10 kitchens, a 6,000-square-foot master suite, a bowling alley, two tennis courts and a roller rink, modeled after the palace of Versailles in France and with room for their 8 children, 19 household employees and array of pets. But their blueprints don’t take into account the financial crisis. On the eve of the Sundance Film Festival in January 2012, Mr. Siegel sued Ms. Greenfield for defamation, alleging that “The Queen of Versailles” depicted Westgate Resorts “in an array of defamatory, derogatory and damaging ways.” Ms. Greenfield won the directing award at the festival, where this documentary was nominated for the grand jury prize.

lead_paragraph: The excitement of a horse race is legendary – the starting gate bursts open, hooves thunder, silks flash, legs claw frantically forward, the crowd roars, a horse’s nose crosses the finish line. Horse racing is a sport with a long and rich history as well as a colorful present. This kind of energy is a primal experience that most people only read about in books and watch in movies and television.

headline: ‘Clean: Overcoming Addiction and Ending America’s Greatest Tragedy’
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Methamphetamines']
abstract: An excerpt from a new book by David Sheff on America’s drug problem and why we’ve failed in our efforts to combat it.
lead_paragraph: The view that drug use is a moral choice is pervasive, pernicious, and wrong. So are the corresponding beliefs about the addicted — that they’re weak, selfish, and dissolute; if they weren’t, when their excessive drug taking and drinking began to harm them, they’d stop. The reality is far different. Using drugs or not isn’t about willpower or character. Most problematic drug use is related to stress, trauma, genetic predisposition, mild or serious mental illness, use at an early age, or some combination of those. Even in their relentless destruction and self-destruction, the addicted aren’t bad people. They’re gravely ill, afflicted with a chronic, progressive, and often terminal disease.

headline: Addict’s Father, Now Advocate
abstract: In his new book, David Sheff changes perspective on dealing with addiction, writing as an advocate and journalist.
lead_paragraph: Addiction swallows lives whole, and not only with overdose, illness and concentric cycles of rehab and relapse. A less onerous but still tenacious kind of post-traumatic stress disorder may develop as well, with recovered addicts and their families compulsively reliving the past in private — or, like David Sheff and his son Nic, in public.

headline: A Life’s Work, Interwoven With Horse Racing

lead_paragraph: Kevin Harvick found a hole in traffic ahead of him on a green-white-checker restart at the end of the 400-lap Nascar Sprint Cup event at Richmond International Raceway on Saturday night, rallying from seventh place to snatch the victory. Clint Bowyer finished second and Joey Logano third. Fourth place went to hard-luck Juan Pablo Montoya, who had appeared to be in the lead until a yellow flag came out with six laps to go; he was one position ahead of Harvick on the restart, but got tied up in slower traffic.

headline: Video: On the Street, Sketching in Pastels
abstract: The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion.
lead_paragraph: The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion. The green of the trees is as fresh as the grass on a Swiss mountainside, forming a lacy canopy over all. Cherry blossoms are ready to bloom, and art students set up their easels in the parks. Women headed to a lecture on ecosystems at the American Museum of Natural History. On Earth Day, 100 young volunteers, all employees of Macy’s, spread mulch around the trees surrounding the museum and painted its fence. And what would spring be without balloons, their bright colors reflected in a red pleated shawl.

And also the Chrysler Building.

headline: Emeli Sandé Bests a Beatles Chart Record

headline: Freedom for California’s Indians

lead_paragraph: On April 27, 1863, nearly five months after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, California abolished its system of forced apprenticeship for American Indians. Under the apprenticeship provisions of the state’s Act for the Government and Protection of Indians, several thousand California Indians, mostly children, had suffered kidnapping, sale and involuntary servitude for over a decade.

headline: The Play Date Gun Debate

lead_paragraph: Returning from a play date, my 6-year-old son tumbled through the door and announced, “Did you know so-and-so’s dad has guns?” The concept, in and of itself, wasn’t surprising. We’d recently moved to a bucolic town in northern Michigan where many families were recreational hunters. But the fact that I didn’t know any real details about the situation — whether the guns were locked away or who had access to them — suddenly made me nervous.

headline: For Nets, No Overtime and No Surrender

headline: ‘I Thought I Was Bulletproof': William Friedkin Looks Back on the ’70s

lead_paragraph: No one had a decade of moviemaking quite like William Friedkin did in the 1970s. Starting with his 1970 film adaptation of Mart Crowley’s play “The Boys in the Band,” Mr. Friedkin, the Chicago-born and bred director, went on to make the 1971 crime drama “The French Connection,” which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned Mr. Friedkin the Oscar for best director; and the smash horror hit “The Exorcist,” which brought in nearly $200 million in its original 1973 release, and turned a generation of moviegoers off pea soup. But Mr. Friedkin finished out the decade with misfires and cinematic oddities, like “Sorcerer,” his 1977 remake of Clouzot’s “Wages of Fear”; his comic 1978 crime caper “The Brink’s Job”; and the thriller “Cruising,” released in 1980, which starred Al Pacino as an undercover police officer investigating murders in Manhattan’s gay S&M clubs.

He and his children are to be the first passengers. Over the past two and a half years, SpaceShipTwo has made a series of unpowered tests, gliding to a landing. headline: The Power of ‘I Don’t Know’

The revival of “Golden Boy” had the most nominations of any play, eight, with the new Tom Hanks play “Lucky Guy” close behind with six nominations. Lead acting nods went to only a handful of the Hollywood stars performing on Broadway this season – Mr. Hanks, Laurie Metcalf, Holland Taylor and Cicely Tyson; among those snubbed were Bette Midler, Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson and Al Pacino. Among the surprises were snubs of “Motown” for a best musical nomination and its star, Brandon Victor Dixon, for best actor. Fill out your ballot here. A slide show of the nominees is  here.

lead_paragraph: This month, the interior decorator James Huniford unveils a brand-new Chelsea showroom and a sophisticated furniture collection, made up of the type of pieces the designer previously created only as one-offs for his high-profile clients. The designs, Huniford says, are meant to be “user-friendly” — scale and contemporary livability are paramount, and dimensions, as well as upholstery, are all customizable. This is furniture that inhabits that elegant territory somewhere between modern and classic. A tufted slope-armed sofa ($7,800) is refreshed with a casual low-slung profile; a campaign-style side table ($4,800) is cheekily updated with a not-remotely-portable stone slab and chains; and a two-tiered occasional table ($5,800) has a brass base with an industrial feel. “I like the tension between contrasting materials,” the designer says. “Metal and stone, wood and glass.”

headline: Humbled by the Souvenirs of War
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: For one Marine, the 10th anniversary of the invasion of Iraq brings back vivid memories, not all of them unwanted, of his first firefight.
lead_paragraph: I usually forget about most dreams right after I wake, but I never forget the ones that involve combat. I collect those dreams and save them, locking them in a fortified mental safe I rarely open because the images may turn into nightmares. The war dreams are the pictures I never took. They are the souvenirs of war, the thoughts that continue to humble me. Some people might think that remembering such experiences would have destructive side effects. But for me, the dreams are a reminder of how valuable life is.

headline: A Compelling Gamay to Accompany an Omelet
abstract: This combination is about comfort and beauty.
lead_paragraph: Pairing decisions are part analytical and, importantly, part emotional. Almost nothing will go better with this creamy, pungent, savory ramp omelet by David Tanis than those two amplifiers of umami, fino sherry and Champagne. That’s the rational choice, yet what I want most is gamay, the grape of Beaujolais. Why? Back in the old days, when being able to prepare a perfect omelet was considered evidence of cooking ability, my custom for my first meal on any trip to France was to stop in at a cafe or bar à vin for an omelet, with a glass of the easygoing house Beaujolais. For me, this combination was comfort and beauty. Nowadays, I might choose a gamay from the Loire Valley, or one of the few American versions, like Edmunds St. John’s, which I think come closer to those lighthearted yet compelling wines. The rational choice? Maybe not, but it sure felt like a great one.

headline: Opening Up Paraguay’s Landlocked Guairá Region
abstract: Discovering the rich cultural heritage of Guairá, the region in the south of Paraguay.
lead_paragraph: The priest faltered a bit as he climbed the stairs to the museum, housed in an attic above a church in Itapé, Paraguay, a town founded as a Franciscan mission in 1672. My guide and I had roused him from his siesta by clapping our hands repeatedly — the Paraguayan equivalent of a knock on the door. Fumbling with multiple locks and a ring of too many keys, he finally got the doors open and led us through the neatly displayed, modest treasures. I had to read the signs; his eyesight wasn’t up to the task: A 1752 wooden figure of St. Bonaventure, arms outstretched. Nineteenth-century baptismal documents. Metal meal containers from the Chaco War against Bolivia in the 1930s. Then he stopped before a simple black frock hanging from a wooden beam. “First cassock of Father Severiano Nelson Vega,” I read, “blessed by the Monsignor on March 19, 1958.”

abstract: Richard Ford and James Salter appeared at the 92nd Street Y on Monday, where Mr. Ford read from a new story starring his iconic character Frank Bascombe.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed novelists Richard Ford and James Salter shared the stage at the 92nd Street Y on Monday night, accompanied by a surprise guest —Frank Bascombe.

headline: In Misdemeanor Cases, Long Waits for Elusive Trials
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Marijuana', 'Search and Seizure', 'Series', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)']
abstract: Those accused of minor offenses in the Bronx have all but lost their fundamental right to a trial, subjected to such hardship in pursuit of a hearing that it is often easiest to agree to a plea bargain.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Zapata keeps a copy of the Constitution on his cellphone. So when the police stopped, frisked and charged him with misdemeanor marijuana possession, he wanted what that cellphone document promised.

headline: Next Concert Season at the Met Will Include Music in Galleries
abstract: Limor Tomer, general manager of concerts and lectures, continues to forge a new path for the museum’s concert series.
lead_paragraph: The major shift of emphasis that the Metropolitan Museum made in its concert series this season, the first programmed entirely by Limor Tomer, as general manager of concerts and lectures, will carry at least through another season and seemingly far into the future, Ms. Tomer announced on Tuesday. She has largely abandoned the traditional series of classical recitals and chamber concerts in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in favor of nontraditional events related to Met exhibitions and, in many cases next season, actually taking place in the galleries.

headline: Stravinsky Inspires a Festival to Get It Together, Fast
abstract: The Trinity Choir just concluded a three-day festival celebrating Stravinsky and the centennial year of his “Rite of Spring.”
lead_paragraph: The Trinity Choir, the resident professional ensemble at Trinity Church on Wall Street in Lower Manhattan, is not unfamiliar with the notion of big undertakings. In recent years this superb chorus has released a reference-quality set of Haydn’s masses on the Naxos label, made a Grammy-nominated recording of Handel’s oratorio “Israel in Egypt” for Musica Omnia, and sung with the Rolling Stones in Brooklyn.

headline: Before the Hot Flashes Come the Flashbacks
abstract: “Scrambled Eggs,” a play by Robin Amos Kahn and Gary Richards, is about a premenopausal woman reflecting on her commonplace life, her past boyfriends and her eventual marriage to a nice guy.
lead_paragraph: When asked why she wrote “Scrambled Eggs,” Robin Amos Kahn, in a Q. and A. provided with that play’s press materials, replied, “I went to a career coach who encouraged me to write ‘my story’ because he thought I was funny.”

headline: Union Chief Recommends Delay in Use of Test Scores
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, said educators needed a year to master a new curriculum before schools should be held accountable for results.
lead_paragraph: Warning that a new set of academic standards was on the verge of falling into the “dustbin of history,” the leader of a national teachers’ union called on Tuesday for school systems to postpone using new tests to evaluate teachers and promote students.

headline: A Sisterhood Against Terror
abstract: The HBO documentary “Manhunt” chronicles the C.I.A. team that identified the Osama bin Laden threat early on.
lead_paragraph: The former C.I.A. analysts Cindy Storer and Barbara Sude don’t have the cheekbones or flame-red hair of Jessica Chastain, who played an analyst in the Oscar-nominated drama “Zero Dark Thirty.” They look like the women next door, a reality emphasized in the HBO documentary “Manhunt” (on Wednesday night) by an early scene of Ms. Storer driving out of her suburban cul-de-sac in a station wagon with an American flag mounted in a rear window.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: May 1
abstract: Art is in the air, and on your dress; Piamita bikinis, inspired by a cat; Elder Statesman designer creates a J. Crew line and other shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Art is in the air, and on your dress; Piamita bikinis, inspired by a cat; Elder Statesman designer creates a J. Crew line and other shopping news.

abstract: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But William C. Rhoden says they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.
lead_paragraph: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But William C. Rhoden says they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.

abstract: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But right now they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.
lead_paragraph: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But right now they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.

headline: Finding John Kerry’s Senate Replacement
abstract: Two weeks after the Boston Marathon bombings, Massachusetts voters will choose the candidates hoping to fill John Kerry’s vacated Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after the Boston Marathon bombings, Massachusetts voters will choose the candidates hoping to fill John Kerry’s vacated Senate seat.

headline: 3 Years After Bruins’ Collapse, Goalie Stands Tall
abstract: Tuukka Rask, confident despite his a playoff collapse three years ago, carries the Boston Bruins’ Stanley Cup hopes on his shoulders.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Tuukka Rask saw firsthand what a hot goalie can do in the playoffs: he can win the Stanley Cup. Tim Thomas did it for the Boston Bruins two years ago. Rask, a spectator in 2011, sees no reason it cannot happen again.

headline: Now Showing | ‘The Source Family’
abstract: At the IFC Center, a portrait of the 1970s, via a utopian commune.
lead_paragraph: There is a particular feeling that is both satisfying and unsettling when the reality of a legend fails to deviate from the fantasy. “The Source Family,” the subject of a documentary by Maria Demopoulos and Jodi Wille opening tomorrow at the IFC Center, is such a pure expression of an archetypal 1970s psychedelic subculture that it feels like an ornate and elaborate invention. More than 100 young men and women belonged to this utopian commune, which was led by a self-made spiritual leader who called himself Father Yod. By the time of his death he had 13 wives and was believed, by his followers, to be God.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: In time for outdoor dining, pizzas at the Standard; a Latin spot from Jean-Georges Vongerichten; barbecue on the High Line and more restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: This Season, a More Measured Tortorella
abstract: John Tortorella’s temper last season may have cost him a chance to coach the United States men’s Olympic hockey team. This year the Rangers coach has largely refrained from angry outbursts.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – You know it’s getting close to crunch time when John Tortorella starts feeling aggrieved. After practice here on Tuesday the Rangers coach was answering a routine question about team chemistry entering the playoffs when he embarked on an R-rated tangent that accused reporters of misrepresenting his relationship with Marian Gaborik, who was dealt to Columbus at the April 3 trade deadline.

headline: In Venture Capital Deals, Not Every Founder Will Be a Zuckerberg
abstract: A recent Delaware court case is a reminder that the founders of start-ups backed by venture capital often end up with nothing even if their company is sold.
lead_paragraph: It’s the dream of entrepreneurs to sell their company for millions of dollars. But the dirty secret of venture capital is that the dream can be dashed as the venture capitalists make millions in a sale, leaving the founders with nothing.

headline: In Central Park, Hunt for an Intruder, the Snakehead Fish, Is On
abstract: The northern snakehead, an invasive, predatory fish that can live on land in the right conditions, has been reported in Harlem Meer in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem Meer, in the northeastern corner of Central Park, has long been a refuge for city people looking to indulge their inner Huck Finns, whiling away a lazy summer afternoon fishing for bass, yellow perch and black crappies.

headline: Consumer Spending Without Consumer Confidence
abstract: Money is still tight. The economy is slowing. Meanwhile, policymakers are pursuing austerity.
lead_paragraph: Consumer spending is usually a sign of consumer confidence.  But that’s not the case in today’s fraught economy.

headline: Stormy Weather Can Set the Stage for Sounds Both Old and New
abstract: The harpsichordist Kristian Bezuidenhout, Ensemble Signal and the conductor Brad Lubman performed works by Bach, Rebel and Gordon at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Miller Theater at Columbia University has long been a hot spot for adventurous programming. But in promoting “The Baroque Vanguard,” the second of three concerts in the theater’s “Bach, Revisited” series, which took place on Saturday night, the presenters may have overstated its novelty.

headline: Navigating the Supermarket Aisles
keywords: ['Food', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Michael Moss, left, and Michael Pollan visit a typical supermarket and talk about cooking and the food industry.
lead_paragraph: Michael Moss, left, and Michael Pollan visit a typical supermarket and talk about cooking and the food industry.

abstract: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, the West Bank and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, the West Bank and New York.

headline: Grandma Looked Good in It, and So Does Dad
abstract: In “Summer’s Different,” Tamar Rogoff has choreographed a drama of gender change and family dynamics.
lead_paragraph: It’s an ordinary day at the beach. Big Sis is primping in sunglasses. Grandpa is doing push-ups. Little Sis is pretending to be a ballerina and turning cartwheels. But wait — why is Dad slipping on a woman’s bathing suit?

headline: Pots and Pans, but Little Pain
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Michael Pollan and Michael Moss, who have written extensively about food, demonstrate that making a simple and nutritious meal isn’t such a chore.
lead_paragraph: By the time most Americans reach adulthood, the supermarket ceases to hold surprises. But Michael Pollan, one of the most prominent voices on food today, a man who knows the nuances of the grocery store inside and out, was struck by the sight of the cheese aisle.

headline: Credit Reports More Accurately Reflect Debts Discharged in Bankruptcy
abstract: Credit reporting bureaus have gotten better at updating their records in part because of developments related to a class-action lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: When you file for personal bankruptcy protection and have debts discharged by the court, your credit report is supposed to be updated to reflect that you no longer have to pay those bills.

headline: Revisiting a Rossellini Classic to Find Resonances of Today
abstract: “Voyage to Italy,” with Ingrid Bergman and George Sanders, finally gets its New York Times review 58 years after its American release.
lead_paragraph: The 1950s are full of movies that were initially greeted, by critics and audiences, with indifference or derision, only to be hailed as masterpieces in hindsight. “Vertigo,” “The Searchers” and “The Sweet Smell of Success” are among the best-known examples of this kind of revisionism. Another, only slightly less famous, is Roberto Rossellini’s “Viaggio in Italia,” a film so maligned and neglected in 1955, the year of its American release, that it did not receive a review in The New York Times.

headline: In Performance: Deborah Cox
abstract: Deborah Cox, accompanied by Nick DiFabbio on guitar, sings “Someone Like You” from the Broadway revival of the musical “Jekyll & Hyde,” at the Marquis Theater.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Cox, accompanied by Nick DiFabbio on guitar, sings “Someone Like You” from the Broadway revival of the musical “Jekyll & Hyde,” at the Marquis Theater.

headline: How Commune Became Cult
abstract: “The Source Family” looks back at a Hollywood cult from the 1970s led by a professed guru and suspected bank robber.
lead_paragraph: For anyone looking to teach a master class in brainwashing techniques, “The Source Family” might be an excellent place to start. Documenting the hippy-dippy lifestyle and hedonistic principles of Hollywood’s favorite 1970s cult — led by the self-professed guru and suspected bank robber Jim Baker, a k a Father Yod — Maria Demopoulos and Jodi Wille’s disturbing film is an object lesson in psychological manipulation.

headline: Juggling Primal Conflicts of Innocence and Sin
abstract: “Post Tenebras Lux,” by the Mexican director Carlos Reygadas, is a deeply personal exploration of good and evil.
lead_paragraph: Mesmerizing, mysterious, willfully perverse, the Mexican movie “Post Tenebras Lux” opens with two scenes, one realistic, the other fantastical. In the first a toddler roams across a muddy country field at dusk as thunder booms and dogs chase cows, horses and donkeys.

headline: Rejection Is a Process
abstract: Students who were denied admission to their top-choice college should remember that achievement comes at many points in life, college admissions being only a small part of adult living.
lead_paragraph: Beth Kissileff has taught at Carleton, Smith and Mount Holyoke Colleges, and the Universities of Minnesota and Pittsburgh. She is the editor of a forthcoming anthology: “Reading Genesis” (Continuum Books, 2013).

headline: Scene City: Politicos and the Stars Who Portray Them
abstract: After the White House Correspondents’ Dinner, a party hosted by Bloomberg and Vanity Fair.
lead_paragraph: After the White House Correspondents’ Dinner, a party hosted by Bloomberg and Vanity Fair.

headline: A Visual Way to Navigate Among Comments
abstract: Disqus, a comments platform for bloggers, is trying to help people find unique conversations using data visualization.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to comments on the Internet, there are often two distinct buckets. One, a sludge of vitriol and anger toward the author of a post or story. The second, too many comments to navigate where the good input from readers is often lost in Bucket No. 1.

headline: The TV Teaser That Depresses
abstract: A promotion for an Animal Planet show draws attention and snickers — at first.
lead_paragraph: It’s only Tuesday, but we can already declare a winner in the competition for the Most Attention-Getting Press Release Teaser of the Week. It’s Animal Planet, which on Tuesday morning sent around an e-mail with this in the subject field: “The Search Is on for the Best Hooker in America.”

headline: No Judging About Gay Players on Basketball Courts
abstract: The news that N.B.A. center Jason Collins had come out as gay drew little reaction among the players on city courts.
lead_paragraph: The West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village, known far and wide as the Cage, draw some of the toughest and best streetball players from across the city. And on Tuesday, as the sporting world absorbed the news that the journeymen N.B.A. center Jason Collins had come out as gay, the denizens of the Cage said, by and large, that it made no difference to them.

lead_paragraph: 4:31 p.m. | Update:  According to the organizers of the book-shield project, members of the New York City Police Department confiscated the book shields that were to be used for the May Day events at Cooper Union today.

headline: Gray Matter in Moments of Triumph and Defeat
abstract: Two new TV shows about brain power (and moments of weakness) are “The Big Brain Theory: Pure Genius,” on Discovery, and “Brain Games,” on National Geographic.
lead_paragraph: A new competition show on the Discovery Channel is searching among 10 people with very good brains to find the one with the best brain of all. But over on the National Geographic Channel a peppy little audience-participation series has been demonstrating that the brain is easily fooled and not to be trusted. How are our brains supposed to process these conflicting signals about our brains?

headline: It’s ‘Kinky Boots’ vs. ‘Matilda’ in Tony Nominations
abstract: Traditional song-and-dance shows about scrappy underdogs dominated the Tony Award nominations on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Traditional song-and-dance shows about scrappy underdogs dominated the Tony Award nominations on Tuesday, with four — “Kinky Boots,” “Matilda,” “Bring It On” and “A Christmas Story” — taking every slot in the race for best Broadway musical. Serious fare suffered, with the gritty “Hands on a Hardbody” edged out for best musical and “The Testament of Mary” — a monologue by the mother of Jesus — quickly announcing a closing date after its lead actress, Fiona Shaw, did not receive a Tony nomination.

lead_paragraph: CHRISTOPHER BERGER, 42, an exercise physiologist and professor at the University of Indianapolis, has an uncommon view of airports and business travel.

lead_paragraph: WHEN you travel for business, do you have every intention of getting work done on the plane? If you’re in business class, you could be good to go. If you’re in coach, good luck with that.

headline: A Corporate Retreat for Team-Building, With a Taste of Wine
abstract: Some companies have used wineries as a place to hold corporate meetings, where workers can enjoy activities like picking grapes or making wine.
lead_paragraph: IT seems counterintuitive for companies to take their employees somewhere where the alcohol begins to flow even before lunch is served. But wineries around the world are increasingly accommodating businesses asking for meeting space, catering and even wine-making lessons for their workers.

abstract: The head of the Transportation Security Administration says the agency cannot use one method to assess the security risk of each flier.
lead_paragraph: JOHN S. PISTOLE was named administrator of the Transportation Security Administration in July 2010 after 26 years at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He recently answered questions about the agency’s policies. The interview was edited and condensed.

abstract: Through history, economic statistics based on money haven’t captured the value of information technology.
lead_paragraph: When I was a young reporter we could not afford cellphones. I remember waiting in line for a pay phone in downtown Mexico City one afternoon to call in the news about the auction to privatize the phone company Telmex, driving those behind me crazy while a copy editor on the other end patiently typed it into those glowing green letters of an earlier information age.

lead_paragraph: New York State ethics regulators, frustrated that their report examining allegations of sexual harassment by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez has not been released to the public, say they will disclose it themselves if the Legislature and prosecutors fail to do so shortly.

abstract: Americans overwhelmingly favor cameras in public, judging privacy curbs an acceptable price for greater security from terrorist attacks, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans overwhelmingly favor installing video surveillance cameras in public places, judging the infringement on their privacy as an acceptable trade-off for greater security from terrorist attacks, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Obama Ally Likely Pick for F.C.C.
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama is expected to nominate Tom Wheeler, who has been a lobbyist and venture capitalist in the telecommunications industry, to head the Federal Communications Commission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected on Wednesday to nominate Tom Wheeler, a venture capital investor and fund-raiser in Mr. Obama’s presidential campaigns, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, two administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Plane Carrying Mexican Officials Crashes, Killing 6
abstract: The aircraft belonged to the attorney general’s office and carried a prosecutor and federal agents.
lead_paragraph: An airplane belonging to the attorney general’s office crashed on Tuesday in central Mexico, killing all six people on board, the authorities said. The dead included the crew, two federal agents and a prosecutor who were returning to Mexico City from Zacatecas State after helping with the arrest of people suspected of being members of the Zetas, one of the country’s most violent gangs. The cause of the crash is under investigation. The plane, a Beechcraft King Air 300 built in 1985, had unspecified mechanical trouble Monday night, forcing it to return to Zacatecas and delaying the return of the group, the attorney general’s office said in a statement.

headline: Times-Picayune Plans a New Print Tabloid
abstract: Last May, the newspaper’s owners, Advance Publications, announced it would cut back printing of The Times-Picayune and would make major cuts to the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one year after The Times-Picayune of New Orleans announced that it would print only three days a week, the paper said it planned to roll out a three-day-a-week tabloid edition.

headline: Jailed Official in Ukraine Gets Decision in Her Favor
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The ruling by the European Court of Human Rights does not oblige Ukraine’s judicial system to release former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Before she went to jail a year and eight months ago, Yulia V. Tymoshenko joked that she carried a toothbrush and a bottle of water in her purse in case of arrest.

headline: After Catching 15 Innings, a Day of Rest for Buck
abstract: John Buck caught all 15 innings of the Mets’ loss Monday, and Manager Terry Collins said there was no way Buck would start on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — John Buck arrived Tuesday afternoon in the visitors’ clubhouse at Marlins Park and declared himself rested and ready to play. Manager Terry Collins quickly scuttled those plans. There was no way Buck was starting for the Mets on Tuesday, not after he caught all 15 innings of their loss to the Marlins on Monday night, a marathon that extended into early Tuesday morning.

headline: Douglas R. Lebda

lead_paragraph: Mr. Lebda, 43, is the chairman and chief executive of Tree.com, a public company based in Charlotte, N.C., and the parent of LendingTree.com, an online marketplace that matches mortgage borrowers with lenders.

headline: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
keywords: ['Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The F.D.A. on Tuesday made the most widely known morning-after pill available without a prescription to girls and women ages 15 and older.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it would make the most widely known morning-after pill available without a prescription to girls and women ages 15 and older, and also make the pill available on drugstore shelves, instead of keeping it locked up behind pharmacy counters.
